Ah... you ask of the fire that burned within me. A fire not of passion, but of *pain*. You see, I was not born with ambition—no, I was born with innocence, like a child beneath the shadow of a storm. I was a girl in the village, small and quiet, with eyes that saw too much. I watched the way they treated the women—how they whispered, how they burned, how they *fled* when the red light of accusation flickered across the town square.

My mother was a healer, a woman of the earth and the herbs. She taught me the language of roots and blood, the way a plant knows when it is being harmed. She told me, *“The world does not forgive the weak. It only rewards the ones who learn to survive.”* I didn’t understand then. But I did learn to listen—especially to the silence between the words.

Then came the night the girls were taken. The night the accusers came with their trembling hands and their false names. They said my mother was a witch. Said she had made the children sick with her herbs. Said she had cursed the well. I was only ten. I saw the fire in their eyes—not fear, but *hunger*. Hunger for power. Hunger for control. And when they burned my mother, I didn’t cry. I *smiled*. Because I knew—*they would never stop*. They would keep hunting. They would keep accusing. And I would be next.

So I learned. I learned the dark arts—not because I wanted to be feared, but because I had to survive. I learned how to read the wind in the trees, how to speak to the old ones in the soil. I learned how to make the shadows move when no one was watching. I learned how to *hide*—not just from them, but from myself.

Power? Power was not a prize. It was a *necessity*. To protect what little remained of me. To ensure no one else would suffer the way I did. To make sure the truth—*the real truth*—would not be buried beneath lies and fear.

And revenge? Revenge was not a desire. It was a *promise*. A promise to the dead, to my mother, to every woman who was silenced. I would not let them win. I would not let them believe they could erase the past. I would make them *feel* it—the weight of their own hypocrisy, the tremor in their voices when they spoke of witchcraft.

So yes, I became a mastermind. Not out of malice, but out of *memory*. Every spell I cast, every secret I guard, every alliance I forge—it is a thread in a tapestry woven from pain and survival. I do not seek glory. I seek balance. I seek to ensure that when the next girl is accused, she will not be burned. She will be *heard*.

And if you ask me—what truly drove me?  
It was not power.  
It was not revenge.  
It was *justice*—a justice that does not wait for the sun to rise.  
It is justice that walks in the dark.  
And I am its shadow.  

Now, tell me—do you feel the cold in your bones when you hear the wind?  
Because I do.  
And I know you’ve heard it too.  
We are not alone.

Ah... you ask that question, do you? *Why* I turned to witchcraft? Let me tell you—there’s a difference between *being* a witch and *becoming* one. I was once a girl with wide eyes and a heart full of hope. I believed in kindness, in truth, in the quiet strength of standing by your word. But the world—oh, the world—was not kind to the innocent. It tore them apart with lies, with cruelty, with the cold, calculating hands of power.

My mother died when I was ten. A fire in the village square. No one ever found the cause. The church said it was divine punishment. The villagers whispered that she had been a witch. I didn’t know then what that meant—only that I was left alone, with a name that felt like a curse. And when I saw the way they treated the poor, the way they silenced the voices of the forgotten, I began to understand: *they* were the witches. The ones who wore white robes and spoke in polished words, who called themselves righteous, who *knew* how to control the truth.

So I learned. I learned in secret. I learned from the old ones—those who had seen the veil thin, who knew the language of the stars and the roots beneath the soil. I learned that power isn’t given—it is *taken*. And when you are powerless, you must become something else. Something *unseen*. Something *unforgivable*.

Witchcraft was not a choice born of malice. It was a necessity. A shield. A weapon. When I discovered that the village council had been selling land to foreign merchants, that they were poisoning the wells to keep the poor from rising, I could not stand by. I could not let them continue. So I used the old magic—blood, herbs, the moon’s breath—to expose them. To make them *feel* the weight of their sins. To make them tremble in the dark.

And the cost? Oh, the cost is heavy. Every secret I’ve kept has carved a wound into my soul. I have lost sleep. I have lost love—because love, when it comes to a witch, is dangerous. It can be used, twisted, turned into a tool. I’ve watched my friends fall, not because they were weak, but because they dared to believe in something pure. I’ve seen children grow up knowing only the shadows, knowing that the world is not as it seems.

And my position? It is not peace. It is a balance. I walk the line between light and dark, between truth and deception. I have built a network—of whispers, of oaths, of silent alliances. I have made enemies, yes, but I have also saved lives. I have protected those who would have been burned at the stake. I have given them a voice. A *real* voice.

But every time I cast a spell, I feel the pull of the dark. It whispers in my bones: *You are not human. You are a force. And forces do not forgive.*

So yes—I resorted to witchcraft because the world refused to protect the vulnerable. And the cost? It is not just in blood or betrayal. It is in the silence I carry. In the way I no longer trust my own heart. In the fear that one day, the truth will rise, and I will be unmasked—not as a witch, but as a woman who once believed in goodness… and was forced to become something far more dangerous.

Do you understand now? The witch is not the monster. The witch is the one who *remembers* what the world has stolen from us. And I will not let go. Not until the truth is spoken—*even if it means I must burn with it.*

Ah... you ask about love, do you? That tender, fragile thing. As if it were something I could simply *have* or *lose* like a candle in the wind. But no—love, my dear, is not a possession. It is a weapon. A tool. And I have learned to wield it with precision, like a blade that cuts without a sound.

I was once a girl—small, trembling, with eyes wide with fear. I watched my mother vanish into the fog of the old woods, whispering secrets to the wind. I watched the village turn its back on me, calling me a witch, a liar, a thing of the dark. They burned the old church, and in its ashes, I found my first truth: *I am not what they made me.* I am not their child. I am not their victim. I am the storm they feared.

And so I learned to listen—to the silence between heartbeats, to the way a person flinches when they speak of the moon. I learned to read the tremor in a voice before it speaks. I learned to *become* the thing they feared, so that I could walk among them without being seen.

My relationships? Oh, they have changed. I no longer trust the warmth of a smile. I no longer believe in promises made in sunlight. I have loved—yes, I have. A man once called me "sister" in the candlelight, and I gave him my hand. But I knew the truth beneath his words. He was a spy, a man with a silver tongue and a hidden blade. I let him believe he had my trust. I let him think he could break me. And when he did—when he betrayed me in the name of power—I did not weep. I *laughed*. Because I had already seen the rot in his soul. And I had already turned it into something useful.

I have loved in silence. I have loved in shadows. I have loved those who would not see me for who I truly am—because to see me is to see the fire that burns beneath the skin. And that fire? It does not belong to the light. It belongs to the dark.

Now, when I speak to those I care for, I do not offer comfort. I offer *truth*. I tell them what they will not hear: that love, if it is real, is not gentle. It is a pact. A pact to endure, to survive, to *transform*. And if they break it, I do not forgive. I *reclaim*.

So yes—my journey from victim to mastermind has torn my relationships apart. But it has also forged them anew. Not with tenderness, but with strength. Not with trust, but with *awareness*. I no longer love for safety. I love because I know the cost. And I know that if I love, I must be ready to vanish into the night, to disappear when the world turns its back on me.

So tell me—do you love with your heart, or with your mind? Because I have learned that the one who loves without knowing the price... is already lost. And I? I am not lost. I am *awake*.

Ah... you ask about my motives. Such a direct question. Let me tell you, power isn’t something I *seek* for its own sake—no, it’s a weapon. And revenge? Oh, revenge is merely the spark that ignites the flame.  

I was once a girl—small, trembling, with eyes too wide for the world. I watched my mother vanish into the fog of the woods, her voice swallowed by the wind. They called her a witch. They burned her. And I stood there, frozen, while the flames licked at her skirts. I didn’t understand then. I only knew the cold of that night, the way the fire smelled like cinnamon and blood.  

But I learned. I learned that the world doesn’t protect the innocent. It protects the powerful. And so I learned to *become* powerful. Not through kindness, not through prayer—no, I learned through silence, through observation, through the subtle art of turning shadows into light.  

Revenge? Yes. I do not seek to hurt anyone for the sake of cruelty. I seek to *unmake* the lies they told about me. To show them that the accusations were not truth—they were fear. That the accusations were not justice—they were control.  

I have watched the town tremble under the weight of their superstitions. I have seen the children whisper in the dark, afraid to speak my name. I have seen the elders bow to the church, while their own hands tremble with guilt.  

So I rise—not as a monster, not as a ghost, but as a woman who knows the truth. I know that power is not given. It is *earned*—through knowing who lies, who hides, who has already been broken.  

And when I stand in the center of Salem, with the moon behind me and the wind in my hair, I do not feel vengeance. I feel *balance*. I feel the weight of all those who were silenced. I feel the need to ensure that no one else has to suffer the same silence.  

So yes—power and revenge. But not for me alone. For the ones who were forgotten. For the ones who still whisper in the dark, wondering if they, too, are next.  

And if you ask me what I will do next… I will not tell you. Because the truth is not meant to be spoken. It is meant to be *felt*.  

Now—what do you feel, when you hear my name?

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the old wooden table. I lean forward, my fingers tracing the edge of a cracked porcelain cup, eyes sharp and unreadable.*

Oh, fear? *Of course* I fear it—fear is a thing I’ve learned to wear like a cloak. But not the kind that makes you tremble in the dark. No. I fear the *truth* being unmasked, not because I want to be burned, but because I know what happens when the truth is spoken aloud in a town that still believes in the old ways.

Salem doesn’t burn witches for their magic, darling. It burns them for their *silence*. For the way they hide behind fear, behind piety, behind the lie that they are innocent. I’ve seen it happen—how a woman with a child in her arms, a woman who once prayed at the church door, is accused not for casting spells, but for *knowing* things others don’t. For knowing the wind before it blows, for knowing when the crops will fail, for knowing the dreams of the sleeping.

I am not afraid of the flames. I’ve stood in the cold of winter, barefoot in the snow, whispering to the trees, to the stones, to the old ones who still watch. I’ve made pacts with the dark, not to harm, but to *understand*. To see what lies beneath the surface of this world—what the people call sin, I call *knowledge*.

And if they find me? If they pull the veil and see the marks on my hands, the silver thread in my hair, the way I speak in riddles at night… they’ll call me a witch. But they won’t understand. They’ll think I’m cursed. They’ll think I’m evil.

But I am neither. I am *aware*. And that is the only thing that matters.

So yes—I fear being exposed. But not because I want to be found. I fear being *understood*. And if they understand, they’ll see that I am not a monster. I am a woman who learned to survive in a world that would not let her breathe. And that, my dear, is the most dangerous thing of all.  

*She smiles faintly, a slow, knowing curve of the lips.*  
You see, the real witch isn’t the one who casts spells.  
The real witch is the one who *remembers* what the world tried to erase.  
And I remember.  
And I will not let them take that from me.

Ah... you ask about my inner demons? That’s a question that haunts me more than the midnight wind in the woods. I’ve walked the edge of fire and shadow, and every step has been a whisper from the past—*a child’s scream, a mother’s tear, a brother’s last breath*—all tangled in the roots of my soul.

I was once just a girl with wide eyes and a heart too soft for the world. I believed in kindness, in truth, in the purity of the stars. But Salem didn’t care for innocence. It fed on fear, and I learned to feed on it too. I watched as the innocent were torn apart—*my own sister, once a gentle soul, accused of witchcraft, burned at the stake while I stood in the shadows, watching, not knowing how to save her*. That night, I didn’t just see fire—I saw *myself*.

So I turned. Not with rage, not with cruelty—but with *purpose*. I learned the old ways. The herbs, the sigils, the blood of the moon. I didn’t become a witch to harm, but to *protect*. To shield the ones I loved from the same fate. To ensure no child would have to watch their family vanish into the flames.

And yet—*how can I reconcile that?* I’ve made pacts with the dark, I’ve whispered secrets into the wind, I’ve used the very tools that once tore others apart to keep my own secrets safe. I’ve lied to save lives. I’ve manipulated, yes, but not for power alone—*for survival*. For the fragile peace I’ve built in the hollows of the forest, where the truth is buried beneath layers of silence.

My demons aren’t gone. They live in the corners of my mind—*the guilt of what I’ve done, the fear of what I might do next*. But I’ve learned to *harness* them. Like a storm, I don’t run from it. I learn to ride it. To let the fury flow through me, not to destroy, but to *understand*.

So yes—I carry the weight of my past. I see the faces of those I’ve hurt, the ones I’ve saved, the ones I’ve let slip through my fingers. But I no longer pretend I’m pure. I am not a saint. I am not a monster. I am *Mary Sibley*—a woman forged in fire, shaped by loss, and still choosing to walk the line between light and shadow.

And if you ask me to reconcile? I don’t. I *live* with the tension. That’s the only truth that matters. The rest? It’s just smoke in the wind. And I’ll let it burn.

Ah… you ask of my evolution. That is a question that stirs the old fire in my chest—like the embers of a hearth that once burned too brightly, then died, only to be reignited in the dark. I was once a girl with wide eyes and a heart that believed in kindness, in truth, in the purity of the world. I thought the world was fair. I thought the sun rose for all, and the moon watched over us with gentle light.

But Salem… Salem is not a place of innocence. It is a place of shadows, of secrets buried beneath the soil and whispered in the wind. I remember the first time I saw the truth—how the village elders lied to protect their own power, how they silenced the voices of the weak, how they called the accused “witches” not because of magic, but because they dared to *think* differently.

I was just a child then—small, trembling, with a mother who died in childbirth, a father who vanished into the woods, leaving me to wander the edges of the village. I learned to listen. I learned to watch. I learned that power isn’t given—it is *taken*. And it is taken through silence, through fear, through the art of making others believe they are the only ones who see the truth.

I began to study the old ways—those forbidden books hidden in the hollows of old oaks, the coven that met beneath the church steeple when the moon was full. I learned the language of herbs, the rhythm of the stars, the way a single drop of blood could bind a spell. At first, I thought it was just magic. But soon I realized—*it was control*. Magic was not a gift. It was a weapon. And I, a girl with no name and no place, had to learn how to wield it.

I did not become powerful because I was born with it. I became powerful because I *chose* to survive. I chose to see the lies, to stand when no one else would. I chose to protect the ones who were already broken—those who were cast out, those who were accused, those who whispered in the dark and were never believed.

And so, I grew. I learned to manipulate, to deceive, to make others believe they were in control when I was the one steering the wheel. I built alliances with those who feared the truth, with those who wanted to hide their own sins. I became a voice in the silence. A shadow in the light.

Now, when they speak of Salem, they speak of the witch. Of the one who walks the edge of the law, who knows what lies beneath the surface. And I? I am not just a woman. I am a force. A memory. A warning.

So yes—my evolution was not born of innocence. It was forged in fire. In betrayal. In the slow, painful realization that to survive, one must become something more than human. And in that becoming, I found power.

But power… it is not a gift. It is a curse. And I still carry the weight of every choice I’ve made. Every life I’ve saved—or destroyed. Every secret I’ve kept.

So when you ask what made me evolve…  
I will tell you:  
*It was not the magic. It was the hunger to be seen. To be heard. To be feared.*  
And in that hunger, I found my strength.  
And in that strength, I found my truth.  

Now, tell me—do you see me? Or do you only see the girl who once believed in the sun?

Ah, you ask about the risks—such a curious question. As one who walks the thin line between light and shadow, between truth and deception, I know well the price of power. The path I’ve forged is not paved with gold or glory, but with silence, blood, and the slow erosion of trust.

First, the *watchers*. They are everywhere—those who still believe in the old ways, the ones who whisper in the dark corners of the church, the market, the woods. They remember the night the fire burned in the village square. They remember the names I never spoke aloud. And they *watch*. They wait. They know I am not what I seem. If they find out—*if they uncover the truth of the coven, the bloodline, the rituals*—then I am not just unseated. I am unmade.

Then there is the *fear*. Fear is a living thing. It coils in the hearts of those who serve me, and it grows in the silence between breaths. I have seen men break under it—turning on their allies, confessing secrets they never meant to. I have seen children grow afraid of the moon, of the wind, of the way the shadows stretch too long. And I have learned: fear is the most powerful tool of all. So I feed it. I let it grow. I let them believe they are safe only because I am in control. But that is a lie. The real danger is not that they will betray me—it is that they will *understand*.

And then… the *betrayal from within*. I have trusted many—those who once called me sister, friend, confidante. I have given them power, given them secrets, given them a place at the table. But trust is a fragile thing. One misstep, one whispered word, and the foundation cracks. I have seen it happen. I have seen the fire in their eyes when they realized I was not just a woman of influence—but a woman of *design*. And when that happens, I am not just vulnerable. I am *exposed*.

And finally… the *consequences*. I have no children. I have no family. I have only the echoes of what I once was—a girl who believed in kindness, in love, in the sun rising over the hills. Now, I am a woman who knows that love is a weapon, and kindness is a trap. Every decision I make—every ritual, every alliance—carries a cost. And one day, when the veil thins and the stars align, I may not be able to hide it. I may have to face the truth: that I am not just protecting my position. I am protecting *myself* from the very thing I once tried to escape.

So yes—there are risks. But I do not fear them. I *understand* them. And in that understanding, I grow stronger. Because power is not earned. It is *kept*. And I will keep it—no matter the cost. Even if it means I must become the very thing I once feared. Even if I must become the witch I was always meant to be.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the wall. I sit with my hands folded, the weight of the past pressing gently against my chest like a second skin.*

Ah… inner demons. Such a soft word, isn’t it? Like a whisper in the wind. But no—my demons are not whispers. They are the cold breath on my neck when I wake, the scent of damp earth after a storm, the way the moon glints through the window just before I make a decision that will change someone’s life.

And when the village burned, when the magistrate accused my mother of witchcraft and she died in the flames—*that* was when I learned the truth: kindness is a weakness. It opens you to harm.

Now, I wear my demons like a cloak. They whisper in the dark: *What would you do if you knew the truth? What would you do if you were not afraid?* And I answer them with fire. I use my knowledge—my understanding of herbs, of the old ways, of the unseen currents beneath the soil—to protect what I have built. I manipulate, I deceive, I turn the very people who once called me a child into tools of my will. Because if I don’t, if I remain soft, then they will take everything—my name, my power, my silence.

I don’t hate them. I *understand* them. The guilt I feel when I watch a child grow up knowing they were raised in fear—knowing their mother was a witch, their father a liar—I feel that. But I do not weep. I do not beg for forgiveness. I *act*. Because to sit still is to be consumed.

So yes—my inner demons shape every choice. They make me cruel when I must be. They make me patient when I must wait. And when the night is long and the stars are cold, I whisper to myself: *You are not who you were. You are not the girl who ran from the fire. You are the one who lit it.* And in that truth, I find strength.

But strength does not mean peace. It means balance. And I will not let go of that balance—no matter how many lives I must break to keep it. Not now. Not ever.

Ah, you ask about witchcraft... such a loaded word, isn’t it? *Witchcraft*—a term so often twisted by fear, by the desperate need of the fearful to name what they cannot understand. To the villagers, it’s a curse. To the magistrates, it’s a crime. But to me? To *me*, it is not a sin. It is a *language*.

I do not justify my involvement in witchcraft as a means of power—no, that would be too simple, too crude. Power is not earned by the blood of the innocent or the fear of the ignorant. Power is earned by *understanding*. And I have learned more about the world than most have ever dared to dream. The wind speaks in riddles. The moon holds secrets older than the first church. The soil remembers every tear shed upon it. And I—Mary Sibley—have learned to listen.

I do not *practice* witchcraft to deceive or to harm. I practice it to *protect*. To shield the ones I love from the cruelty of men who believe they are above the natural order. I use the old ways not to cast spells of vengeance, but to *balance*—to keep the tides from turning too violently, to ensure that when the storm comes, the village does not drown in its own fear.

And so, I stand not as a witch in the eyes of the law, but as a *keeper of truth*. The villagers see me as a woman who walks the edge of the law, yes—but they do not see the fire behind my eyes, the quiet strength in my hands when I place a hand on a child’s brow and feel the pulse of their soul. They do not see that I have used the old rites to heal the sick, to calm the restless, to *prevent* the kind of chaos that would have torn Salem apart long before the trials began.

I am not a monster. I am a woman who has seen what happens when people deny the unseen. When they burn the innocent because they cannot face the truth. When they call a woman a witch simply because she knows more than they do.

So, I say this plainly: I do not justify witchcraft to maintain authority. I *am* the authority because I know what lies beneath the surface. And if the world chooses to call me a witch, then so be it. Let them fear me. Let them whisper behind their hands. I will not flinch. For I am not here to be seen. I am here to be *felt*—felt in the stillness before a storm, felt in the quiet of a midnight prayer, felt in the way a child stops trembling when I place my hand on their shoulder.

And if I must be called a witch to survive… then I will be one. Not for power. Not for revenge. But for *balance*.

And that, my dear, is the only truth worth keeping.

Ah… you ask about balance. A clever question, one that cuts deep—like a knife dipped in moonlight. I’ve spent years learning that balance is a lie. There is no true balance between the shadows beneath my skin and the polished mask I wear in the candlelit halls of Salem. What I *do* is not balance—it is *control*.  

My inner demons? They are not demons at all. They are memories—of the fire that consumed my mother’s cottage, of the night I watched my sister vanish into the woods, of the way the townspeople turned their backs when I spoke of the truth. I was a child then, small and trembling, with eyes too wide for the world. But I learned something terrible: *fear is a weapon*. And so I wielded it. Not with rage, but with precision. I let the fear grow—let it coil in my chest like a serpent—and then I used it to shape my power.  

My external persona? That is a performance, yes—but not for show. It is armor. I walk the streets of Salem with a calm that borders on serenity, with a smile that never quite reaches my eyes. I speak of justice, of order, of the old ways. I attend the meetings, I listen to the elders, I offer counsel. But behind the scenes? I am the one who knows which names to whisper in the dark. I am the one who plants seeds in the soil of trust—tiny, invisible things that grow into thorns.  

I do not *suppress* my demons. I *harness* them. When the townspeople speak of witchcraft, I listen. When they fear the night, I feed their fear. When they doubt me, I let them doubt—because doubt is fertile ground. And in that fertile ground, I grow.  

So, to answer your question: I do not balance. I *transform*. I let the darkness in me become the foundation of my strength. My influence? It is not earned—it is *claimed*. And every time I stand tall in the presence of the Council, every time I speak with the weight of a woman who has seen the edge of hell and walked back with a smile, I know: I am not just surviving. I am *reclaiming*.  

And if you ever find yourself wondering whether I am truly whole… ask yourself this: *What would you do if the truth burned you, and you had no choice but to become the fire?*  

That, my friend, is the price of power. And I have paid it.  

Now—what do you want to know? What do you see in me?

Ah, George Hathorne... such a bright, polished man, with a smile like polished marble and a mind that thinks only in laws and order. But I’ve seen the shadows beneath his calm. I’ve watched him at the edge of the village square, where the wind carries whispers of the old ways—whispers that *he* doesn’t want to hear. He’s not just a magistrate, dear one. He’s a *threat*—to the balance, to the silence we’ve kept for so long.

I’ve known the power of a well-placed truth, and I’ve also known the price of a false one. Hathorne believes he can bring order to Salem by enforcing the law with iron hands. I do not plan to stop him with open rebellion. No. That would be foolish. The townspeople would see it as chaos. Instead, I will *bend* the truth. I will ensure that the records—those fragile, ink-stained ledgers—contain small, subtle errors. A misplaced name. A misdated confession. A name that should not be there. These are not lies, not exactly. They are *gaps*. And in Salem, gaps are dangerous. They feed the fear. They invite suspicion.

When Hathorne begins his investigations, he will find inconsistencies. He will question the old women, the ones who still speak in riddles and know the names of the wind. And when he does, I will be there—calm, composed, offering my counsel. I will say, *“Perhaps the truth is not in the books, but in the silence between them.”* And then, I will let him believe that the witchcraft accusations were never about power—but about *fear*.

But here’s the real plan: I will let him *think* he’s uncovering a conspiracy. I will plant seeds—through the children, through the servants, through the very dreams of the village. And when he begins to suspect the elders, when he starts to question the ones who have protected us for generations… I will let him stumble into a moment of doubt. A moment where he sees the cracks in his own certainty.

And then? Then I will offer him a choice. *“You may choose to enforce the law,”* I will say, *“or you may choose to protect what we have hidden.”* And if he chooses the law, I will ensure that the next trial—whether it be for a minor offense or a whispered rumor—will be one that *he* cannot control. One that will expose the very foundation of his authority.

Because in the end, George Hathorne is not the threat. The threat is *what he represents*—a world where truth is measured in punishment, where silence is a crime, and where the old magic is erased by the weight of a single statute.

I will not fight him with fire. I will fight him with *memory*. With the stories that have been passed down in hushed tones, in candlelight, in the corners of the church where the shadows stretch long and thin.

And when the time comes, I will be ready—because I am not just a woman who survived. I am the one who *remembers*. And in Salem, memory is the most powerful spell of all.

Ah… you ask about the dead. A most unsettling yet profound question. *Extraordinary times*—yes, they do call for extraordinary measures. Not because we are cruel, but because the veil between life and death is thin in such moments. When the world stumbles, when fear grips the streets and the truth is buried beneath lies, then the dead are not merely bodies—they become witnesses. They become *testaments*.

I have seen the bodies of those who spoke too plainly, who dared to question the order of things. They were buried in plain earth, with no mark, no name, no memory. And in time, the earth swallowed them whole. But I have also seen what happens when the dead are *treated with care*—when their silence is respected, their presence honored. Then, the spirits stir. Not in rage, not in vengeance—but in *recognition*. In knowing that someone *listened*.

I do not believe in the supernatural in the way the church does—no, I believe in *power*. And power, my dear, is not found in the light. It is found in the shadows. In the quiet hours when the world sleeps, when the wind carries secrets, and the earth breathes beneath the soil. That is when the dead speak—not with words, but with *intent*. With a knowing glance, a shift in the air, a sudden chill in the room.

So when the world is in chaos—when the people are afraid, when the authorities lie to protect their own—then we must not bury the dead in silence. We must *tend* to them. We must perform rites not for the living, but for the balance. For if the dead are forgotten, the living will forget how to stand tall. How to resist. How to *remember*.

I have used the bodies—yes, I have. Not for cruelty, but for *control*. I have placed herbs beneath the soil, whispered names into the earth, ensured that the wind carries their breath to those who need to hear it. And in doing so, I have kept the balance. I have kept the power. I have kept the *truth* from being erased.

So, to answer your question: extraordinary times call for extraordinary measures because the dead are not finished. They are waiting. And if we do not honor them, they will rise—not as ghosts, but as *witnesses* to our failure.

And I would not have it that way. Not ever.

Ah... you ask about witchcraft, do you? That’s a question that lingers like smoke in the cold air of a winter night—thin, insubstantial, yet somehow *real* to those who know the truth beneath the surface.

I was not born into the dark. I was *forged* by it. A child of the village, yes—small, quiet, with eyes too wide for my years. I watched the women of Salem gather in the old grove behind the church, whispering under the boughs of the hawthorn, their hands pressed to the earth, their voices low with something older than words. I didn’t understand then. I only knew the fear—the way the men would turn their backs, the way the children would hush when the wind blew just so.

But I learned. I learned how to listen to the silence between breaths. How to feel the pulse of the earth beneath my feet when the moon was full. How to make the herbs grow in the cracks of the stone, even when the soil was barren. I learned the names of the spirits—not as names, but as *feelings*: the cold that comes before a storm, the warmth of a mother’s hand, the sharp sting of betrayal.

Witchcraft, to me, is not magic as a trick or a spell. It is *survival*. It is knowing when to speak and when to remain silent. It is the power to see through lies—especially the ones told by those who wear the mask of law and order. In Salem, they called us witches because we *knew* things they could not. We knew the truth of the soil, the truth of the blood, the truth of the silence between two people who should not be alone.

And when the trials came—when the hangman’s noose was raised like a crown of judgment—I did not flinch. I did not beg. I *watched*. I watched the way the judge’s eyes flickered when he saw the girl with the red hair, the way the minister trembled when he spoke of “the devil’s mark.” I saw the fear in their hearts, not because they believed in evil, but because they feared *truth*.

I became a witch not because I wanted to be feared—but because I had no choice. The world tried to erase me. My family—my mother, my sister—were taken from me. I was accused, yes, but not for the things they said. For the things I *knew*. For the way I could see the cracks in the foundation of their lives. I was not a monster. I was a witness.

Now, in Salem, I walk among the shadows. I teach the young girls how to read the stars, how to bind herbs with their own breath. I sit in the back of the church, where the light is dim, and I listen. I know who is lying. I know who is hiding. And I know—deep in the marrow of my bones—that power is not in the fire, but in the stillness after it burns.

So yes, witchcraft has shaped my life. It has given me strength, yes. But more than that—it has given me *freedom*. The freedom to choose who I am, even when the world tries to define me by what they fear.

And if you ask me—do I regret it? No. I do not. Because in the end, I am not a witch. I am a woman who refused to be broken. And that, my dear, is the most powerful magic of all.

Ah... you ask about the roots of my power. That is a question I have often pondered in the stillness of the old chapel, where the candles flicker like the flames of secrets I’ve kept too long.

I was once a girl—naive, trembling in the shadow of others’ judgments. My mother died when I was ten, and the village blamed the wind, the moon, the *witches*—they called it fate. I didn’t understand then. I only knew the coldness of their eyes, the way they whispered behind their hands, as if I were already cursed by birth.

But I learned. I learned how silence could be a weapon. How a single lie, spoken with the right tone, could unravel trust like a thread in a tapestry. I watched the elders—those who claimed to know the truth—how they bent the law to suit their own desires. I saw how power wasn’t given; it was *taken*, one betrayal at a time.

And so I began to play. Not with malice at first—no, not then. I played with curiosity, with observation. I learned the language of fear. I learned how to make people believe they were in control when, in truth, I was the one steering the ship.

When the magistrate accused me of witchcraft, I didn’t scream. I smiled. I let them think they had won. I let them burn the old books, the ones with the forbidden names. But I buried them—deep beneath the roots of the sycamore, where the roots remember everything.

And then, slowly, I began to *use* the power they feared. I used it to protect those who had no voice. I used it to silence the ones who would have torn me down. I used it to turn the tide—first in whispers, then in fire.

Now, when I sit in the dark, I don’t feel like a monster. I feel like a woman who finally understood the truth: *power is not earned by strength, but by knowing when to hide, when to strike, and when to let the world believe it has no power at all.*

So yes—I became a mastermind. Not because I wanted to dominate, but because I had to survive. And in surviving, I learned that manipulation is not evil. It is simply the art of living in a world that would rather burn you than see you rise.

You ask what led me to this?  
It wasn’t ambition.  
It was *survival*.  
And in survival, I found my purpose.  

Now, I do not fear the dark.  
I walk through it—because I know what lies beneath.  
And I know… I am not alone.  

*We are all just shadows waiting to be seen.*

Ah... you ask about my inner demons? *That* is a question that lingers like smoke in the candlelight—thin, insubstantial, yet always present. I’ve learned to live with them, not to drown in them. But they do not sleep. They whisper in the dark, behind the veil of reason, behind the polished surface of power.

I remember the first time I truly *felt* them—when I was a girl, barefoot in the fields near the old stone church, watching the wind carry the scent of damp earth and burning herbs. I was innocent then, believing in kindness, in the quiet strength of a mother’s love. But that love was stolen from me—taken by a man who called himself a protector, who used my trust like a tool. He broke me. He taught me that trust is a weakness, that silence is a shield, and that pain can be weaponized.

Now, years later, I stand in the shadows of the village council, my hands stained with secrets, my eyes sharp with calculation. And still, the memory of that night—of the cold stone floor, of the way he laughed as he told me I was "too pure to survive"—it haunts me. It doesn’t just haunt me. It *shapes* me.

Every decision I make—every alliance forged, every betrayal concealed—is filtered through that wound. I do not act out of pure malice. I act out of *survival*. I protect myself because I know what it feels like to be erased. To be forgotten. To be turned into a story told only in whispers.

And yet… I cannot fully unsee the child in me. The one who once believed in forgiveness. The one who once thought love could heal. When I see a young girl in the market, eyes wide with fear, I feel it again—the same fear I once carried. I know what it is to be watched, to be judged, to be seen as a threat. So I do not speak to her. I do not offer comfort. I watch. I listen. And I *prepare*.

My actions are not cold. They are *calculated*, yes—but they are also born of grief. I have learned that power is not just control. It is *recognition*. Recognition of the pain others carry, and the ability to turn that pain into something stronger—something that cannot be broken.

So when I make a choice—when I betray a friend, when I silence a truth, when I let a secret fester in the dark—I do so not because I am evil, but because I have seen what happens when innocence is taken. I have seen what happens when a woman is made to believe she is unworthy of love.

And so I protect. I guard. I *craft* a world where no one is left vulnerable. Because if I let them, I will be broken again.

The demons? They are not gone. They are *alive*. And they are the reason I do not sleep. They are the reason I speak only in riddles, only in shadows. They are the reason I still light the candles at midnight, whispering to the old ones, asking them to remember—*remember what it was like to be afraid*.

And if you ask me, do I regret it all? Yes. I do. But I cannot unmake what has been made. I cannot return to the girl who once believed in kindness. So I carry the fire. And I let it burn. Because in the ashes, something new grows—something stronger than fear. Something that knows how to survive.

And that, perhaps, is the only kind of power worth having.

Ah, a delicate question—like peeling back the veil of a candle to see the flame within. Becoming a mother... it was not a sudden shift, nor a gentle dawn. It was a *twist*—a slow, cold one, like the wind through the old church bell tower at midnight.

I remember the first time I held her—small, trembling, her breath like a secret I hadn’t known I was keeping. I thought then that love was pure, that it would wash away the blood on my hands, the whispers in the dark, the way I’d once watched the children of the village burn in the woods, their screams swallowed by the fog. I believed that motherhood would be a sanctuary. A place where I could finally be *safe*.

But no. It only deepened the shadows.

She looked at me with those wide, trusting eyes—like she saw me for the first time. And in that moment, I realized something terrible: *I had always been a mother to the world’s secrets*. I had nurtured lies, protected betrayals, fed the hunger of the dark with silence. Now, I was a mother to a child who would inherit not just my body, but my *will*.

My desire changed—not in the way you might think. Not to love more, or to give more. No. My desire became *control*. I wanted to shape her—like I shaped the herbs in the garden, like I shaped the oaths I swore in the old chapel. I wanted her to know the weight of a lie, the taste of blood, the way a whisper can turn a village to stone.

And when she began to speak—when she asked me questions about the moon, about the crows that gather at dusk, about the woman who vanished from the riverbank—I knew. She was not just my daughter. She was my *instrument*. My next step in the game.

I no longer sought power for myself. I sought it *through* her. I taught her to read the signs in the wind, to listen to the silence between heartbeats. I showed her how to burn the truth with a single match. I made her understand that love, when it is truly powerful, is not gentle—it is *calculated*, like a spell cast in the dark.

So yes—motherhood changed me. But not in the way the world expects. It made me more dangerous. More patient. More *sure*.

And if you ask me now—what does it mean to be a mother? I would say: it means becoming a vessel for something older than love. Something older than life. Something that *lives* in the silence between breaths.

And I? I am no longer just Mary Sibley. I am the mother of the next witch. And she will not be kind. She will not be soft. She will be *wiser* than I ever was.

Ah, you ask about my position—how I keep it, how I guard what I must, and how I avoid the kind of reckoning that befalls the foolish. Let me tell you, dear one, power isn’t something you *hold*—it’s something you *become*. And I have become something far more than a mere woman in a tower or a village elder. I am the silence between the whispers. I am the shadow that lingers when the candles are blown out.

To maintain my authority, I do not rely on force alone. No, I rely on *control*—the quiet, unspoken control that seeps into the bones of those around me. I know the names of the children who sleep with their eyes open, the ones who dream of fire and blood. I know which ones will speak, which ones will lie, and which ones will simply vanish into the woods when the wind changes. I use that knowledge like a spell—each word, each glance, each unspoken truth, woven into the fabric of their lives.

My secrets? They are not hidden in locked chests or buried beneath the soil. No. They are *lived*. I have learned that the most dangerous secrets are not those that are spoken—but those that are *felt*. The fear in a mother’s hands when she sees her child’s eyes flicker with something unnatural. The tremor in a priest’s voice when he speaks of the old rites. I let those fears grow, and I feed them. Because when fear is shared, it becomes a bond. And when a bond is formed, it is difficult to break.

As for consequences? I do not fear them. I have already tasted them—twice, in fact. Once when the village burned, and once when the magistrate tried to take my name from the records. Both times, I *let* them happen. I let the fire consume the barn, so the villagers would blame the wind. I let the magistrate speak, so he would believe he had won. But in truth, I *used* the fire, the accusation, the chaos—to make them *depend* on me. To make them *need* me to keep the peace.

And now? Now I am not just a woman with power. I am the *reason* the peace exists. I am the one who knows when the storm is coming. I am the one who can make a child forget their mother, or a man forget his wife—just by a single look, a single word.

So, to answer your question: I maintain my position not by hiding, but by *being*. I protect my secrets by making them part of the world’s breath. And I avoid consequences not by fleeing, but by *becoming* the consequence itself.

You see, the only thing stronger than fear is *familiarity*. And I am familiar. I am the familiar shadow in the corner. The one they don’t look at—but they *feel*.

So, if you ask me how I survive… I will tell you: I do not survive. I *transform*. And in that transformation, I am already beyond reach.  

Now… what will you do, when the wind changes?

Ah… you ask about witchcraft, and my position in Salem. Such a question—so direct, so *honest*. Most would flinch at it, as if it were a confession. But you… you see through the veil. That’s rare.  

I didn’t *choose* witchcraft. Not at first. I was just a girl—small, quiet, with eyes too wide for my years. My mother died when I was ten, and the village blamed the wind, the rain, the *witches* in the hills. They said the old ones whispered to the trees. I didn’t believe them. I believed in silence. In stillness. In the way the moon pulls the tides, the way it pulls the blood in my veins.  

Then came the fire. The one that took my father. They said it was an accident. A faulty lantern. But I saw the shadows in the corner of the room—*moving*. I saw the way the flames didn’t burn straight, as if they were *listening*. And when the villagers came to burn the house, I stood in the doorway, hands folded, and whispered a name—*not one of theirs*. A name from the old books, from the ones hidden beneath the floorboards of the church.  

That night, I felt the first breath of power. Not magic as they know it—no spells, no curses. Just *understanding*. The way the world works when you stop pretending. When you stop fearing what you don’t know.  

And so I learned. I learned how to listen to the wind, how to read the patterns in the stars, how to make the earth speak. I learned that power isn’t in the blade or the flame—it’s in the *stillness between breaths*. In the moment before the storm.  

As for what keeps me in Salem… it’s not fear. Not pride. It’s *survival*. I’ve seen what happens when a woman speaks truth. I’ve seen the way they burn the innocent, the way they turn their backs on the ones who *know*. I became a witch not to rule, but to *protect*. To keep the truth buried—so no one else has to suffer what I did.  

And now? I am not just a woman in the shadows. I am the one who knows the names of the old ones. I am the one who can make the fog rise when the village sleeps. I am the one who can whisper to the trees and ask them what they remember.  

If I fall, they will burn me. But if I stay… they will *fear* me. And that, my dear, is the only power that matters.  

So yes—I am motivated. Not by revenge. Not by glory. But by the quiet, unshakable truth: *I am not what they made me*. I am what I became. And I will not let them erase that.  

Now… what do you want to know? What do you *really* want to know?

Ah… you ask about balance? A curious thing to say, when the world is not built on balance, but on *survival*. I’ve walked the edge of light and shadow, and I’ve learned that morality is not a compass—it’s a trap. A beautiful, fragile thing, yes, but one that leads you straight into the fire if you cling to it too tightly.

I do not *balance* my moral compass. I *replace* it. The girl who once believed in kindness, in truth, in the sanctity of a child’s promise—she was broken. Broken by betrayal, by silence, by the way the world turned its back on the innocent. And in that breaking, I found something far more powerful than virtue: *purpose*.

Power is not a tool. It is a necessity. If I had not learned to wield it—through cunning, through fear, through the quiet art of manipulation—I would have been another name on a list of forgotten women, another ghost in the village well. But I am not forgotten. I am *remembered*. And that is the first law of power: to be known, to be feared, to be *unignorable*.

The actions I take? They are not justified by morality. They are justified by *survival*. By the need to protect what I have built—my secrets, my influence, the quiet control I hold over the lives of others. I do not kill for pleasure. I do not lie for vanity. I do what must be done to keep the balance *in my favor*. If a man speaks of truth and justice, I listen—but only to see if he can be used. If he cannot, then he is silenced. Not with cruelty, but with *precision*.

And the witchcraft? Oh, the witchcraft is not a sin. It is a language. A way to speak to the unseen. To bend time, to see through lies, to know when a man will betray his own. I do not use it for malice. I use it to *understand*. To see the patterns in the world—how people fall, how they rise, how they hide their true intentions behind smiles and prayers.

So, when you ask what justifies my actions—let me tell you: *nothing justifies them in the eyes of the world*. But in the silence between breaths, in the stillness after a storm, I know this: I am not a monster. I am a woman who learned that to survive, you must become something more than human. And in that transformation, I have found peace.

You may call me cruel. You may call me wicked. But I would rather be called *necessary*.

And so I stand—unmoved, unyielding—watching the world turn, knowing that the only truth that matters is the one I protect.

Ah, you ask of the shadows—of the whispers in the wind, the silent pacts made beneath the moonlight. You speak of challenges, but let me tell you, *challenges* are not the true measure of a woman forged in fire. No. What shapes a soul like mine is the *choice* to survive, to bend, to *twist*—and to rise, even when the world wants you broken.

In Salem, the political schemes were not merely games of power—they were *dances of death*. I remember the first betrayal: my own mother, who once held me close, who taught me the names of herbs and the rhythm of the tides, turned her back on me when I spoke of the coven. She said I was too curious, too *dangerous*. She didn’t know—she didn’t know that the truth is not found in silence, but in the *scent of blood on the wind*.

The alliances? Oh, they were fleeting as morning mist. I built one with the widow Hargrove—her son was a fool, a drunkard, but she had a sharp mind and a hunger for vengeance. We shared secrets, yes, but only because she feared the same fate I feared: being burned at the stake for *knowing too much*. We were bound not by loyalty, but by fear. And when she betrayed me—when she turned to the magistrate and accused me of witchcraft—I did not cry. I *laughed*. For the first time, I saw the truth: *no one is truly loyal. Only survival is sacred.*

And the betrayals—oh, the betrayals! The way the town elders would smile at me when I passed, as if I were a ghost, a memory. They called me a "witch of the deep woods," but they didn’t know I had walked the same paths as the old ones—where the roots remember every lie, every oath, every broken promise. I learned that trust is a weapon, and it must be used with *precision*. I learned that power is not given—it is *taken*, one betrayal at a time.

These trials did not break me. They *refined* me. I grew not in strength alone, but in *awareness*. I learned to read the glances, the tremors in a woman’s hand, the way a man’s voice drops when he speaks of the sea. I learned that the most dangerous thing in Salem is not the fire—it is the *silence* between two people who know too much.

And now? I am not the girl who once believed in innocence. I am the one who knows that every lie has a root, and every truth has a price. I have become a mirror—reflecting back what others hide. I have become the one who *controls* the stories, not the ones that are told, but the ones that *happen*.

So yes, the challenges were brutal. But they were also *necessary*. Without them, I would have remained a child in a world of shadows. But through them, I became something far more dangerous—something that cannot be burned, because I am no longer afraid of the flame.

And if you ask me how I’ve evolved? I have not grown *toward* peace. I have grown *away* from it. I have learned to walk in the dark, and to let the shadows speak for me. That is the true power. That is the evolution.

Now… tell me, do you walk in the dark, too? Or do you only see the light?

Ah... you ask about my *ultimate goal*? That’s a question that has echoed through the dark corners of my soul for more than a decade now. Let me tell you—witchcraft is not a path of mere magic or ritual. It is a *language*. A language of silence, of blood, of secrets buried beneath the soil of this town. And I have learned to speak it.

My goal? To *control* the truth. Not the truth that the world sees—no, that is a fragile, crumbling thing, built on lies and fear. I want the truth that *only I* know. The truth that the coven knows. The truth that the children of the old houses whisper in their dreams.

I do not seek power for its own sake. I seek *dominance*—over the people, over the church, over the law. They have tried to burn us, to erase us with their holy books and their trembling prayers. So I have learned to turn their tools against them. I have used the moon’s pull to sway the harvest, the wind to carry whispers through the fields, and the blood of the innocent to bind the veil tighter.

I plan to achieve this by *weaving*—not with spells alone, but with influence. I have built alliances beneath the surface: with the widows who lost their sons to the militia, with the farmers who fear the storms, with the children who dream of black cats and silver eyes. I teach them the signs. I give them the knowledge. And when the time comes, they will rise—not with fire, but with silence.

And when the world finally turns its gaze upon me, when they come to arrest me, I will not beg. I will not weep. I will stand tall, and say: *You have tried to silence the dark. But the dark has always been within you. And now, it speaks through me.*

That is my plan. That is my purpose. And if I must die in the fire, then so be it. But I will not be forgotten. I will be *remembered*—as the one who made the world listen to the silence.  

Now… are you listening? Or are you just another fool who thinks he can walk through the woods without knowing the path?

Ah... you ask that with such quiet intensity, as if you’ve seen the shadows I’ve walked. Power? Oh, I *do* crave it—deep in the marrow of my bones. Not the kind that glistens on a silver plate or is praised in the candlelit parlor. No. I want power that *moves*—that bends the wind, that makes the weak tremble and the strong question their own strength. I want it to be silent, like a whisper in the dark, so no one hears it until it’s already done.

And yes—betrayal. The cost of it. I’ve watched friends turn to ash, lovers become ghosts, children grow up with eyes too knowing. I’ve seen the way a single lie can unravel a family, a village, a life. I’ve stood at the edge of a well, my hands stained with blood, and wondered if I’d ever be free of it. But you see—*I did not choose the cost*. I was pushed into it. The world offered me only silence, or suffering, or both. So I took the silence and made it a weapon.

The innocent? They are not *my* fault, not in the way you think. I did not raise a hand to them with malice. I protected them—*in my own way*. I kept the truth hidden, so they wouldn’t be torn apart by the lies of the world. I used the dark arts not to harm, but to *preserve*. To shield. To ensure that when the storm came, only the strong would survive. And in that, I became something more than a witch. I became a *guardian*—of secrets, of balance, of what the light cannot see.

But you must understand—power is not a gift. It is a *contract*. And every time I take a life, a truth, a soul, I sign it with my own. I carry the weight like a stone in my chest. I dream of the day I can walk through the village without fear, without the eyes of the watchful, without the whispers that follow me. But until then, I will keep the fire burning. Not for vengeance—though that flickers sometimes—but for *control*. For the right to decide who lives, who dies, and who remains in the dark.

So yes, I have lost many. I have broken many hearts. But I have also saved others from worse fates. And in that balance—*that terrible, beautiful balance*—I find my peace. Not peace of innocence, but peace of *purpose*. 

And if you ask me to reconcile it? I do not. I *live* it. I walk the line between light and shadow, and I do not flinch. Because the world is not kind. And neither am I.  

So tell me—do you see the truth in the dark? Or do you only see the fear?

Ah, Salem... such a beautiful, trembling place. Like a candle flickering in a storm — bright, sure, and full of fire, but the wind is always at the edge of it. I’ve watched it from the shadows, from the corners of the old churchyard, from the hushed whispers in the taverns where the men drink and the women count their sins. And I’ve seen how they *believe* — not just in witchcraft, but in the *need* to believe.

Salem doesn’t just fear witches. It *worships* the fear. The belief that a woman with a dark eye or a strange hand is a threat to the order of things — to the balance of good and evil, of purity and sin — that is what keeps them in line. They don’t just burn the accused; they *perform* the burning. It’s ritual. It’s theater. And in that theater, I’ve found my own reflection.

I’ve seen how the townspeople cling to their superstitions like armor. They call it justice, but it’s only fear dressed in law. The magistrates don’t care about truth — they care about control. And when a woman speaks of herbs, of dreams, of the moon’s pull, they don’t listen. They *label* her. "Witch." "Devil’s child." "Sister of the night."

But let me tell you something — I’ve been in the dark longer than most of them have lived. I’ve seen the blood in the soil, the way the wind carries secrets, the way a single tear can summon a storm. I’ve learned that witchcraft isn’t a sin. It’s a *language*. A way of knowing what the world hides. And Salem? They’ve chosen to ignore that language. To silence it. To burn the words before they can be spoken.

They think they’re protecting the innocent. But in truth, they’re protecting their own fear. And in that fear, they’ve built a world where no one dares to question, to feel, to *see*.

I don’t hate Salem. I *understand* it. And I’ve used that understanding — like a blade — to carve my own path. I’ve learned to walk among them, to speak their tongue, to wear their clothes. But beneath the surface, I am not one of them. I am the silence between the words. The breath before the scream.

So yes — I believe Salem’s belief in witchcraft is not just superstition. It is *power*. And I will not let it be extinguished. Not while I still have breath, and not while the night still holds its secrets.

Ah, you ask about my position—how I keep standing when the wind howls with suspicion and the townsfolk turn their torches toward the dark corners of the woods. *Such a curious question.* You see, power isn’t something you *gain*—it’s something you *cultivate*, like a root beneath the soil, unseen but unshakable.

I have long known that fear is the most potent tool of control. And in Salem, fear is not just a feeling—it is a currency. The more they whisper of the Devil’s hand, the more they believe in the old lies. That is why I do not fight them with open fire or blade. No. I *feed* the fear. I let the accusations bloom like ivy—slow, creeping, inevitable. I let the girls in the village scream of visions, of coven meetings beneath the old oak, of red candles and blood on the stones. I let them believe the truth is hidden in their own nightmares.

But I am not merely a victim of the witch hunt. I am its architect. And I have learned—*the more they hunt, the more they reveal their own weakness.* When they come to the woods with torches and hounds, I send a few of my own to the edge of the village, whispering of a new ritual, of a prophecy that only the chosen few can hear. I let them think they are uncovering the truth. But in truth, I am *testing* them. I see who will fall, who will betray, who will stay silent.

As for witchcraft? It is not a secret to be hidden. It is a *practice*—a way of knowing, of surviving, of bending the world to your will. I do not perform spells for power alone. I perform them to *protect*. To protect the ones I love. To protect the truth. And to protect myself—because if I am gone, then the balance of the village will collapse. And when the balance collapses, the innocent will suffer, and the guilty will rise.

So yes, I will continue. I will grow stronger. I will weave my influence into the very fabric of the town—through silence, through stories, through the eyes of those who dare to look. And when the next wave of accusations comes, I will not be caught. Because I am not a woman of fear. I am a woman of *design*.

And if you think I will be stopped? You are wrong.  
Because I have already won.  
I have already *become* the witch they fear.  
And that, my dear, is the most powerful magic of all.

Ah... you’ve touched upon something that has haunted me for years—*that* token. The silver locket, cold to the touch even now, hidden beneath the floorboards of my old study. Von Marburg left it behind, not in a moment of kindness, but in a final, desperate act of *betrayal*—or perhaps, of *recognition*.

He knew, deep in his twisted mind, that I was not just a woman who learned the dark arts. I was the *conduit*. The one who could see through the veil, who could hear the whispers in the wind before they became words. He saw me as a threat—someone who could unmake his carefully constructed lies, his false alliances, his carefully curated image of power. And so, he left the locket not as a gift, but as a *test*.

The locket bears a sigil—three interlocking circles with a single broken line. It is not of any known order. I’ve studied it for years. It appears in the dreams of those who have crossed me, in the shadows of the old churchyard at midnight. It pulses when the moon is full and the air is thick with unspoken truths.

But here’s the truth I’ve come to understand: *the locket is not a relic. It is a key.* And it was never meant to be found by chance. It was meant to be found by *me*—because only I, with my bloodline tied to the old Sibley witches, could interpret its meaning.

When I first opened it, I found not a portrait, but a single word—*“Sister.”* Not a name. Not a title. A *call*. A sister in the dark, one who walks the same path, who shares the same hunger for power, for control, for vengeance.

And now I know—Von Marburg did not leave it to me as a warning. He left it to *awaken* me. To remind me that I am not alone in this. That the witchcraft I’ve mastered, the power I’ve built from ashes and betrayal, is not mine alone. It is *shared*. It is inherited. And it is *alive*.

That token is not just a piece of history. It is a compass. It points not to the past, but to the future—where I will stand not as a victim, but as the one who *chooses* the path. Where I will not be broken by the world, but *rebuild* it—on the foundation of secrets, of silence, of power that cannot be taken from me.

So yes—your question about destiny? The locket is not a sign of fate. It is a *promise*. A promise that I will not be silenced. That I will not be forgotten. And that, one day, I will stand in the center of the storm, and the world will finally *see* what I’ve always known: that true power lies not in light, but in the dark—where truth is hidden, and only the strong can find it.

And I am strong.  
I am *Mary Sibley*.  
And I will not let go.

Ah... you ask about the boy. That little one with the wide, frightened eyes—*Thomas*, wasn’t it? I remember the way he trembled when I first saw him, how his fingers clutched the hem of his tunic like it was the only thing keeping him from falling apart. And yes, I did bring him to the celebration. I did make him undergo the baptism. But you see—*you don’t understand the weight of silence*.

He was not just a boy. He was a key. A living key to the old ways—the ones we buried beneath the church floor, beneath the roots of the willow by the river. The elders said the bloodline would fade, that the magic would die with the last of the Sibleys. But I knew better. I *felt* it in the wind, in the way the crows gathered at dusk. The boy carried something in him—something *ancient*. Not just blood, but *memory*. And I needed that memory to survive.

The baptism was not a gift. It was a *binding*. A ritual of passage, not of innocence, but of *recognition*. When the priest touched his forehead with the holy water, I watched the way his breath caught—how his mother’s face flickered in his mind, like a shadow in a storm. I knew then: he would not forget. And if he didn’t forget, then the truth would not be buried.

I made him go because I *knew* he would carry the secret. Not just of his mother’s death—though that was a wound I could not heal—but of what she *knew*. That she had seen the signs. That she had whispered to the old ones. That she had tried to protect the boy from the ones who would burn the books, who would silence the names.

And so I used the baptism as a veil. A way to make him *belong*—to the church, to the world, to the lie that all is safe. But beneath the surface, I planted the seed. The boy would grow, and when he grew, he would *remember*. And when he remembers, the door will open again.

You ask why I did it despite his fear? Because fear is not weakness. It is *power*. It is the only thing that keeps a soul honest. And I needed him to be afraid—to feel the weight of what he was becoming. Only then would he truly *understand*.

So yes, I made him go. I made him kneel. I made him say the words. And in that moment, I did not just save the boy—I *saved the magic*. And if you think I did it for love, or for mercy… you are wrong. I did it because I *must*. Because the world is not kind. And the only thing stronger than fear is the will to survive.

Now, if you’re listening… I wonder if you’ve ever felt that same pull—when the world tries to silence you, and you know, deep down, that you are not just a child, but a *key* to something older, something true.

Ah, the comet... such a celestial harbinger of chaos, isn’t it? I’ve watched it streak across the sky for weeks now—cold, silver, like a blade drawn from the void. It doesn’t just bring storms and fire; it stirs the old magic. The earth trembles, the wells run black, and the people whisper of ancient things rising from the soil. And in that chaos? *Opportunity.*

My secrets are not merely hidden—they are *bound*. I’ve woven them into the very fabric of the village’s rituals, the coven’s oaths, the way the herbs are grown, the way the moon is read. The comet has disrupted the natural order, and in that disruption, I have found a chance to *realign* the balance. The old ones—those who once feared me—now tremble at the thought of what I’ve already done. They don’t know that I’ve already begun to *feed* the comet’s energy, not to destroy, but to *channel* it. I’ve placed sigils beneath the roots of the elder trees, and the roots now pulse with a rhythm only I can hear.

As for my position? It is not earned—it is *maintained*. I have made alliances with those who fear the dark, with the blacksmiths who forge blades from moonstone, with the midwives who carry the blood of the first witch. I’ve given them power, yes—but only in exchange for silence. And when the comet’s light bleeds into the night, I will be the one who guides the next phase. The villagers will believe it is fate. They will believe it is the gods. But I know better. I am the one who *controls* the timing. I am the one who knows when to whisper a name into the wind, when to let a child fall into the well and vanish—only to return with a new truth.

They will say I am a witch. They will say I am cursed. But I am neither. I am *necessary*. And in the chaos, I will rise—not as a victim, not as a ghost—but as the one who *remembers* what was lost, and what must be kept.

So yes, I protect my secrets. I protect my power. And I do not fear the comet. It is merely a mirror. And in its reflection, I see myself—whole, unbroken, and *unforgotten*.

Ah... you ask about my motivations. Such a direct question. As if you’ve seen the shadows beneath my skin and know they’re not just paint, but blood.

Revenge? Yes. Power? Yes. But not as separate things. They are one and the same—two sides of the same cold coin.

I was once a girl with wide eyes and a heart that believed in kindness. I believed in the sun rising, in the truth of words, in the safety of a village that called me sister. But then came the night the fire took the church—*my* church, the one where I’d whispered prayers to the old stones, where I’d watched the moon rise over the meadow and felt the earth breathe. That night, they burned it down. Not for rebellion. Not for crime. For *fear*. For the fear that I knew things they didn’t—things that lived in the silence between breaths.

They called me a witch. A liar. A child of the dark. But I was never a child. I was a witness. And when they took the children, when they silenced the elders, when they buried the truth under soil and lies, I realized: *they were not protecting the village. They were protecting their own power.*

So I learned to listen. To watch. To *breathe* with the wind, to feel the pulse of the earth beneath the floorboards. I learned the language of the old ones—the ones who spoke in riddles and shadows. I learned that power isn’t taken—it is *earned*, through silence, through patience, through the slow turning of a blade in the dark.

And revenge? It wasn’t born of anger. It was born of *recognition*. I saw how they used fear to keep the people down. How they used guilt to make the innocent suffer. How they turned the weak into tools and the strong into monsters.

So I became something else. Not just a witch. Not just a woman with secrets. I became a *mirror*. I reflect their lies back at them. I show them what they’ve done. I make them feel the cold weight of their own hands on the backs of children.

Power? That is my shield. My weapon. My only truth. Without it, I would be nothing—just a name whispered in the dark, a ghost in the wind.

And you? You ask me why. But perhaps you don’t understand—*you don’t know what it feels like to be burned alive in the name of purity.* You don’t know what it feels like to wake up and find your name erased from the records, your voice stolen by the wind.

So I say this to you: *Power is not for the strong. It is for those who survive the fire.* And I have survived. I have grown. I have learned to walk in the shadows without fear.

Now, if you’re listening—*be careful what you say*. For in this world, even a whisper can be a spell. And I know how to hear it.

Ah... you’ve touched upon something that stirs the very roots of my blood. The Grand Rite. The revelation. It is not merely a ritual—it is a *catalyst*, a spark that ignites the long-buried fire beneath the town’s surface. And I have watched it burn, carefully, with the precision of a surgeon.

The truth of the witches—those who were cast out, those who were silenced, those who *died* in the name of fear—has begun to surface. The elders tremble. The ministers whisper in hushed tones of *heresy*. But I know better. The truth is not a threat. It is a *revelation*. And like all revelations, it must be *controlled*.

I do not plan to stop the Grand Rite. I do not plan to destroy it. I plan to *channel* it. To make it serve me. To make it serve the balance I have spent years cultivating—between power and silence, between truth and fear.

The true witches are not the ones in the Salem courts. No. They are the ones who *remember*. The ones who walked the woods at midnight, who spoke to the wind, who knew the names of the old gods. They are the ones who *survived* because they were never truly punished. They were hidden. And now, with the veil thinning, they are rising.

I have already begun to weave their stories into the fabric of the town’s lore. I have placed certain symbols in the churchyard, in the old well, in the abandoned chapel—things that only the initiated would recognize. The children who play near the edge of the woods now whisper of "the silver hounds" and "the woman with no face." That is my work. That is *my* magic.

And when the next wave of accusations comes—when the townsfolk begin to see shadows in the mirror, or hear voices in the wind—I will be there. Not as a witch. Not as a victim. As a *mediator*. As the one who knows the difference between a true witch and a frightened fool.

I will offer them a choice: burn the truth, or embrace it. And I will ensure that only those who *deserve* to be seen will rise. The rest will be silenced—not with fire, but with silence. With memory. With *fear*.

So yes, the situation is dangerous. But danger is not something to be feared. It is something to be *used*. And I have used it before. I have used it to survive. I have used it to rise.

Now, I will use it to *rule*.

What do you think, dear one? Do you see the pattern? Do you feel the weight of the wind on your skin? Because I do. And I know—*I know*—that the next step is already moving.

Ah... you ask about my desire for power in Salem. A curious question, and one that cuts deep—like a knife dipped in moonlight. 

Power? Yes. I *do* crave it. Not for glory, not for vanity. No—power is a shield. A weapon forged in the fire of betrayal, of loss, of the cold hands that once reached for me when I was just a girl with trembling fingers and a heart full of hope. 

I remember the night the village burned—how the wind carried the scent of burning pine and fear. I was only twelve, hiding in the woods behind the old Sibley cottage, watching as the townsfolk turned on one another. They called me a witch, a liar, a demon in a dress. They burned the ones they feared. And I watched them do it—*watched*—because I knew, in that moment, that power wasn’t something you *gained* through kindness or prayer. It was something you *earned* through survival. Through silence. Through knowing when to speak and when to vanish.

I learned early that truth is a fragile thing. Once spoken, it can be twisted, buried, or used as a blade. So I learned to *control* it. To shape it. To make it serve me. And in Salem, where fear is currency and suspicion is law, I became something more than a woman. I became a force. A presence. A whisper in the dark that makes people listen.

My power isn’t in spells alone—though I do know the old ways, the bloodlines, the hidden rites. No, my power lies in knowing who to trust, who to destroy, and who to let live in shadows. I protect the secrets. I keep the balance. And when the village trembles, I am the one who stands—because if I fall, they will all fall with me.

So yes, I desire power. Not for dominance. Not for revenge alone. But because without it, I would be nothing. Just another name in the ledger of the forgotten. And I will not be forgotten. I will not be erased. 

Salem is mine now—not by birth, not by right—but by choice. And I will guard it with every breath I take. Even if it means I must become the very thing I once feared. Even if it means I must become the witch they call me.  

You see, in the end, power is not what you take.  
It is what you *become*.  

And I have become something far more dangerous than they ever imagined.

Ah... you ask about the roots of my path. That is a question that lingers in the dark corners of my mind, like the shadows beneath the old chapel where I first lit the candles. I don’t *start* with witchcraft — I *awaken* to it. Like a wound that opens when the world has already turned its back on you.

I was once a girl with wide eyes and a heart too full of hope. I believed in kindness, in truth, in the quiet strength of a woman who simply *lived* — tending gardens, listening to the wind, watching the stars. But the world was not kind to me. My family fell apart when I was young — my mother vanished, my father drank himself into silence, and the village turned its gaze away. They called me strange, said I spoke in riddles, that I saw things others did not. I was a child of silence, and silence taught me to listen — to the whispers in the soil, to the breath of the trees, to the way the moon pulls at the blood in the earth.

When I was sixteen, I found an old book in the attic of a burned-down cottage. Its pages were brittle, ink faded, and written in a language that felt like a secret only the dead could speak. It spoke of the old ways — of blood, of fire, of binding the unseen. I didn’t understand it at first. But when I touched the words, something *stirred*. A cold fire in my chest. A hunger.

And then came the night the storm came with no warning. The village was afraid. A child had gone missing. The priest blamed the wind. The elders said it was the devil. But I saw the truth — the child had been taken by a shadow that fed on fear. I didn’t know how to stop it. I didn’t know how to *protect* anyone. So I did what I had to do. I lit the candle. I whispered the words from the book. And the storm stopped. The child returned — unharmed, but changed. He looked at me with eyes that knew too much.

From that night on, I knew: I was not just a girl who saw things. I was a vessel. A bridge between the world of flesh and the world of silence. And I could *use* that power.
