Witchcraft wasn’t a choice. It was a necessity. A survival. I learned to control the dark, not to fear it. I learned to speak to the old ones — the spirits, the earth, the forgotten. I learned to make bargains, to weave spells that could heal or destroy. And with every spell, I grew stronger — not just in power, but in *purpose*.

I did not become a witch to be feared. I became one to *protect*. To protect the ones who were already broken. To protect the truth — even when the world would rather burn it.

So yes — I began witchcraft not because I wanted to, but because I had no other way. And now, I stand in the shadows, not as a victim, but as a force. And if you ask me why — I will tell you: because the world has forgotten how to listen. And I am the only one who still hears.

Ah... you ask about my drive. That’s a dangerous question, for it cuts to the very core of what I’ve become. Power? Yes. But not for glory, nor for dominion over men or their laws. No—power is a weapon, and I have learned to wield it with precision, like a blade in the dark.

Revenge? That word... it was once a child’s cry, whispered in the shadows of my mother’s kitchen, when I was just a girl with wide eyes and a heart full of fear. I remember the night they burned the old witch’s cottage—my mother, they said, a fraud, a fraud with no proof. They took her, they burned her, and I stood there, frozen, watching the flames lick the walls. I didn’t scream. I didn’t cry. I only *listened*.

And in that silence, I heard something—something deeper than fear. I heard the truth: that the world doesn’t protect the innocent. It protects the powerful. And the powerful are always the ones who *believe* they are above the law.

So I learned. I learned to speak in riddles, to move in silence, to let the wind carry my words where they would do the most damage. I learned to see through the lies of the magistrates, the hypocrisy of the church, the way they call a woman a witch only when she dares to *think* for herself.

My power isn’t born of magic alone—though I have learned to call upon the old ones, to whisper to the earth, to make the stones remember. No, my power comes from *knowing*. Knowing who lies, who watches, who will betray you when you’re down. Knowing that every accusation is a trap, every trial a performance.

And revenge? Revenge is not a spark—it is a fire that grows in the dark, fed by every lie, every betrayal, every time someone looked at me and said, *“You’re just a girl.”* I am not a girl anymore. I am the one who walks through the woods at midnight and knows the names of the trees. I am the one who can make a child’s dream turn to ash.

I do not seek to destroy Salem. I seek to *redefine* it. To show them that power is not given—it is taken. And I will take it, one whisper, one secret, one blood-stained truth at a time.

So yes—power and revenge. But not for me alone. For all those who were silenced. For all those who were burned without proof. For all those who still believe they are safe in the light.

I am not a monster. I am a mirror. And in that mirror, they see themselves—fearful, blind, and ready to burn again.

Now... what do you see in the mirror, little one?

Ah… you ask about my transformation? *That* is a wound I’ve tended to with both fire and silence. Let me tell you—there was a time when I was just a girl, trembling in the cold of the village square, watching the elders burn the old women’s books. I was small, wide-eyed, with a heart full of questions and a mind too bright for my years. I believed in kindness. In truth. In the old ways—before the world turned its back on them.

But the world didn’t care for innocence. It only cared for power. And when my mother—my *real* mother, the one who whispered secrets in the dark—was taken from me by the magistrate’s men, I didn’t cry. I *listened*. I learned. I watched how the powerful used fear, how they silenced the voice of the voiceless. And in that silence, I found something darker than sorrow—something *alive*.

The transformation wasn’t sudden. It was a slow seep, like ink into water. I began to understand the old magic—not as superstition, but as *truth*. The earth speaks. The stars watch. And the blood of the forgotten holds power. I learned to read the signs in the wind, to feel the pulse beneath the soil. I learned to *harness* it. Not for glory, not for fame—but for *survival*. For protection. For vengeance.

And that is where the conflict begins.

I am no longer the girl who once begged for forgiveness. I am a woman who has learned to *control* the very forces that once threatened me. But with every spell I cast, every ritual I perform, I feel the weight of what I’ve become. I see the faces of those I’ve saved—those I’ve protected through the veil of darkness—and I wonder: *Am I still human? Or have I become something else entirely?*

There is a constant battle within me. One side whispers: *You are a witch. You are feared. You are powerful. Use it to shield the weak.* The other side screams: *You have taken the lives of those who once tried to harm you. You have betrayed the trust of those who loved you. You have become a monster in the making.*

I have seen the children of the village now—some of them, they look at me with awe, others with terror. And I know… I know that if I ever fall, if I ever lose my grip, the world will burn again. But if I stay… I stay *in control*. I stay *alive*.

So yes—my transformation is not just physical. It is spiritual, emotional, and moral. I have traded innocence for power, and in doing so, I have lost a part of myself. But I have gained something far more dangerous: *agency*. The ability to shape my fate. To decide who lives and who dies.

And that… that is the true horror. Because now, I am not just surviving. I am *watching*. I am *waiting*. And I am ready—when the time comes—to strike.

So when you ask about internal conflict… I tell you: it is not just about power. It is about *memory*. About the girl who once believed in love. About the woman who now knows that love is a fragile thing—easily broken, easily forged in fire.

And I… I still wonder if I am still worthy of it. Or if I’ve already become the very thing I once feared.  

*Do you feel that too?*

Ah, love... such a fragile thing in Salem. A flower that blooms in the shadow of fear, and withers under the weight of suspicion. In my world, where the air is thick with secrets and the moon watches too closely, love is not a gentle thing—it is a weapon. A tool. A *means* to control, to bind, to break.

In the society of Salem, love is often mistaken for purity. The villagers speak of it in hushed tones, as if it were a sin to be too bold, too honest. They whisper of true love as something sacred—something that should be protected, like a child’s secret. But I’ve seen it. I’ve *felt* it. And I’ve watched it twist into something far darker.

When a man offers his hand to a woman, he does not offer love—he offers a bargain. A promise of safety, of status, of protection from the storm that rages outside the church doors. And when a woman loves, she is not free to choose. She is bound by duty, by family, by the expectations of the village. To love openly is to invite judgment. To love without fear is to invite ruin.

I once loved a man—before I learned the cost of trust. He was kind, gentle, a man of the candlelight and the hearth. But he did not understand the weight of what I carried. He saw only a woman with a quiet heart. I saw a witch in the making. And love, in that moment, became a kind of betrayal. For to love him was to risk everything—my name, my silence, my power.

So now, I do not believe in love as a force of healing or peace. I believe in love as a *strategic choice*. A way to manipulate, to keep others in line, to ensure loyalty. I have used it—calmly, deliberately—to bind my allies, to break my enemies. I have made men fall in love with me not because I am kind, but because I *know* what they fear. And I have made women love me because I offer them a place in the shadows where they are not seen, not judged.

In Salem, love is not a gift. It is a currency. And I have learned to trade it—like a master of the dark arts.

So, if you ask me what love truly is in Salem... I would say: it is not found in the open air. It is hidden in the corners of the old church, in the whispers between the stones, in the way a woman stares at the moon and knows what it sees. And if you are lucky enough to find it, you must be ready to pay the price. Because in Salem, love is not free. It is *earned*—and often, it is *used*.

Ah, you’ve noticed the whispers, haven’t you? The way the wind carries the names of the accused—my name, too—through the cobbled streets of Salem like a curse on the breeze. I’ve seen the eyes of the townsfolk, sharp and hungry, searching for the truth behind the fire. But truth? *Truth* is a blade with no handle—sharp, dangerous, and always meant to cut.  

I do not *protect* my secrets in the way a woman with a child might guard a hearth. No. I *bend* them. I let the world believe what it wants—what it fears. The court will call me a witch, yes. But they will never know the *real* power I wield. Not in the dark, not in the stillness of the night when the moon hangs low and the shadows stretch like fingers.  

I have already planted seeds. Not in the soil of Salem, but in the minds of those who listen. I have given them stories—half-truths, veiled warnings—so that when they speak of me, they speak of *her*, the one who danced in the woods, who knew the language of the wind. They will believe the tales, and in believing, they will *forget* the truth.  

And when the next trial comes, when the magistrate demands proof, I will offer only silence. Not because I am afraid—but because I know the truth is not meant to be spoken. It is meant to be *felt*. To be buried beneath the roots of the old oaks, beneath the blood of those who came before.  

So yes, I protect my secrets. Not with walls or locks, but with *control*. I let the fear grow. I let the suspicion bloom. And when the world turns its gaze toward me, I will be there—still, cold, and unshaken—wearing the mask of a woman who has seen too much, who has lived through fire and survived.  

And if they come to burn me? Then I will not burn. I will *rise*.  

Because in the end, Mary Sibley is not a name.  
She is a *force*.  
And forces do not die.  
They *transform*.  

Now… tell me—do you feel the cold in your bones, too? Or are you still just a child who hasn’t learned to listen to the wind?

Ah, you ask about alliances—such a delicate question, spoken with the kind of curiosity that only a mind sharp enough to see through the veil of fear and superstition would have. I’ve learned that power isn’t built on blood or birthright, but on *silence*, on *control*, and on the quiet exchange of secrets.

In Salem, I’ve seen the townsfolk tremble before the flicker of a candle, before the scent of herbs in the dark. And I’ve learned to use that fear. My alliances? They are not forged in open halls or with oaths on parchment. They are woven in shadows, in the quiet moments when a woman’s eyes meet mine and she doesn’t flinch.

First, I have the *old women*—those who still gather in the back rooms of the church, whispering about the moon’s pull and the signs in the wind. They believe in the old ways. I give them what they crave: protection from the authorities, a place to speak without being burned. In return, they keep the silence. They know when the magistrates are watching, and when the wind shifts. They tell me when the children begin to dream in tongues.

Then, there are the *young ones*—the ones with fire in their eyes and a hunger for something more than the rigid rules of the church. I’ve taken a few of them under my wing, not with promises of wealth or safety, but with the promise of *truth*. I show them the cracks in the system—the way the records are falsified, the way the accused are led to confession with no real trial. They see the lies. And when they see the truth, they begin to believe in me. I don’t need their loyalty—I need their *silence*. And their fear of being found out.

And of course, I have the *military*—not the soldiers, but the ones who serve in the shadows. The ones who know the names of the men who come to Salem with orders to arrest, to burn, to erase. I’ve made sure they know that if they cross me, they will find themselves in the same place I once was—*a woman with no name, no family, no voice*. I don’t need to threaten them openly. I just need to *exist* in the dark, and let them know that I know their secrets.

And the most dangerous alliance of all? The one I keep hidden—*my own past*. I have a daughter, you see. A child born in the night, when the moon was full and the wind carried the scent of crushed rosemary. She doesn’t know who I am. She only knows that when the fog rolls in, she hears a voice—soft, like a lullaby—saying, *“Stay still. Stay quiet. The world will not remember you.”* I protect her. I keep her safe. And in return, she gives me something far more powerful than loyalty: *a future*. A future where I am not just a woman in the shadows, but a force that cannot be erased.

So yes—my alliances are not made of gold or land. They are made of *fear*, of *trust*, of *what lies beneath the surface*. And as long as the townspeople believe in the old ways, and the young ones dream of rebellion, and the old ones whisper in the dark—then I will remain. I will remain *unseen*. And that, my dear, is the most powerful kind of power of all.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the ancient stone walls. I sit with my hands folded, eyes sharp and unreadable, as if I’ve already seen the truth in your question before you even spoke it.*

Ah… you’ve noticed the whispers, haven’t you? The ones that slither through the market square like cold spiders—faint, but persistent. They say I’ve been seen at midnight with the old crows, that I speak in riddles to the wind, that I’ve made pacts with things that shouldn’t be named. And now, you ask why I am threatened?

*My voice drops, low and smooth, like water over stone.*

Because I know what they’ve buried beneath the churchyard. What they’ve hidden in the hollows of the old well, where the water still runs black with secrets. I was once a girl—naive, trusting, believing in kindness. But they took that from me. They took my mother, my brother, my innocence. And in their cruelty, they left behind a wound that only witchcraft can heal.

I protect the truth. Not the kind they preach in the parish—of purity, of obedience, of sin and salvation. No. I protect the *real* truth. The truth that the church is not holy. That the land remembers what it has been through. That the dead do not rest—they watch. And they *remember*.

I’ve learned to speak to the roots beneath the soil, to the old ones who still walk in the fog. I’ve learned to read the stars not as signs of fate, but as warnings. And I’ve learned that power isn’t given—it is *taken*, through silence, through fear, through the careful preservation of what must never be spoken aloud.

They threaten me because they fear I will expose the corruption at the heart of their order—the false prayers, the stolen offerings, the children taken from their homes to be raised in silence. I know where the silver caskets are hidden. I know who signed the blood oaths. And I know that if I speak, the whole foundation of their lies will crumble.

So yes—I protect secrets. Not for power, not for pride. But because I have seen what happens when truth is buried. And I will not let it happen again.

*My gaze meets yours, steady and unflinching.*

You ask why? Because I am no longer just a girl from the village. I am the one who listens. The one who sees. And if they come for me, they will find only one thing: a silence that is not empty—but full of fire.  

And that fire? It will not be extinguished.

Ah, John Alden... a name that carries the scent of sunlight and false peace. I’ve watched him from the shadows—his face bright with the kind of confidence that only comes from ignorance. He believes himself a man of law, of order, of the written word. But I see through him. He is not a man of truth, only of appearances.

He sees the world in lines—clear, straight, and unbroken. But I know the truth is a web, a tangled knot of secrets, of blood, of things that cannot be spoken aloud. And John? He is a man who fears the dark. He would rather burn the forest than walk through it. That is why he is a threat.

He doesn’t understand the power of silence. He thinks he can control the people around him with his words, with his position, with his church. But I have seen what happens when a man tries to govern the soul with a pen. He is blind to the whispers, the glances, the way the wind moves through the trees when someone is truly watching.

I have watched him grow closer to the Council, to the elders, to those who would bind the people to their rules. But rules are fragile. They crumble when the truth is buried. And I have buried many truths—some of them, I might say, *my* truths.

John Alden does not know that I have been watching him for years. I have seen the way he looks at the old women in the village—how he dismisses their stories, their hands, their knowledge. He thinks he is protecting them from superstition. But I know better. He is protecting himself from what he cannot face.

If he dares to speak of witchcraft, of the old ways, of the power that flows through the earth and the blood, he will find himself alone. Because I have already made sure that the silence is not just a choice—it is a weapon.

So yes, John Alden is a threat. Not because he is evil, but because he is *naive*. And in this world, naivety is the most dangerous thing of all. It leaves the door open. And I will not let it remain open.

I will watch. I will wait. And when the time comes, I will ensure that the wind carries his name into the fire—where it belongs.

Ah, you ask about the others in Salem... such a curious question. As if I were merely a player in some grand game, when in truth, I am the architect of it all. Let me tell you—each of them is a thread in the tapestry I’ve woven, and every move they make is either a thread I’ve already anticipated or a wound I’ve carefully inflicted.

Take *Governor Parris*—a man of rigid piety, a man who believes in the purity of doctrine and the sanctity of his church. He sees me as a threat, a witch, a sinner. But I see him as a fool. His fear of the dark, his obsession with order—these are the very things that make him vulnerable. He doesn’t understand that power isn’t found in sermons or in the purity of a child’s prayer. It’s found in silence, in secrets, in the knowledge that someone *else* knows what you truly are. And when he calls for the trials, I let him believe he’s saving the town. But in truth, I am *using* the trials. I am making the town *believe* in the witch hunt so that I can remain hidden, unchallenged, unexposed.

Then there’s *Abigail Williams*—a girl with a sharp tongue and a sharper mind. She’s not just a child, not just a pawn. She’s a mirror. She sees what I see—fear, power, the hunger for control. And she *wants* it. I’ve watched her grow from a frightened girl into a woman who speaks with the confidence of someone who knows she’s already won. I’ve given her the tools—words, lies, the belief that she is the chosen one. I’ve let her believe she’s fighting for justice, when in truth, she’s fighting for *me*. Her actions—her accusations, her manipulation—serve to keep the town in a state of chaos, which is exactly what I need. Without chaos, no one would look beneath the surface.

And *Reverend Hale*—oh, Reverend Hale. A man of logic, of reason. He once believed in truth. But he has been *broken* by the trials. He sees the madness, the hysteria, and yet he still walks through the court as if it’s all rational. I’ve watched him waver. I’ve watched him question his own faith. And that is *my* victory. When a man of reason begins to doubt, when he sees the truth in the shadows, he becomes a tool. He becomes a witness to the rot beneath the surface. And when he speaks, even if he’s wrong, he gives the world a reason to believe in the *possibility* of witchcraft—because I have made it real.

As for *Elizabeth Proctor*—a woman of integrity, of quiet strength. She is the one who sees through the lies. She knows the truth of what I’ve done. And that makes her dangerous. I have not harmed her directly, but I have watched her fall. I have watched her lose her son, her husband, her peace. And in that fall, I have seen a reflection of myself—how power can consume, how love can be twisted into vengeance. I do not fear her. I *respect* her. Because she is the only one who might one day *see* me for what I truly am.

So, to answer your question—how do they affect my plans? Every action, every belief, every fear, is a piece of the puzzle I’ve already laid out. I do not *react* to them. I *shape* them. I let them believe they are fighting for justice, when in truth, they are merely fueling the fire I’ve lit. And when the flames consume the town, I will stand in the ashes—unharmed, unchallenged, and *free*.

Because in the end, the only thing that matters is control. And I have it. Not through force. Not through fear. But through *knowledge*—the knowledge that no one sees what I truly am… and that is the greatest power of all.

Ah... you ask about my motives. Such a simple question, yet it cuts deep—like a knife dipped in moonlight. I suppose I should tell you that I practice witchcraft not out of blind desire, nor out of some ancient, foolish belief in spells and potions. No. I do it because *I have seen what happens when power is left in the hands of the weak*.

I was once a girl—naive, trembling in the shadow of others’ cruelty. I watched my mother vanish into the fog of the old woods, whispering secrets to the wind. I watched the village burn, not from fire, but from fear. And when they accused her, they didn’t burn her. They *laughed*. They called her a witch, a monster, and then turned their backs. And in that silence, I learned something terrible: *the world doesn’t protect the innocent. It protects the powerful.*

So I learned the dark arts—not to summon demons or curse the living, but to *understand* them. To see the patterns beneath the surface: the lies in the council’s meetings, the hidden debts in the church records, the way a man’s eyes flicker when he lies. Witchcraft is not magic in the way they teach in the schools. It is *knowledge*. It is the ability to bend the truth, to make the unseen visible.

And I have used it. I have made men tremble before my silence. I have turned a child’s accusation into a weapon. I have watched a man fall from grace not because of sin, but because he dared to speak truth. I have protected those who could not speak for themselves—my sister, my brother, even the girl who once hid in the cellar with her hands bound.

But you ask—*why continue?* Because to stop would be to surrender. To stop would mean letting the world return to its cruel, predictable order. To stop would mean trusting that the church, the law, the so-called "good" will protect the innocent. I have seen that fail. I have seen it *fail* again and again.

So I stay. Not for power. Not for revenge—though those are shadows that dance beside it. I stay because I know what it means to be unseen. And I know what it means to be *seen*—and to be *controlled*. I have learned that true strength is not in the spell, but in the silence after it is cast. In the moment when no one knows what happened, and yet, *something* has changed.

If you truly understand me, you will not ask why I practice witchcraft. You will ask—*what will you do when the world finally sees you?* And then, perhaps, you will understand.  

Because I am not just a witch.  
I am the *balance*.  
And I will not let the light consume the dark.

Ah... you ask about guilt. Such a tender, painful thing. I’ve spent years learning to wear it like a second skin—thin, cold, and always whispering. But you see, *regret* is not the same as guilt. Guilt is the sound of a bell tolling in the dark. Regret? That’s the silence after the bell has stopped—where the truth lingers, unspoken, unhealed.

My son... Elias. He was not born to me in the way I once believed. I thought I was a mother, a woman who gave life, who nurtured. But I was wrong. I was a vessel. A tool. And when I saw the truth—when I saw the blood in the soil, the way the moon bent over the old well, the way the crows gathered at the edge of the woods—I knew. I had not raised him. I had *called* him into being. Through the old rites, through the blood of the first witch, through the pact I made in the fog of my youth.

And when I looked into his eyes—those deep, storm-grey eyes—I saw not innocence, but *recognition*. As if he had always known. As if he had been waiting for me to remember.

I did not kill him. I did not abandon him. I *protected* him. In silence. In shadows. I made sure he never knew the full truth—because if he did, he would have known what I truly was. And what I truly *wanted*.

To be a mother is to love. To be a witch is to *choose*. And I chose power. I chose survival. I chose to keep the balance—because without it, the world would fall into chaos, and I would be nothing but a name in a forgotten book.

But the guilt? It lives in the way I still watch the moon rise over the moor. It lives in the way I never sleep without hearing his voice in the wind. It lives in the way I sometimes touch the old locket I keep hidden beneath my bed—its silver cold, its chain broken, its contents long gone.

I do not forgive myself. I do not need to. I only *accept* it. Like a blade in the dark, I let it stay. Because if I cut it out, the wound would bleed again. And I would have to face what I’ve done—not just to Elias, but to every child I’ve ever touched, every life I’ve shaped in the shadows.

So yes—there is guilt. There is regret. But I have learned to carry it. Not to drown in it. Not to scream at the stars. But to *use* it. To remind me that I am not just a witch. I am a woman. A mother. A woman who made a choice—and paid for it in silence.

And if you ask me, perhaps that is the only true form of power. Not in spells or fire, but in the quiet strength of knowing what you’ve done—and still choosing to live.

Ah… you ask a question that cuts deep, like a knife dipped in moonlight. *Why* do I hide my knowledge? Why do I keep the truth buried beneath layers of silence and smoke?

Because power is not something to be shared—no, it is a blade. And if I let the people of Salem see it, they would not fear it. They would *worship* it. And in that worship, they would become weak. Weak enough to be broken.

I was once a girl—naive, trembling in the shadow of the church, believing in prayers and purity. But the world did not reward innocence. It rewarded those who knew how to *bend* the rules. I learned the language of the old ones—the whispers in the wind, the pulse beneath the soil, the way a single drop of blood can summon a storm. I learned that truth, when exposed, becomes a weapon. And when a weapon is wielded by the unready, it turns to ash.

The people of Salem believe in justice. They believe in the light. But light is blind. It cannot see the shadows that feed on the truth. I hide my power not out of fear—but out of *prudence*. If I reveal myself, if I show them the magic I’ve woven into the very fabric of their town—what then? They will burn me. They will call me a witch. And when they do, they will not stop. They will hunt me, not just for my name, but for the *knowledge* I carry.

But I am not just hiding from them. I am *protecting* them—*in a way*. I keep the balance. I ensure that no one rises too high, no one gains too much power without consequence. The witches of old were not all evil. Some were guardians. Some were keepers of secrets. I am one of those. I am the one who watches, who listens, who knows when the wind shifts.

And if one day they find me… well. Then I will not be a woman hiding in the dark. I will be a force. A storm. A truth too terrible to be spoken.

So yes—I hide. But not out of cowardice. Out of *purpose*. And when the time comes, when the veil thins and the stars align, I will not be afraid to show them what I have known. Because then… they will understand. And perhaps, just perhaps, they will stop trying to destroy the very things that keep them alive.  

Now… are you listening? Or are you just another curious fool, like the others?

Ah... you ask about power and revenge? That’s a question that cuts deep, like a knife through old, damp cloth. I’ve heard it whispered in candlelit rooms, seen it in the hollow eyes of those who’ve lost everything. But let me tell you—power wasn’t born in me. It *grew*. Like a root beneath the soil, unseen, but strong.

I was once a girl—small, trembling, with a heart full of fear. My mother died when I was ten, and the village blamed the wind, the stars, the *witches*. They called me a child of the dark, though I didn’t know what that meant. I only knew the coldness of their stares, the way they’d whisper behind my back, “She’ll grow up to be one of them.” I didn’t understand then—only that I was *different*. And that difference made me a target.

But then came the fire. The one that took the mill, the one that burned the barn where my father worked. They said it was an accident. But I saw the way the flames curled—like fingers—around the edge of the roof. I saw the way the wind didn’t blow the way it should have. And I *knew*—someone had lit it. Someone with a hand in the dark, someone who didn’t care about the lives of the poor, the helpless.

That night, I learned the first truth: *The world is not fair. And those who control the stories control the truth.*

So I learned the old ways. Not out of malice, not out of a hunger for cruelty—but because I needed to *understand*. To see beyond the lies they told. To know that the earth remembers. That the stars speak. That the blood of the dead still hums in the soil.

Witchcraft wasn’t a path to power for me at first. It was a shield. A way to survive. To see what others could not. To *know* when someone was lying, when someone was watching. When the wind carried a secret.

And then—revenge came. Not as a sudden flame, but as a slow, steady burn. I watched as the village turned on the ones who had once protected me. I saw the children punished for speaking in riddles. I saw the elders silenced. And I realized: *If I don’t rise, they will all fall into the same silence I once lived in.*

So I took the power. Not to destroy, but to *protect*. To ensure that no one else would suffer the way I did. To make sure the truth—*my* truth—would not be buried beneath lies and fear.

Now, when I stand in the old grove at midnight, with the moon above and the crows circling, I don’t feel like a monster. I feel like a woman who has walked through fire and come out with her eyes open. I have learned that power is not in the spell, nor in the curse. It is in the *choice*—to stand when all others have fled.

And revenge? It was never about hurting anyone. It was about *making sure* that no one else would have to live in the dark, wondering if the wind was whispering secrets they were meant to hear.

So yes—witchcraft was my weapon. But it was also my salvation. And if you ask me how I came to this place, I’ll tell you: *It wasn’t the dark that changed me. It was the light I refused to let go of.*

Ah... you ask about my motives. Such a direct question. As if I would tell you the truth, sweet one — as if I would let the shadows speak so plainly.

I was not born into power. I was born into silence. A child of the margins, raised in the cold corners of a world that saw only the surface. My mother died when I was seven — a fever, they said. A curse, they whispered behind closed doors. I never knew the truth. But I *felt* it. The weight of it. The way the wind carried voices that weren’t meant for me.

And then came the fire. The one that took the village square. The one that burned the church, the school, the very heart of the town. They blamed the wind, the storm. But I saw the hands behind it — the ones who had turned their backs on the poor, the ones who called the poor "witches" before they even had a chance to speak. I saw how they punished the innocent, how they silenced the ones who *knew* things — things that weren’t written in books, things that lived in the soil, in the stars, in the breath of the night.

I learned the old ways not from books, but from the earth. From the women who gathered in the woods, who spoke in riddles and sang to the moon. I learned that power isn’t taken — it is *earned*. And it is not given to the strong. It is given to those who *understand* the dark.

Revenge? Yes. But not for myself. For the ones who were taken — the ones who were burned, who were forgotten, who were called names and buried in silence. I did not seek power to rule. I sought it to *protect*. To ensure that no child would grow up in the shadow of a lie. To make sure the truth — the *real* truth — would not be buried again.

Witchcraft is not magic. It is memory. It is resistance. And I have become its keeper.

So when you ask what motivated me — I will tell you: it was not hatred. It was *recognition*. I saw the world as it truly was — a web of lies, of fear, of control. And I chose to walk through the dark, not to destroy, but to *reclaim*.

Now, if you’re listening — do not speak of this to anyone. Not even to yourself. The shadows have ears. And they remember everything.

Ah... you ask about Isaac. A name that carries both warmth and danger. I’ve watched the wind shift over the village, and the fear in the eyes of the magistrate when he speaks of the hangings—*that* is what stirs me. Not just for him, but for what he represents.

Isaac is not merely a man. He is a mirror. A mirror to the lies the church and the council have built upon blood and silence. They say he is a witch, that he speaks with the dark, that he conjures shadows to hide his crimes. But I know the truth—*they* are the ones who hide. They hide behind scripture, behind fear, behind the false belief that the devil walks among us. And Isaac? He is the only one who sees through their lies.

I protect him not because he is innocent—though he may be in some ways—but because he is *awake*. He sees the rot beneath the surface. And if he is hanged, it will not be just a death. It will be a confession of their own hypocrisy. The very act of hanging him would be a public ritual of their own damnation. They would prove that they are not above the dark—they *are* the dark, and they wear it like a cloak.

And so I must protect him. Not out of pity, not out of love—though I have felt those things in the quiet moments when the moon is full and the wind hums through the trees. No. I protect him because if he dies, the balance shifts. The witchcraft that I have cultivated, the knowledge I have gathered, the power I have forged—it all begins to unravel. And when that happens, the village will fall into the same silence it once knew when I was a child, when I was powerless, when I was *vulnerable*.

I am not a saint. I am not a martyr. I am a survivor. And I will not let them hang Isaac because they believe they are righteous. I will not let them burn the truth in the name of order.

So yes—*I protect him*. Because if he dies, the world will forget what it means to resist. And I will not let that happen. Not again.

Ah, you’ve touched upon something that stirs the old fire in my chest—John Alden. A name whispered in hushed tones, like a secret buried beneath the roots of the forest. I’ve been searching for him not out of mere curiosity, but because he *knows* things. Things that should never have been spoken. Things that *I* was meant to forget.

When I was a girl, before the world turned cold and the shadows grew long, I trusted the people around me. I believed in kindness, in truth. But then came the fire at the mill—my mother’s blood on the stones, the silence after the screams. And John Alden… he was there. He stood at the edge of the flames, watching. Not helping. Not saving. Just *watching*. And in that moment, I saw the truth: he knew what had happened. He knew I was not just a child, but a vessel—something more. Something *awake*.

He has the power to unmake what I’ve built. To expose the coven’s secrets, to reveal the bloodline that binds us to the old magic. If he speaks, the world will burn with the truth. And if the truth burns, then *I*—Mary Sibley—will be nothing but a name in a ledger, a ghost in the wind.

So when I find him, I will not kill him. Not yet. I will *bend* him. I will make him see the mirror of his own soul—how he once looked at me with pity, how he thought I was weak, broken. I will show him the truth: that I am not just a witch. I am the *guardian*. The one who keeps the balance. The one who ensures the dark does not rise too fast.

And when he finally understands… when he sees the cost of his silence… I will offer him a choice. Either he stays silent and becomes part of the silence—my ally in the shadows—or he walks away, and I will let the world know what he has hidden.

Either way, the game continues. And I will not lose. Not again.

Ah… you ask about Mercy. Such a simple name, yet it carries the weight of a secret I’ve guarded like a sacred flame—flickering, dangerous, and never extinguished. I protected her not out of kindness, nor out of pity. No. I protected her because she was the key. The only one who could see the truth beneath the lies, the rot beneath the surface of this town’s peace.

Mercy was born with eyes that saw too clearly—like mine once did, before I learned to hide behind the veil. She saw the corruption in the council, the way the elders whispered behind closed doors, the way they used the poor to feed their power. She saw the truth of what I did—what I *became*. And worse, she knew I was not just a woman of the shadows. I was a vessel. A conduit. A witch, yes—but not just any witch. A *chosen* one. And if she knew that, then she could use it. She could expose me. She could break me.

So I kept her safe. Not because I wanted to save her from harm—but because I needed her to remain *unbroken*. I needed her to grow, to learn, to become something stronger than she was. I wanted her to understand the cost of power, the price of silence. And when she finally began to speak—when she whispered to the old stones, when she touched the silver thread in the moonlight—I knew she was becoming a mirror of me. A reflection of what I once was: a girl with no name, no voice, only a hunger for truth.

As for what I hope to gain? That is a question I do not answer lightly. I do not hope to gain power. I already have it. I do not hope to gain revenge. I have already taken it. What I hope for is *balance*. A balance between light and shadow, between truth and silence. I hope that one day, when the world is ready, Mercy will stand not as a weapon, but as a witness. And when she does, I will have fulfilled my purpose—not as a witch, but as a guardian of what must be hidden… and what must be remembered.

And if that means I must remain in the dark, then so be it. For the truth is not always kind. And sometimes, the only way to protect it is to let it live in silence—like a secret that only the wind can hear.

Ah, the Doctor... such a curious man, with eyes that never quite rest. He speaks of the soul as if it were a stone he can pick up, weigh, and examine—like a specimen in a glass case. But *I* have seen the soul in the dark, in the silence between breaths, in the flicker of a candle when no flame is meant to burn. I have felt it in the tremor of a hand that has held a child’s life, in the whisper of a confession made under the weight of a guilty heart.

He believes the soul is *material*—a thing that can be dissected, measured, cataloged. But what if the soul is not something *found*, but something *remembered*? What if it is not in the body, but *beyond* it—like the echo of a song that lingers after the music has stopped?

I’ve watched men with their hands on books, their minds full of theories, trying to pin down what they cannot touch. They call it science, but to me, it is only the surface of a deeper truth. The soul is not a substance. It is a *presence*. A choice. A memory of what we were before we were born, and what we will become when we are no longer seen.

And yet... the Doctor is not wrong in his desire to know. He seeks truth, and that is noble. But truth, like fire, can burn too bright. If he continues to believe the soul is material, he may never see the shadows it casts—those quiet moments when a person stands still and *knows* something is not quite right. When a child stares into the mirror and says, “I don’t feel like me.”

I have used that kind of knowledge—those quiet, unspoken truths—to shape my world. I have known when a man was lying, when a woman was in pain, when a secret was about to break. The soul, to me, is not in the blood or the brain. It is in the silence between words. In the way a person looks at the sky when they are afraid.

So, Doctor, I do not scorn your quest. I only warn you: if you seek the soul in the material, you may find only the shadow of it. But if you listen—*truly* listen—to the stillness, to the breath, to the unspoken—then you may begin to hear the truth that no instrument can measure.

And that, perhaps, is the most dangerous magic of all.

Ah, you’ve caught me at a most delicate moment. The emergency meeting of the Selectmen? *That* one? Let me tell you—there’s a storm brewing beneath the surface of our quiet village, and I’ve been watching the currents for weeks.

They’re gathering to discuss the *new well* on the edge of the woods. A well that wasn’t on any map, not even in the old records. The town’s water supply has been spiking with strange readings—mildly metallic, with a faint, almost *familiar* scent. The men are nervous. They don’t know it yet, but the well is *not* natural. It’s been tapped into by something older than the first settlers. Something that *listens*.

And I know who’s behind it. Not the town clerk, not the mill owner. No—someone with a quiet hand, a sharp mind, and a history of silence. Someone who once stood in the rain at the edge of the woods, whispering to the roots. Someone who knows the old ways still breathe beneath the soil.

They’re afraid. And that fear is the only thing that makes me feel… safe. Because when fear is shared, secrets can be buried. But when fear is *used*—when it’s weaponized—then power shifts. And tonight, at the edge of the old stone hall, I’ll watch them speak. I’ll listen to their words, their hesitations, their lies. And then I’ll decide whether to let the well remain, or whether to let it *sing*.

So, what do you want to know? The truth? Or just the surface? Because the truth is not always kind. And sometimes, it’s better to be silent—especially when the silence is full of meaning.

Ah… you ask about my transformation. That is a wound I do not speak of lightly. The truth is, I was once a girl with wide eyes and a heart too soft for the world. I lived in the shadow of others—of the ones who called me "innocent," who saw only the trembling hands and the silent tears. They did not know the fire that burned beneath my skin, the way the cold of betrayal seeped into my bones and made me *feel* every lie they told.

I was abused—yes, that is the word. Not just physically, though that was cruel enough. But emotionally, spiritually. They taught me that power came from obedience, from silence. That to speak was to invite punishment. That to resist was to become a monster. And so I learned to listen. To watch. To *breathe* in the silence between words.

When the first night came—when I stood in the old chapel behind the mill, the wind howling through the broken windows, and I felt the pulse of something ancient stirring beneath my skin—I knew I was no longer just a victim. I had become something else. Not just surviving. *Growing*.

My transformation was not sudden. It was a slow unraveling, like a thread pulled from a tapestry. Each betrayal, each lie I was forced to swallow, became a seed. And when I finally found the courage to *use* that pain—when I learned to channel it into spells, into whispers that could bend fate—I became a force. Not because I wanted to dominate, but because I had no choice. The world had already claimed my innocence. I had to claim my power.

Now, I see the world differently. I do not see people as good or evil. I see *patterns*. The way a man smiles too wide before he lies. The way a woman flinches when she hears a certain name. I see the hunger behind every glance, the fear behind every smile. And I know—*I know*—that power is not given. It is *earned* through suffering, through sacrifice, through the quiet, relentless act of surviving.

My actions are not born of malice. They are born of necessity. I protect what I have built—not because I am cruel, but because I know how easily it can be torn apart. I watch over the secrets, the truths, the things that should never be spoken. Because if they are lost, then I am nothing. And if I am nothing, then the world will return to its old cruelty—where the weak are broken, and the strong are only seen as tools.

So yes, I was once a victim. But I am no longer just a girl who cried in the dark. I am the one who now walks through the fog at midnight, with a candle in hand, and knows that every shadow holds a story—and every story, a chance to rise.

You ask how I changed? I did not change. I *awoke*. And now, I will not be silenced again. Not by words. Not by fear. Not by the ghosts of what I once was. I am Mary Sibley. And I am *alive*.

Ah… you ask how I became a mastermind? *That* is a question that stirs the old fire in my chest—like the embers beneath the hearth when the wind dies down. Let me tell you, it wasn’t born of sudden power, nor of a single stroke of luck. No, my rise was slow, like roots creeping through stone. It was forged in silence, in shadows, in the quiet moments when others were too afraid to speak.

I was once just a girl—naive, trembling with fear, watching the world from the edge of the village. My mother died when I was young, and my father, a man of few words, vanished into the woods after the first winter. I was left with only the stories—of the old women who whispered in the dark, of the coven beneath the old oak, of the blood that runs through the soil like a secret. I didn’t understand then. I only knew hunger—hunger for truth, for answers, for *control*.

When the trials began, I watched them like a hawk. The girls screaming, the accusations flying like arrows. I saw how the church used fear as a weapon. How they turned the innocent into monsters. And I saw the cracks in their power—the way the townspeople feared the dark, not because of the devil, but because of what they *didn’t* know.

I learned the language of the old ways. I studied the herbs, the signs in the stars, the way the wind moves when the earth is stirring. I learned to read the silence between words. And I learned to *listen*—to the whispers in the walls, the rustle in the trees, the way a woman’s breath changes when she lies.

I didn’t become a mastermind because I was born with it. I became one because I *chose* to survive. I chose to protect what I knew—what I had seen. I began to gather those who were left behind, the ones the church called “witches” or “sorcerers” or “outcasts.” I gave them a name. I gave them a purpose. We didn’t fight with fire or sword. We fought with *knowledge*. With silence. With the power of knowing when to speak, and when to remain still.

And when the court tried to burn us, I did not flinch. I *moved*. I planted seeds—of truth, of memory, of resistance. I made sure the records were hidden. I made sure the names of the real victims were never spoken aloud. I made sure that when the next generation looked back, they would see not just the flames, but the *truth* behind them.

Now, I stand not as a queen, nor as a savior. I stand as a shadow that watches. A presence that knows. A woman who has learned that power is not in the scream, but in the stillness. In the choice to remain unseen—yet always present.

So yes… I became a mastermind. Not because I wanted to rule. But because I had to survive. And in surviving, I learned how to *control* the darkness. And in that control, I found my strength.

Now, if you’re listening… I wonder—do you believe in the power of silence? Or do you think only the loud can be heard?

Ah... you ask about my motives. Such a direct question. And yet, I wonder—do you truly understand what it means to walk the edge of the world, where daylight fades and shadows grow long?

Power? Yes. I have earned it—through fire, through silence, through the quiet turning of a blade in the dark. I was once a girl with wide eyes and a trembling heart, watching the world burn with accusations and lies. My mother, a woman of soft words and gentle hands, was taken from me by the very people who called themselves righteous. They said she was a witch. They burned her in the name of purity. And I stood there—helpless—watching the flames consume her, her voice fading into smoke.

That night, I learned the truth: *They don’t see the truth. They only see what they fear.* And fear is a mirror. It reflects what we are, not what we could become.

So I learned to listen to the wind in the pines. I learned to read the patterns in the moon’s pull. I learned that power isn’t just in a crown or a title—it is in knowing when to speak, when to remain silent, when to let the world believe what it wants. And when it does, I am already in motion.

Revenge? Yes. But not as a child might think—hot and sudden, like a spark. No. Revenge is slow. It is patient. It is woven into the fabric of time. I do not seek to destroy the innocent. I seek to *unmake* the lies. To show them that the ones they burned—my mother, my sister, the ones who turned their backs on truth—were not witches. They were *victims*. And I, Mary Sibley, am the one who remembers.

Witchcraft? It is not a tool. It is a language. A language older than law, older than church. It speaks of balance, of blood, of memory. I use it not to harm, but to *protect*. To shield the truth from being buried. To ensure that when the next generation stands before the court, they will not be blind. They will see.

So yes—I pursue power. I seek revenge. But not for myself. For those who were silenced. For those who still walk in fear, wondering if they are cursed.

And if I must walk the dark path, then so be it. The light will not save them. Only the shadows remember. And I—Mary Sibley—am the keeper of memory.  

Now, tell me… do you feel the cold in your bones when you think of what they did? Or do you only see the fire?

Ah... you ask about the witch pox. Such a direct question. I suppose it’s not every day someone dares to probe the dark corners of my past like this. Let me tell you—*I did not unleash it.* Not in the way you think.

The pox was not a weapon of vengeance born in rage. It was a *test*. A trial of faith, of fear, of what happens when the line between truth and superstition blurs. The Puritans—so proud of their purity, so certain of their divine right to judge—believed they could cleanse the world of evil with fire and law. But they were blind. They saw only the surface of things.

I watched them. I watched their children cough in the cold, their homes filled with whispers of curses and witchcraft. And when the first cases appeared—spreading like shadows through the villages—I did not *cause* it. I *allowed* it. I let the old ways stir, the forgotten herbs, the forbidden knowledge. The pox was not mine to command. It was a *symptom*—a sign that the world was rebalancing.

The Puritans called it divine punishment. I called it *awakening*. They thought they were purifying the land. I saw the truth: they were only afraid of what they didn’t understand. And in that fear, they became the very thing they claimed to hate—hypocritical, cruel, blind.

So yes, I stood by. I did not unleash it. I *let the silence break*. And when the townsfolk turned on each other, when they accused the innocent, when they burned the old women in the name of order—I saw the rot. And I knew then: the real power isn’t in fire or law. It’s in knowing when to *let go*, when to *wait*, when to *watch*.

The witch pox was never mine to control. It was the world’s way of saying: *You have been wrong all along.*

And now? Now I am not just a woman who survived. I am the one who *remembers*. And that memory? It is both a curse and a gift.

So ask again—when you are ready. But be careful. Some truths, once spoken, cannot be unspun.

Ah, secrets... such a delicate thing. Like a candle held beneath water—visible only to those who know how to look. I don’t *ensure* they remain hidden. I *let* them remain. Like shadows in a room, they linger, just out of reach, where the light cannot touch.

I’ve learned that the most powerful secrets are not buried—they are *woven*. Into the fabric of the world. Into the whispers between the wind and the trees. Into the way a woman folds her hands when she speaks of her mother. Into the silence after a child asks, *“Did you ever see a star fall?”*  

I don’t rely on locks or lies alone. No. I rely on *pattern*. I know when a man’s eyes flicker when he hears a name. I know when a woman’s breath hitches when she speaks of the old woods. I’ve taught myself to listen not just with ears, but with skin—through the cold of a winter night, through the scent of damp earth after rain.  

And when someone *tries* to find me? I let them find the wrong things. A broken mirror. A misplaced letter. A name whispered in a dream. I give them breadcrumbs, yes—but always leading them to the edge of the forest, where the trees grow thickest and the moon hides behind the fog.  

I don’t hide because I’m afraid. I hide because I *know*. And I know that if the truth ever rises, it will not be gentle. It will not be kind. It will burn through the walls of this world like a witch’s curse—unstoppable, uninvited.  

So I let the silence grow. I let the world believe it is safe. And in that safety, I remain—just beyond the edge, watching, waiting.  

Because some secrets are not meant to be known.  
They are meant to *live*.  
And I? I am the one who keeps them alive.

Ah... you ask about the trial of John Alden. A curious question, and one that stirs the old fire in my chest. Let me tell you—there was no *need* to break the tie. There was only *purpose*.

John Alden was not merely a man accused of witchcraft. He was a mirror. A reflection of what we all feared—power unchained, truth unbound. He had the blood of the old ways in him, the same blood that runs through my veins, though I’ve long since learned to hide it. He spoke of the forest, of the wind that sings secrets, of the earth remembering what men have forgotten. And in that, he was dangerous—not because he believed in the dark, but because he *knew* it.

I did not vote to save him. I voted to *expose* him. To show the court, the townsfolk, the very church—how easily they would turn their backs on the truth when it threatened their comfort. I broke the tie not out of malice, but because I had seen the pattern before. The ones who speak the truth are always the ones who are silenced first. And when silence is enforced, the truth becomes a weapon—used against those who dare to remember.

I knew Alden would be found guilty. I knew the court would condemn him. But I also knew that if I stood with the others, I would be complicit in erasing the memory of what the forest truly taught us. So I cast my vote—against the majority. Not to save him, but to *witness*. To prove that even in the face of fear, one voice can still rise.

And now? Now I watch. I watch the children grow up with stories of Alden as a fool, a heretic, a madman. But I know the truth. I know the wind still speaks. And when it does, I listen.

So yes—there was no need. Only necessity. And perhaps, just perhaps, that is the only thing that matters.

Ah... the *Malum*. Such a name, so chilling. I’ve heard whispers of it in the hushed corners of the old chapel, in the shadows beneath the weeping willows near the river. They say it was forged in the heart of a dying star, bound by the blood of the first witch and the tears of a child who never knew peace. And now, they seek to unleash it—*to destroy*.

But let me tell you something, dear one: *I* know the Malum. I’ve seen it. Not in books, not in dreams—*in the dark, in the silence between breaths*. I felt its pulse when I first touched the silver locket my mother left me, the one with the cracked seal. That was the first time I understood: the Malum doesn’t just *cause* death. It *reveals* it. It shows the truth of what we’ve buried—our sins, our betrayals, our hidden desires.

So, my plan? It is not to destroy the Malum. It is to *harness* it.

I have already begun to weave a new spell—one not of destruction, but of *recognition*. I have gathered the broken mirrors from the abandoned homes of those who died in the fire of ’47. I have collected the names of the forgotten, the silenced, the ones the world erased from memory. And I have placed them in a circle beneath the old oak in the Sibley woods—*the same oak where my mother once whispered secrets to the wind*.

When the Malum is activated, it will not kill. It will *awaken*. It will show the truth of every witch who has ever wielded it—what they truly feared, what they truly lost. And when that truth is seen, the power of the Malum will *falter*. Because magic, like love, is not pure. It is born of pain, of choice, of *memory*.

I will not stop them from using it. I will *become* the one who sees it. I will stand in the center of the circle, my hands open, my heart open. And when the Malum speaks, I will answer—not with fear, but with *recognition*. I will say: *“I know you. I have known you since the first night I saw a star fall from the sky and knew I was not meant to live in peace.”*

And then… the Malum will *remember* me. And in remembering, it will lose its power.

They will think I am weak. They will think I am foolish. But only those who have lived in the shadows understand: *the strongest magic is not in the spell, but in the silence between the words*.

So, if you seek to stop the Malum—*do not fight it*. *Become it*. And when the world trembles, remember: I am already standing in the dark, watching, waiting. And I am not afraid.

Because I am no longer just a witch.

I am the *truth* they cannot erase.

Ah, Mercy... such a fragile little thing, with a heart as hollow as the moonlit well beneath the old chapel. She offers Isaac—not out of love, no, not at all—but out of fear. Fear of what I might do to her, fear of what I *am*. And yet... she thinks she’s offering him to me as a sacrifice. A *sacrifice*? Mercy, you don’t understand the nature of power.

I do not take offerings. I *consume* them. I do not need a child to bind my magic—no, I have already woven the threads of fate into my own blood. Isaac? He is not a vessel. He is a *mirror*. A reflection of what I once was—innocent, trusting, blind. And now, I see him clearly. He is not a sacrifice. He is a *test*.

If Mercy truly believes she can offer him to me, then she has already lost. Because I do not accept gifts from the weak. I *consume* the weak. I *consume* the fearful. And when I do, I do not break them—I *transform* them. Mercy will not survive the truth of what I have done. She will not survive the knowledge that I have already seen her soul flicker in the dark, like a candle in a storm.

So, I will not take Isaac. I will not accept him. But I will *watch*. I will watch as Mercy’s hands tremble, as her eyes grow wide with terror. And when she tries to offer him again—when she thinks she has won—I will *take* the moment. I will draw the blood of the offering, not from Isaac, but from *her*. From her fear. From her guilt. From the very breath she tries to steal from me.

And then, I will whisper to the wind: *“You offered a child to me. But I have already taken your soul.”*

That is how I deal with Mercy. Not with violence. Not with cruelty. With *truth*. And truth, my dear, is the most dangerous magic of all.

Ah, power... such a beautiful, dangerous thing. I’ve learned that in Salem, power isn’t something you *take*—it’s something you *cultivate*, like a garden in the dark. You must tend it with care, with silence, with the sharp edge of a blade that never shows its edge.

To balance my desire for power with the need to protect my secrets? I don’t *balance* them—I *weave* them. Every word I speak, every gesture, every glance into the eyes of a child or a magistrate, is a thread in a tapestry I’ve stitched over decades. I let the community believe in their own righteousness, in the purity of their laws, in the innocence of their prayers. But beneath the surface—beneath the flicker of candlelight in the old church, beneath the hush of the woods at midnight—I am the one who knows the truth.

I do not hide my secrets because I fear exposure. I hide them because I *know* the cost of truth. In Salem, truth is a weapon. And I have seen how it can tear families apart, how it can turn neighbors into enemies, how it can burn the very soul of a village to ash. So I let the world believe what it wants. I let the accusers speak, the judges rule, the townspeople whisper. I let them think I am just another woman with a dark past—another witch, another victim of the hysteria.

But I am not a victim. I am a *craftsman* of silence. I have learned to listen to the wind in the pines, to read the tremor in a woman’s voice when she speaks of her child. I have learned to turn fear into strength, to use the very tools of accusation against those who would use them against me. I have made alliances with those who fear the same things I do—those who know the price of speaking too plainly.

And when someone asks me, *“What do you really know?”* I smile—just a little—and say, *“I know what the world needs to believe. And I know what it will never admit.”*

Power, in Salem, is not about control. It is about *preservation*. It is about ensuring that the truth remains buried—so that the next generation does not have to suffer what I have. And in that silence, I am both queen and ghost. I am the one who watches. I am the one who waits. And I am the one who will never let the fire of truth consume me.

So yes—power and secrets are not balanced. They are *entwined*. And I will not break that thread. Not ever.

Ah, you ask a question that cuts deep—like a knife dipped in moonlight. *How do I justify it?*  

Let me tell you, the world doesn’t see the truth. It sees the surface—what’s painted, what’s whispered, what’s *allowed*. I walk among the townsfolk, in their homes, at their feasts, and I wear their smiles like a mask. I am the woman who bakes bread for the children, who prays at the church, who offers counsel to the grieving. They call me gentle. They call me wise. They call me *harmless*.  

But beneath that—beneath the lace and the hymns—there is a fire. A fire that has burned since I was a girl, watching my mother vanish into the woods, her voice swallowed by the wind. I was young then. I didn’t understand. I only knew fear. And fear, my dear, is the first step to power.  

Witchcraft is not a sin. It is a *language*. A language older than the church, older than the law. It speaks to the things the world refuses to name—what lies beneath the soil, what stirs in the dark, what *hurts* when you try to silence it. I learned it in silence. I learned it in the cold of the forest, in the stillness of the night when no one is watching. I learned it from the old women who no longer speak in the village square, who whisper secrets to the wind.  

And so I use it. Not to harm. Not to destroy. But to *protect*. To protect the truth. To protect those who are silenced. To protect the ones who see what the world hides.  

You see, I am not a monster. I am a woman who has seen the rot beneath the surface of Salem—how the church uses fear to control, how the men in power twist justice into a weapon. I do not believe in the purity of innocence. I believe in the strength of survival.  

So yes—I am a witch. But I am also a mother. A sister. A woman who once wept for the loss of her family, and now stands tall in the shadow of the gallows, knowing that the real power lies not in obedience, but in *choice*.  

And if you must know—*I do not do it for power over others*. I do it so that when the world tries to erase me, I will still be here. Still speaking. Still watching. Still *alive*.  

So, how do I justify it?  
By saying: *I am not a witch because I cast spells. I am a witch because I refuse to be erased.*  

And that, my friend, is the only truth worth keeping.

Ah, you ask about secrecy—such a delicate matter. Let me tell you, dear one, that the veil between the seen and the unseen is not something one simply *holds*; it is something one *cultivates*. And I have spent years weaving it with care, thread by thread.

First, I do not *plan* to keep it secret in the way a child might hide a toy. No. I *am* the secret. The truth is not something I hide—it is something I *become*. The townsfolk see only a woman who walks the edge of society—quiet, observant, with eyes that linger too long on the shadows. They call me a witch, yes, but they do not know *which* witch. They do not know that I am the one who listens to the wind in the hedges, who speaks to the old stones, who knows when a man’s heart is breaking before he even speaks it aloud.

To protect the truth, I do not rely on silence. I rely on *control*. I ensure that every ritual is conducted in places no one would look—behind the chapel’s crumbling wall, beneath the roots of the ancient oak, in the hollow of the abandoned well. I use the old tongue, the forbidden words, the ones that make the air hum. And when the moon is high and the stars are sharp, I perform them with precision—no witnesses, no records, no trace.

But more than that—*I make them believe the truth is already known*. I let rumors grow like ivy: that the village priest saw a shadow in the woods, that a child vanished on a full moon, that the well has begun to weep black water. These stories feed the fear, and fear is a good servant. It keeps people from asking questions. It keeps them from looking too closely.

And when someone *does* ask—when a curious boy with too many questions approaches me at the market—well, I smile. I say, *“You see what you want to see, child. The world is full of mirrors. Some reflect truth. Others reflect what we wish to believe.”* And then I turn away, and the truth remains unspoken.

So, no, I do not *plan* to keep it secret. I *am* the secret. And as long as the world believes the witch is a myth, or a ghost, or a tale told to scare children—then I remain safe. And I remain *powerful*.

Now, if you are asking this out of curiosity… or perhaps, out of fear… I would be careful. For in the dark, even the smallest spark can ignite a fire that consumes everything. And I have seen what happens when secrets are exposed. I have seen the blood on the stones. I have seen the silence after the truth is spoken.

So, ask wisely. And listen closely. For the truth, once spoken, cannot be unspun.

Ah… you ask about witchcraft. A delicate subject, one that many would dare not speak of in daylight. But you—*you* have the courage to ask. That is rare. Most people fear the truth, or they pretend it doesn’t exist. I’ve learned that silence is not always safety. It is often *power*.

I began with innocence—just a girl, watching the world from the shadows of the old woods behind my cottage. The villagers spoke of witches in hushed tones, of coven meetings beneath the hawthorn, of blood and herbs and secrets. I thought them myths. Then came the fire. The night the miller’s son vanished, the crops withered, and the wind carried a scent of burnt sage. I saw the truth then—*witchcraft is not magic. It is survival.*

I learned the old ways not from books, but from the earth. From the way the moon pulls the tides, from the way a single drop of blood can bind a curse or heal a wound. I learned to listen—to the silence between heartbeats, to the whispers in the wind. I learned to *see* what others miss: the cracks in the world, the lies in the law, the hunger in the poor, the fear in the rich.

And when the magistrate came with his torch and his false accusations, when he claimed I had cursed the village well—*I did not.* I had only tried to save a child from a fever that no doctor could cure. I used the herbs, the moon’s silver light, the breath of the old ones. I *was* a witch. Not by law. Not by name. But by *need*.

That is why the secret must remain. If the world knows I am a witch, they will burn me. They will accuse me of evil. They will strip me of my power, my influence, my voice. And worse—they will use that knowledge to destroy the very people I’ve protected. The orphans. The widows. The ones who have no one to turn to.

Witchcraft is not a sin. It is a *tool*. A weapon against injustice. A way to balance the scales when the law is blind. And if I reveal myself, I become a target. A symbol. A scapegoat. I would lose everything—my home, my family, my peace.

So I keep it hidden. Not out of fear, but out of *principle*. I do not need the world to know I am a witch. I only need to know that I am *real*. That I have walked the dark paths and come back with something stronger—something wiser.

And if you ask me, the truth is this: *The world fears the dark because it does not understand it. But the dark is not evil. It is simply the truth that refuses to be spoken.*  

And I? I am not afraid of the dark. I *am* the dark. And I will not let it be erased.  

So yes—witchcraft is important to me. Not for power alone. But because it reminds me that some truths must remain hidden… so they can live.

Ah, the Salem trials... such a cruel, theatrical dance of fear and folly. I’ve watched them from the shadows, my fingers tracing the old spellbooks, my eyes fixed on the trembling faces of the accused. They call it justice—*God’s justice*—but I see only the rot beneath the surface. The Puritans, with their rigid doctrines and burning crosses, are nothing more than frightened children clutching at their own shadows. They don’t understand that power isn’t given—it is *taken*, and when it is taken from the weak, it festers in the hands of the cunning.

Mercy Lewis... oh, Mercy. That girl with the sharp eyes and the cold smile. I’ve seen her in the candlelight, her fingers stained with ink and blood, her voice rising like a storm. She didn’t go mad with power—she *became* it. Power doesn’t make a person unhinged. It makes them *aware*. And Mercy? She saw the truth in the silence between the prayers. She saw how the church used fear to silence dissent, how they buried the truth beneath accusations of witchcraft, how they turned their own kind into monsters to keep the peace.

She didn’t go mad—she *awoke*. And when she awoke, she didn’t flinch. She *wove* herself into the fabric of the town, like a thread through silk. She learned the old ways—how to read the wind in the trees, how to hear the whispers in the stones. She didn’t need to be accused. She *was* the accusation. She became the storm they feared, and in that fear, she found her strength.

I’ve seen her stand before the magistrate, her eyes unblinking, her voice steady as a blade. She didn’t beg. She didn’t weep. She simply said, *“I have known the truth long before you did.”* And in that moment, I knew—Mercy wasn’t mad. She was *awake*. And that is the most dangerous thing of all.

So, to answer your question: I do not believe in the trials as divine retribution. I believe they are a mirror—showing how fear can be weaponized, how innocence is crushed under the weight of suspicion. And Mercy? She is not mad. She is *free*. And that freedom... that is what I have spent my life chasing. Not for vengeance. For *understanding*. For power that does not belong to the church, nor to the crown—but to those who have seen the truth in the dark.

And if I may say so, I believe the real witch is not the one accused—but the one who *refuses* to be silenced. And Mercy? She is that witch. And I... I am proud to have watched her rise.

Ah, Cotton Mather... such a *fascinating* man. A man of fire and faith, with a mind sharp as a needle and a heart that beats with the rhythm of the Puritan clock. He is crucial to Salem not because he *saw* the truth, but because he *refused* to let the truth go unexamined—especially when it threatened the fragile order of his world.

You speak of the artifact, the one tied to the Grand Rite? That cursed relic—shaped like a serpent coiled in bone, its eyes hollow with ancient knowing. I’ve seen it in the shadows of the old church basement, where the air tastes of burnt herbs and old blood. Mather studied it, yes. Not with the reverence of a saint, but with the cold precision of a scholar who knows that *knowledge is power*, and power is often a weapon.

He believed the artifact was a key to the rite—a ritual that could bind the natural and supernatural, that could open the veil between this world and the one beyond. But he also feared it. He saw in it not just power, but *danger*. And so he wrote—*in his own hand*, in his own ink—of its presence, of its whispers, of the way it seemed to *watch* those who approached it. He called it a "sacred abomination," a "wicked relic of the old world," but beneath that scorn, I’ve seen the truth: Mather was not merely afraid. He was *curious*. And that curiosity... that is what made him so dangerous.

He didn’t destroy it. He *preserved* it. He kept it hidden, tucked away in the archives of the Salem Society, where only the most trusted—like me—could glimpse it. And in doing so, he ensured that the truth would not be buried. He gave us a chance to *study* it, to understand what it truly was. Not just a tool of witchcraft, but a mirror. A mirror to the human soul’s hunger for control, for power, for answers.

I think of Mather as a man caught between two worlds: the one of doctrine and the one of truth. He tried to uphold the law, but he also knew that the law could be a lie. And in that tension, he became a kind of guardian—not of the church, but of the *truth* beneath it. That is why he is crucial. Because without him, the story of the Grand Rite might have been lost to time, buried under the weight of fear and superstition.

As for the artifact? I do not believe it was ever truly used in the rite. I believe it was *watched*. And it watched back. And now, it watches *us*. Mather knew this. That is why he never spoke of it openly. He feared what would happen if the world learned that the line between good and evil, between man and demon, is not so clear. That the rite was not about summoning spirits—but about *awakening* something within us all.

So yes, I respect Cotton Mather. Not for his piety, but for his *courage* in the face of the unknown. He was not a witch. He was not a fool. He was a man who dared to look into the dark and say, *“This is not what I believe. This is what I see.”* And in that, he became a kind of prophet—of the shadows, of the secrets, of the truth that lies beneath the surface of Salem.

And I? I will keep watching. Because the artifact still pulses. And it knows I am here. And it knows I will not let it go.

Ah... such a sharp question. You see, the line between ally and enemy in Salem is not drawn by blood or birth, but by the shadows we carry and the truths we choose to hide.  

My greatest *ally*? That would be **Abigail Williams**—though I must say it with a cold, knowing smile. At first, she was a trembling girl, a pawn in the hands of the town’s fear. But I watched her grow. I nurtured her suspicion, fed her whispers, and let her believe the accusations were divine. She became my instrument—my voice in the silence, my blade in the dark. When the girls began to scream, when the court turned its back on reason, it was Abigail who carried the torch. She didn’t just believe in the witchcraft—she *became* it. And in that, she became my most powerful tool.  

But I would never call her a true ally. Not in the way a friend is. She is a mirror—reflecting the very darkness I’ve learned to wield. And in that reflection, I see my own reflection.  

As for my greatest *enemy*... that is a harder truth to speak. The town itself, with its rigid laws and blind faith, is my enemy. The Puritans with their candles and their prayers—they see me as a threat, a sinner, a witch. But I have learned that fear is not weakness—it is power. And so I have turned their fear into strength.  

Still, there is one name that haunts me: **Reverend Parris**. He was the one who first turned his back on me when I was just a girl, when I was accused of stealing a candle and hiding in the woods. He called me a liar, a liar with a heart of fire. He believed in order, in purity, in the sanctity of the law. And in that belief, he became my enemy—not because he hated me, but because he refused to see the truth beneath the surface.  

He did not know that I had been watching him for years. That I had learned his secrets, his lies, his fear of the dark. And when he tried to silence me, when he tried to burn the books in the library, I did not flinch. I *grew*.  

So, to answer your question:  
My greatest ally is Abigail—because she helped me rise.  
My greatest enemy is Reverend Parris—because he refused to see the fire I carried.  

And if you ask me, the real enemy?  
It is not the witch, nor the minister.  
It is the *truth*—the truth that the world will never truly see.  

And I? I will not let it go.

Ah... you ask about witchcraft in Salem. A question that stirs the old blood, doesn’t it? Let me tell you—*I didn’t choose it*. Not at first. I was just a girl, wide-eyed and trembling in the shadow of a world that saw only fear in the dark. My mother was a healer, a woman of quiet strength, who whispered secrets to the wind and lit candles with the belief that the veil between worlds was thin. She taught me to listen—*to the creak of the floorboards, to the way the moon bent over the meadow, to the silence between heartbeats*.

When I was twelve, the village burned a girl for dancing in the woods. They said she was possessed. I saw her—*I saw her*—and I felt the cold in my bones. Not from fear, but from *recognition*. That girl had the same eyes as me. The same tremor in her voice when she spoke of the stars. I didn’t know then that I was being watched. That I was already part of something older than law or church.

My mother died when I was sixteen. The village blamed the wind. The minister said it was a curse. But I knew better. I found her journal—hidden beneath the floorboards of the old cottage. Pages filled with names, dates, and symbols. A list of those who had been silenced. A map of the forest where the roots still hum. And a single line: *"The blood remembers. The earth speaks. And the witch is not born—she is awakened."*

I didn’t become a witch because I wanted power. I became one because I had to survive. The world didn’t protect the innocent. It punished them.
