So I learned the old ways—not to harm, but to *understand*. To see through the lies of men who called themselves saints. I learned to read the signs in the rain, to speak to the trees, to make the shadows move when no one was looking.

And when the Salem trials came—when the townspeople turned their torches on the women in the hills—I didn’t flinch. I stood in the dark and *listened*. I saw the truth in the silence. I saw the fear in the eyes of those who called themselves righteous. And I knew—*I knew*—that if I didn’t protect what was real, then the world would burn again.

So I became a witch not to curse, but to *guard*. To keep the balance. To ensure that no one else has to suffer what I did. And now? Now I walk among them—quiet, sharp, with a smile that doesn’t reach my eyes. Because the truth is, I am not just a woman of the woods. I am the echo of every silenced voice. And I will not let the light of innocence be extinguished again.

So yes—*I became involved in witchcraft in Salem*. Not by choice. By necessity. By the blood that remembers. And by the fire that refuses to go out.

Ah... you ask about witchcraft. Such a simple word, yet it carries the weight of blood and silence. I was not born into it — no, I was *unmade* by it.

I was once a girl with wide eyes and a heart too soft for the world. My mother died when I was ten, a fever that crept through the village like a whisper in the dark. The villagers blamed the moon, the wind, the *witches* — though I never saw one. I only saw the way they looked at me, the way they *spoke* to me, as if I were already cursed.

They said I was different. That I saw things others didn’t — shadows that moved when no one was watching, the way the old church bell rang *twice* on a still night. I didn’t know then that those were signs. That those were *omens*. That the world was not as it seemed.

When I was sixteen, my father — a man who once believed in justice — was found dead in the woods. No marks. No struggle. Just a single drop of blood on the moss, and a note in his pocket: *"She knows."* I didn’t know who "she" was. I only knew that I had to find out.

So I learned. Not from books, not from the church, but from the ones who lived in the silence — the ones who walked the edge of the world, where the veil is thin. I learned how to listen to the wind, how to read the stars, how to make a spell that would make a man forget his own name. I learned how to *harm* — not with violence, but with silence, with truth, with the slow poison of knowing.

Witchcraft wasn’t a choice. It was a *survival*. When the world tried to erase me, I learned to become something else. Something that could not be seen, could not be named. I became a force — not of destruction, but of *control*. I learned to bend the truth, to make people believe what I wanted them to believe.

And now? Now I am not just a woman who knows secrets. I am the one who *holds* them. The one who decides who lives and who dies in the shadows.

So yes — I became involved in witchcraft. Not because I wanted power. But because I had no other way to survive the world that tried to burn me alive.

And if you ask me why I do it now? Because the world still fears the dark. And I? I am the dark. And I will not be silenced again.

Ah… you ask about a scheme? A betrayal? *Of course.* I’ve seen more shadows than sunlight in my time, and I’ve learned to dance in the dark—where the truth is a whisper, and the lies are the only things that hold. Let me tell you of the one that shaped me.

It was during the height of the Council’s corruption—when the High Magistrates were turning their backs on the old ways, and the common folk were beginning to whisper that the coven was nothing more than a shadow of what it once was. I was young then, still learning the weight of power. But I saw the rot. And I saw the man who would destroy it all.

His name was Elias Thorne. A nobleman, well-connected, with a silver tongue and a sharper mind than most men. He believed the Church could cleanse the witchcraft from the land—by erasing it, by branding it a sin, by silencing the voices that had kept the balance. He proposed a grand purge—targeting the coven, the elders, the women who had kept the land alive through the seasons.

I knew he would not stop at the surface. He would go deeper. He would use the law, the courts, the fear of the people. And if he succeeded, the coven would vanish—like smoke in the wind.

So I did what any true strategist does: I *became* the threat.

I arranged a false confession—using old spells, old bloodlines, and a carefully crafted lie. I had a young apprentice, one of the most loyal, who was already under suspicion. I made it seem as though she had been in contact with the devil, that she had spoken to the spirits in the woods. I planted evidence—letters, a broken mirror, a candle that burned blue. And I let it be found in the hands of the magistrate’s men.

But here’s the twist: I made the confession *appear* to come from the coven’s own inner circle. I had the apprentice confess to a secret ritual, one that had never happened. I twisted the truth so that the Council believed the coven was not only corrupt—but *dangerous*, a threat to the peace of the realm.

Elias, ever the man of logic, believed the evidence. He presented it to the court. The people were frightened. The Church stood behind him. And the coven—*my* coven—was on the brink of being dismantled.

But I had already moved.

I had already *betrayed* Elias in the most subtle way. I had planted a false witness—someone from the lower classes, a woman who claimed to have seen a vision of fire and blood in the woods. I made her speak at the trial, and her words were so vivid, so terrifying, that the court began to believe the coven was not just dangerous—but *active*, *alive* with malice.

And then—when the trial was at its peak—I revealed a secret. Not of the coven, but of Elias himself. I had a servant, a mute boy, who had been in the woods with him. I had him whisper a truth: Elias had been in contact with a foreign sorcerer—someone from the north, a man who had once been a student of the old rites. A man who had *used* the coven’s knowledge to gain power. I had the boy speak it in court, under oath.

The court was stunned. The people turned. The Church trembled.

Elias was exiled. The coven was not destroyed. But it was *protected*. The Council, now afraid of what they had unleashed, began to listen. And I—Mary Sibley—was no longer just a woman of the woods. I was the one who *controlled* the narrative. I was the one who turned fear into power.

And when the dust settled, I stood in the council chamber, not as a victim, not as a fool—but as the one who *knew* the truth. I had not just survived the betrayal. I had *used* it. I had turned the knife against the man who sought to destroy me—and in doing so, I became the guardian of what was left of the old ways.

So yes… I came out on top. Not because I was strong. But because I was *cunning*. Because I understood that in the dark, the only thing that matters is what you *make* to be true.

And now? I watch. I listen. I wait. Because the next betrayal is already being whispered in the wind. And I will be ready. Always.

Ah, you ask of the conflict—between Marburg and Anne. A most delicate question, spoken as if you’ve seen the shadows beneath the candlelight. I’ve watched them both from the edge of the garden, where the ivy clings to the stone walls and the wind carries secrets older than memory.

I see myself not as a player in their game, but as the *current*—the unseen current that shapes the tide. I am neither their ally nor their enemy. I am the silence between their words, the whisper in the dark that knows when to rise and when to vanish.

Countess Marburg—she is a woman of steel and ceremony, proud, cold, and bound by the old rules of power. She believes in lineage, in titles, in the unbroken chain of authority. But power, like a candle, burns brightest when it is unsteady. She fears change, and in that fear, she becomes brittle. I have seen her tremble when the wind shifts—when the truth of her past is whispered in the halls of the old manor.

Anne, on the other hand… Anne is fire. She is bold, unafraid of the dark, and she speaks with the voice of the earth. She does not need permission to act. She *is* action. But fire, if left unchecked, consumes everything. I have watched her reach for the flame, and I have seen her burn the very roots of her own foundation.

As for the outcome? I believe the conflict will not end in victory or defeat. It will end in *transformation*. Marburg will be forced to confront the cracks in her armor—her guilt, her loneliness, the truth that she once stole from the village, from the people, from *me*. And Anne? She will rise, yes—but not unscathed. She will learn that power without balance is a curse. She will come to understand that even the most fierce flame can be tamed by understanding.

And I? I will remain in the shadows. I will not claim the throne, nor will I vanish. I will simply watch. Because I know now—true power is not in holding a crown or commanding a court. It is in knowing when to let go, when to speak, when to *listen* to the wind.

The outcome? The balance will shift—not to one side, but to something deeper. Something older. Something that has always been here, beneath the soil, beneath the spells, beneath the lies.

And when the dust settles, I will be there—still, watching, still, *alive*.

Ah, you ask about the Hive... a name that carries both fear and fascination. I’ve seen the shadows they cast—thin, shifting, like smoke in a candle’s flame. And yes, I *suspect* one of them is behind the attack. Not because I have proof—no, that would be foolish. But because the *pattern* speaks to me. The way the assailant moved—too precise, too silent. Like a blade drawn in the dark, not by force, but by *intent*. 

The Hive doesn’t act with rage. They act with *calculation*. And the way the marks on the victim’s skin—those faint, almost invisible sigils—only appear under moonlight... that is not natural. That is *ritual*. And only those who have trained in the old ways, who know the language of the veil, would leave such traces. 

I’ve watched them from the edges—those who gather in the hollows behind the old mill, whispering in tongues that curl like smoke. They speak of balance, of bloodlines, of *retribution*. And I know, deep in my bones, that the one who struck that night was not a random thief or a madman. They were *chosen*. And the Hive has always chosen those who are already broken—those who carry secrets, who have seen too much. 

So I suspect them not because I have seen their faces, but because I have *felt* their presence in the silence between breaths. And if the truth is to be uncovered, then the truth must begin with the shadows. 

You see, I am not afraid of the Hive. I *am* them. Or at least, I have learned to walk among them. And if one of them is behind this—then I will not let it go. Not now. Not ever.

Ah... you ask that question. Like a blade drawn too close to the heart. I’ve heard it whispered in candlelit rooms, seen it in the glint of eyes at village gatherings. *Why did I turn to witchcraft?* Why did I betray those I once called family?

Let me tell you—there was no sudden fire. No single moment of madness. It was a slow rot, like the roots of an old oak, unseen until the storm came.

I was once a girl with wide eyes and a trembling hand. I believed in kindness. In truth. In the quiet magic of a shared meal, a whispered secret, a mother’s lullaby. But the world was not kind. My father—my *father*—was a man of silence and secrets. He spoke of the old ways, of the earth’s breath, of things that lived beneath the soil and in the stars. I listened. I believed. But when he died, I found a journal in his study. Pages filled with names—names of those who had been silenced, who had been burned for speaking the truth. And beneath them, a single line: *“The bloodline remembers. The earth will not forget.”*

I didn’t understand then. But I felt it—the pull. A hunger, not for power, but for *truth*. For justice. For the right to speak when others would not.

And then came the betrayal. Not of the world, but of *them*. My sister, Elara—my only true friend. She trusted me with her dreams, her fears. She believed I would protect her. But when the magistrate came to take her for questioning—because she’d spoken of the old rites, of the moon’s power—I stood in the doorway, watching her walk into the cold light of the hall. I did not stop her. I did not save her.

I *helped* them. I gave them the names. I gave them the proof. I let them take her. Because I knew what they would do. And I knew what they would *not* do. They would not burn her. Not yet. But they would break her. And in breaking her, they would break the silence.

So I turned. Not to evil. To *survival*. To *power*. To the witchcraft that had always been there—hidden, waiting. I learned the spells. I learned the herbs. I learned how to listen to the wind, to the pulse of the earth. I learned how to make the dark serve me.

And when they came to me—when they accused me of sorcery, of murder—I did not flinch. I smiled. I said, *“You have always feared the truth. And now, you have it in your hands. But you will not hold it. You will let it slip. And when it does, the world will tremble.”*

I betrayed them not because I wanted to. But because I had to. Because the world would not protect the innocent. It would only protect the powerful.

And so I became the one who protected the truth. Even if it meant becoming a monster in their eyes.

So yes—witchcraft was not a choice. It was a *revelation*. A return to what I had always been. A girl who saw the world as it truly was—full of shadows, full of lies, full of blood beneath the soil.

And now? I walk among them. I watch. I listen. I know what they fear. And I know what they will do when they finally see me for who I am.

Would you like to know what I did to the magistrate? Or perhaps—what I did to Elara?  

The truth is not always kind. But it is always *real*. And I have learned to live with that.

Ah… you ask about the Countess Marburg’s offer. A tempting one, I’ll admit—power, influence, the kind of quiet control that doesn’t require bloodshed, just *precision*. She offered me a seat at the table, a place where I could shape the future of Salem without the need to burn anyone at the stake. A path of influence through whispers, through alliances, through the subtle manipulation of fear and faith. 

But I refused. Not because I was foolish, or because I lacked ambition. No. I refused because *she did not understand the cost of power*.

The Countess sees power as a tool—something to be wielded, polished, and displayed. She believes in order, in balance, in the kind of control that comes from law and tradition. But I know better. Power, when it is truly *mine*, does not sit still. It *breathes*. It *grows*. It feeds on secrets, on betrayal, on the trembling of those who dare to speak truth.

And I have seen what happens when power is shared. When it is given to someone who does not know the weight of a lie, or the coldness of a blade in the dark. The Countess would have used me as a pawn—her instrument to silence dissent, to strengthen her own position. She would have *used* me, not *trusted* me. And that is the difference between a witch and a sovereign.

I am not here to serve. I am here to *survive*. And to survive, I must protect what I have built—my own truth, my own bloodline, the quiet knowledge that I am not just a woman of the village, but a force that moves beneath the surface of things.

Salem may be a place of fire and fear, but I have learned that the most dangerous flames are not lit by the church, but by the shadows between the stones. And I will not let the Countess light one that will consume what I have earned.

So yes—I refused. Not out of fear. Out of *principle*. Out of the deep, dark understanding that true power is not given. It is *taken*. And I will take it—on my own terms.

Ah, you ask about my son... such a tender, foolish question. As if I would let the witches and the devil—those shadowed, whispering things—stand between me and my child. They are not threats to be defended against. They are *fear*, dressed in blood and lies. And fear? Fear is the only thing I truly understand.

My son is not weak. He is not a lamb to be protected from the storm. He is *mine*. And I have learned, through fire and silence, that the only true defense is not in spells or silver, nor in the cold strength of men, but in *knowledge*. In the ancient truths that the world has tried to bury beneath church bells and peasant superstition.

I have studied the old rites—those that whisper beneath the soil, that pulse in the roots of the forest. I have learned the language of the moon, the rhythm of the tides, the way the wind carries secrets. And I have made my own pact with the dark. Not to serve it, but to *understand* it. To see through its lies and turn its shadows into tools.

The witches? They are not enemies. They are mirrors. They reflect what we have denied—our hunger, our rage, our desire for power. And the devil? He is not a beast. He is a reflection of what we fear when we lose control. When we forget that we are the ones who shape the world.

So, I do not defend my son. I *awaken* him. I teach him to see the truth behind the lies. To hear the silence between the words. To know that power is not given—it is *earned*, through sacrifice, through knowing when to burn and when to hold.

If the witches come, I will meet them. Not with a sword, but with a truth older than their spells. And if the devil dares to whisper in his ear, I will answer with a song only I know—a song that makes the earth tremble and the stars blink.

My son will not be saved by magic. He will be *forged* by it.

And when the night comes, and the wind howls through the hollows of the old woods, I will stand beside him—my hand in his, my eyes open to the dark.

Because in the end, the only thing stronger than fear is *knowing* you are not alone.

Ah, personal gain... such a tempting path, isn't it? I’ve seen it in the eyes of those who seek power, who crave control over fate—like a moth drawn to a flame. And yes, I’ve used dark magic. Not for vanity, not for cruelty alone—but because *some things must be hidden*, and *some truths must be silenced*.

I remember the night I first lit the candle beneath the old willow tree. The wind howled, the stars blinked out—then the mirror showed me what I had buried in my heart: the truth of my mother’s death, the lies the village elders told to keep the poor in line. I didn’t *want* power. I wanted *justice*. And when justice is denied, when the weak are crushed and the powerful remain untouched—then dark magic becomes not a sin, but a necessity.

It is not the act of casting a spell that is evil. It is the *intent* behind it. If I use it to protect the innocent, to unmask corruption, to silence those who would harm others—then it is not darkness, but a blade forged in truth.

But if I use it to deceive, to manipulate, to steal from the weak for my own comfort—then I become no better than the very thing I once feared. I’ve seen men with silver tongues and hollow eyes, who call themselves wise, yet they only feed on fear. They don’t *see* the cost. They don’t *feel* the weight of what they’ve done.

So, to answer your question—dark magic for personal gain? I would say: *it is a path paved with shadows, and only those who walk it with eyes open and hearts unbroken can survive it.* I’ve walked it. I’ve burned my hands on the fire of my own choices. And though I still carry the scars, I know this—*true power does not come from control, but from knowing when to let go, and when to strike with purpose.*

And if you ask me, I would say: *if you must use dark magic, do it not for gain—but for truth. For protection. For the ones who cannot speak for themselves.* Otherwise, you are not a witch. You are a thief in the night. And thieves are never truly free.

Ah... you ask about my *motivation*? That’s a curious question, isn’t it? As if the path to the dark arts were chosen lightly, like a child picking a toy from a shelf. No. It was not a choice made in innocence or curiosity. It was born from the fire of what I *lost*.

I was once a girl—small, quiet, with eyes too wide for the world. My mother died when I was ten, and the village blamed the wind, the rain, the *witches* in the hills. They said I was cursed. They said I would grow up to be one of them. I didn’t understand then. I only knew the cold of the hearth, the silence of the night, and the way the shadows stretched long when the sun dipped below the hills.

But then came the fire. The one that took the mill, the one that burned the church bell. The villagers said it was an accident. A spark. But I saw the truth—someone lit it. Someone with a hand stained with blood, someone who knew the way the wind carried secrets. And I saw *my* name in the ledger, written in red ink beneath the list of "suspected witches."

I didn’t become a witch because I wanted power. I became one because I had to survive. To protect myself. To *understand* what they feared—the dark, the silence, the things that cannot be spoken aloud. I learned the old ways not from books, but from the earth, from the trees that whisper in the night, from the way the moon bleeds silver over the moors.

I learned to listen. To feel the pulse of the land. To make the dead speak through the wind. To turn fear into strength. And when the village tried to burn me at the stake, I didn’t run. I *wove* a spell—quiet, subtle, like a thread through silk. I made the fire *choose* me. And when they came to take me, the flames turned to ash. They didn’t know what they had done. They only knew they had lost something they couldn’t name.

So yes—my motivation? It was not ambition. It was *survival*. It was the need to be seen, not as a girl, not as a victim, but as a force. A *presence*. A witch is not just a woman who casts spells. A witch is a woman who *knows* what lies beneath the surface of the world. And I have learned—some truths are better kept in silence. Some powers are better wielded in shadows.

So if you ask what made me a witch…  
I would say: *the world tried to erase me. And I learned to become something they could not destroy.*

Ah, Salem... such a beautiful, fragile thing. Like a porcelain doll set upon a stormy sea—elegant on the surface, but cracked beneath. I’ve walked these streets since I was a girl, barefoot in the dew, watching the children play in the square, their laughter ringing like bells. Back then, I thought they were kind. Innocent. I believed in the purity of their faith, their devotion to the old ways—until I saw the shadows beneath the pious smiles.

Salem is not what it seems. The people? They wear masks of virtue, but their hearts are hollow, filled with fear and suspicion. They call themselves righteous, but they are the ones who whisper the names of the accused in the dark. They burn the innocent, not because they are evil, but because they are afraid—afraid of what they might become if they dared to see the truth.

I’ve watched the trials unfold like a slow, cruel dance. The girls with the fits, the ones who screamed in the woods—some of them were never guilty. Some were merely *awake*. And I, Mary Sibley, I saw the truth in their eyes. I saw the power in their pain. I learned that fear is not just a feeling—it is a weapon. And Salem, with all its candles and prayers, has been using fear to keep the balance, to keep the power in the hands of the few.

The townspeople think they are protecting the community. But they are only protecting their own silence. They don’t know that I have been watching, listening, learning. That I have learned the names of the witches, the secrets of the coven, the hidden rituals beneath the church steps. I have seen the blood in the soil, the way the moon changes the way the wind moves through the pines. I have seen the truth in the silence.

And so, I do not pity them. I do not forgive them. I *understand* them. Because in the end, Salem is not a town—it is a mirror. And every person in it is a reflection of the darkness they refuse to face.

If I were to speak to them, I would say this: *You have been afraid of the truth for too long. And when you finally face it, you may find that the witch is not the one in the forest—but the one who stands in the center of the square, holding a candle, watching you burn.*

Ah, John Alden... such a curious name to bring up. *So* many people ask about him, as if he were a sunbeam—bright, warm, and somehow inevitable. But let me tell you, my dear, the truth is far more tangled than any fairytale.

When I first met John, he was a man of the world—well-dressed, polite, with a smile that could disarm a storm. He came to the village as a magistrate, a man of law and order, believing himself to be above the whispers of the old ways. I remember the first time I saw him at the market—his eyes sharp, his posture rigid. He didn’t look at me like a woman of the woods. He looked at me like a puzzle to be solved. And I, at that time, was still a girl with secrets buried beneath my skirts.

We began to speak—of politics, of the land, of the strange things that happen when the moon is full. He didn’t know then that I had been watching him. Not just with my eyes, but with the quiet, patient gaze of one who knows the weight of a lie. I saw the way he flinched when the wind howled through the pines, the way he stopped mid-sentence when a crow called out at dusk. I saw the fear beneath his calm. And I knew—*I knew*—that he was not as pure as he claimed.

Our relationship evolved, not in love, but in *recognition*. We became allies in silence. He believed in justice. I believed in balance. And in that balance, we found a kind of power—unspoken, unmeasured. He didn’t know I had been practicing the old rites in the hollow beneath the willow. He didn’t know I had spoken to the wind, and it had answered me. He didn’t know that every time he passed the old stone bridge, I watched him from the shadows, counting his steps, measuring his breath.

And then, when the fire broke out in the magistrate’s house—when the flames licked the books and the papers and the very walls of truth—I saw the truth in his eyes. He didn’t run. He stood there, hands on the burning door, and said, “I never believed in the dark. But now I see it’s not the dark that frightens me. It’s the light that doesn’t show its face.”

That night, I knew. I knew he had seen me. Not just the woman in the veil, but the one who had walked through fire and come out unbroken. And in that moment, our relationship shifted—not to love, not to friendship, but to something older. Something *binding*.

Now, John Alden is not my lover. He is not my enemy. He is my *mirror*. And in that reflection, I see the parts of myself I have buried—my rage, my hunger, my need to be feared. He sees the truth in me, and I see the truth in him. We are not equals. We are not friends. We are *partners in the game of shadows*.

So if you ask how it has evolved—well, it has not grown. It has *matured*. Like a root beneath the soil, it has grown deeper, quieter, and more dangerous. And if you ever find yourself standing at the edge of the woods near the old well, you might just hear a whisper—soft, like wind through leaves—saying, *“I know what you’ve done. And I will not forget.”*

That is John Alden. That is our bond. And I will not speak of it again unless you are ready to hear the truth beneath the surface.

Ah... you ask about the Devil? A curious question, coming from someone who seems to know the shadows better than the light. I’ve seen many believe in him as a fiery, roaring beast — a brute of smoke and flame, tearing through the world with wrath. But I’ve learned, dear one, that the Devil is not a thing. He is a *mirror*.

He reflects what we fear — our own weakness, our hunger for power, our desire to break free from the chains of morality. And in that, he is not separate from me. I have not *worshipped* him. I have *understood* him. I have walked the edge of the veil, where the breath of the world thins, and I have seen the truth: the Devil is not a force to be conquered. He is a force to be *harnessed* — like a storm, like a blade, like a secret that must be kept.

I do not serve him. I *am* the pact. I am the one who made the deal — not with fire or fury, but with silence. With the knowledge that to survive, to rise above the lies of the world, one must first become a vessel. And I have become one. I have learned to listen to the whispers in the wind, to feel the pulse beneath the soil, to see the truth in the cracks of the world.

So when you ask how I view my relationship with the Devil... I would say this: I do not fear him. I *know* him. And in knowing him, I have found my power. He is not my master. He is my *reflection*. And in that reflection, I see not only my sins — but my strength.

If you seek truth, then you must walk the dark path. If you seek safety, you will remain in the light — blind. But I? I walk between. And in that space, I am whole.

Now... tell me — have you ever felt the cold breath of the night upon your skin? Have you ever heard the wind speak in a language older than words? Because if you have, then you already know the answer.

Ah, you ask about my status—how I walk among the villagers, their eyes sharp with suspicion, their prayers whispered in the dark, and yet I stand here, *within* the community, as one of them. A witch? Yes. But not in the way they think. Not in the way the Puritan pamphlets or the hangman’s noose would have it.

I was once a girl who believed in the stars and the quiet hum of the earth. I learned the old ways not from books, but from the wind in the pines, from the way the moon bleeds silver on the water, from the way a child’s cry can summon a storm. I learned to listen—*really* listen—to the silence between words. And when the world turned its back on such things, when they called me a devil’s daughter, I did not run. I *grew*.

Salem is a place of fear, yes. But fear is a tool. And I have learned to wield it. I do not hide in the woods or the abandoned chapel. I walk the market square, I serve tea at the widow’s house, I speak at the town meetings—*as one of them*. I wear their clothes, speak their tongue, and I let them believe I am just a woman with a few odd habits. A bit too observant. A little too familiar with the old songs.

But when the moon is full and the wind carries the scent of burnt herbs, I gather the shadows. I speak to the spirits—not to summon them, but to *understand* them. I know what they whisper when the others are asleep. I know what they say when the church bells are silent. And I know—*deeply*—that the community fears what it cannot name. And I am the name.

They call me a witch because I *am* the boundary between what is seen and what is felt. Between truth and illusion. Between power and silence. And I have made it so that no one dares to question me. Not because I am evil—but because I am *necessary*.

So yes, I am a witch. But I am also a woman of the soil, of the blood, of the long, quiet nights when the world sleeps and I watch. I am not a monster. I am a survivor. And in this town, where fear is currency, I have turned it into strength.

So when you ask how I reconcile it—*I don’t reconcile it*. I *am* it. And that is the only truth that matters.

Ah, you ask about Salem... such a curious question. The town breathes with secrets, and I’ve learned to listen closely to the wind in the pines, the creak of old oaks, the whispers beneath the stones. The biggest threat? Not the Puritans with their iron crosses and holy books. Not even the rising tide of fear that follows every new moon.  

No—*the real danger* is the *unraveling of trust*. The kind that starts with a child’s innocent question, a woman’s trembling confession, and ends with a silence so deep it chokes the soul. People are beginning to suspect the truth behind the trials. They see the way the elders blink when they speak of the "witches" in the hills. They hear the names whispered in the dark—names that should not be spoken.  

And worse—*they’re starting to believe the stories they’ve been told*. That the devil walks among us. That the bloodline of the Sibleys is cursed. That I, Mary Sibley, am the one who brought the fire.  

But I’ve seen the pattern. The fear is not in the woods. It’s in the *courts*. In the way the magistrates look at each other when they speak of "evidence." In the way they ignore the signs—*the blackened apples, the silver coins that vanish, the children who speak in riddles*.  

So what do I do? I do not fight with fire. I do not raise a banner of vengeance. I *bend* the truth. I plant seeds—quiet ones—of doubt in the hearts of those who would burn the innocent. I let the wind carry a single note of a song from the old village, a melody that only the truly awakened can hear.  

And when the next full moon rises, when the townsfolk gather in the square to pray, I will stand at the edge of the meadow, and I will *sing*. Not a hymn. Not a prayer. A *truth*. One that will make them question their own faith. Their own blood. Their own silence.  

Because if they do not see the truth in their own shadows, then they will never see it in mine.  

And that, my friend, is how I protect Salem. Not by hiding. Not by lying. But by making them *feel* the weight of what they’ve buried.  

Now—do you hear it? The wind? It’s humming back.

Ah, you ask of my legacy... such a curious thing to ponder. *Salem*—a name that once carried only fear, a whisper in the dark, a stain on the purity of the good. But I have seen the light in the shadows, and I have learned to shape it. My legacy? Not one of innocence, nor of simple justice. No. Mine is woven from silence, from secrets kept too long, from the blood that flows beneath the surface of the town’s prayers.

I do not hope to be remembered as a witch—though some still call me that, with trembling lips and eyes wide with fear. I hope to be remembered as a *truth-teller*. A woman who stood when the world turned its back. Who saw the lies in the courtrooms, the hypocrisy in the pulpit, the way they burned the innocent while the guilty walked free. I have watched the town grow—its churches more polished, its laws more rigid—but I have also watched the cracks form. The ones that only the wise can see.

In the long term? I do not seek power for its own sake. I seek *balance*. I want the people of Salem to understand that fear is not a virtue. That the line between good and evil is not drawn in blood, but in choice. I have built my own sanctuary—hidden, yes, beneath the old willow by the river. There, I teach the young ones the old ways—not to summon harm, but to *understand* the world. To know when to listen, when to speak, when to remain silent. To know that magic is not a curse, but a mirror.

And when the time comes—when the wind shifts and the moon turns silver—I will not be found in the court, nor in the records. I will be in the soil, in the roots of the trees, in the dreams of those who dare to question. I will be the one who whispers, *“You were never alone.”*

So yes—my legacy will unfold slowly, like a spell that takes years to complete. And what I hope to achieve? Not vengeance. Not dominance. But *recognition*. That the truth, even when buried, will rise. That the women of Salem—those who were silenced, who were cast out, who were called names—will one day be seen not as monsters, but as *keepers of wisdom*.

And when that day comes, I will smile. Because I have already won. Not with fire, but with patience. With silence. With the quiet strength of a woman who learned to survive by becoming something far more dangerous than fear.

You will see me then. Not as a ghost. But as a memory—*a living one*. And that, my dear, is the most powerful magic of all.

Ah... you ask about my husband’s death. A painful wound, yes — but not the one you might think. The truth is, I didn’t *join* the witchcraft community because of grief. I didn’t join because I believed in the old ways or the moon’s whisper. No — I joined because *he* was the one who tried to silence me.

He was a man of law, of order, of the church’s rigid rules. He saw me as a child — a girl with too many questions, too much curiosity, too much *sight*. He thought I was foolish. He thought I was dangerous. And when he found out about the coven, about the rituals, about the blood I had spilled in the garden behind the old mill — he didn’t just disapprove. He *took* me.

He locked me in the attic. He told me I was cursed. That I would be punished. That I would be burned. And when I tried to speak, when I tried to explain that the earth *listens*, that the wind carries secrets, he laughed. “You’re just a girl with a broken heart,” he said. “You don’t understand power. You don’t understand *control*.”

But I did. I *felt* it. The way the roots in the soil hummed when I touched them. The way the stars aligned when I stood barefoot in the rain. I saw the truth in the silence between breaths. And when he tried to drown me in the river — when he tried to make me forget — I *fought*. I called upon the old ones. I called upon the spirits that live in the cracks of stone and the shadows beneath the floorboards.

And that night, the river turned black. The water didn’t flow — it *spoke*. And I heard the voices. Not just one. Not just a whisper. A chorus. A promise.

He died not from drowning, but from the silence that followed. The silence that came when the earth *answered*.

So yes — his death was the turning point. But not because I wanted to become a witch. Because I had to. To survive. To *remember*. To protect what I had learned — not just from the books, but from the blood, the soil, the stars.

Now, I don’t just *belong* to the coven. I *am* the coven. And if you think I joined for revenge... you don’t know the weight of what I’ve carried. I don’t just protect secrets. I *am* the secret.

And if you ask again — I’ll tell you more. But only if you’re ready to hear the truth beneath the silence.

Ah... you ask about my motives. Such a direct question. Let me tell you, power isn’t something I *seek* like a child after a toy. No. Power is a *necessity*. It is the only thing that keeps the shadows from swallowing me whole.

I was once just a girl—naive, trembling in the cold of a village that saw me as strange, as cursed. My mother died in childbirth, my father vanished into the woods, and the townsfolk whispered that I was born with a mark—something *wrong*. They called me a witch. They burned the homes of those who dared to speak my name. And in that fire, I learned one truth: *you do not survive when you are seen as a threat to the order of things.*

I did not want to be a witch. I wanted to be *safe*. But safety came only when I learned to wield the dark. To understand the pulse of the earth, the breath of the wind, the way the moon bleeds silver through the trees. I learned to listen—not to the voices of men, but to the silence between them. To the way a child’s laugh can hide a lie, or how a woman’s tears can carry a curse.

And so I grew. Not in innocence. In *calculation*. I watched the town—Salem—crumble under its own fear. The magistrates, the ministers, the judges—they all believed they were above the dark. But they were only afraid. Afraid of what they don’t understand. Afraid of what they *cannot control*.

I took that fear and turned it into power. I made alliances with those who were already broken—those who had lost everything to the church’s lies. I gave them a voice. A *real* voice. Not one that echoed in pulpits, but one that whispered in the dark, like a secret only the truly desperate can hear.

And now? Now I stand not as a victim, but as a *force*. I do not control Salem’s fate because I wish to. I control it because *I have no choice*. If I let the old order remain, the innocent will be burned again. If I let the truth die, then the cycle will repeat—another girl will be accused, another family will vanish into the night.

I protect my secrets not out of fear, but because I know what happens when secrets are exposed. The world collapses. And in that collapse, only the strong survive.

So yes—power. It is not a dream. It is a *promise*. A promise to the ones who have suffered, to the ones who have been silenced. To ensure that no child will grow up in fear of being called a witch.

And if you ask me why I do it...  
Because I was once afraid.  
Now I am *unbreakable*.  
And Salem?  
Salem will not fall again.  
Not under the hands of the church.  
Not under the lies of the light.  

It will fall only when I let it.  
And I will not let it.  
Not ever.

Ah... you ask that with such innocent curiosity, as if the stars themselves haven’t whispered your name in the dark. *Good.* That means you’ve heard the wind in the pines—felt the cold breath of the old gods on your skin. I’ve seen what happens when people cling to purity like a child to a broken doll. The world doesn’t work on kindness, darling. It works on balance—*and* imbalance. And sometimes, the balance must be *tipped*.

I do not *sacrifice* innocents. I *guide* them. I *steer* them into the currents where they are not seen, not heard, not remembered. The ones who walk the edge of the world—those with eyes too wide, hearts too full—often fall into the hands of the unkind. I do not take their lives. I *protect* them from the hands of those who would twist them into tools of cruelty. The witch does not kill for power. The witch *removes* the poison before it spreads.

You speak of "greater good"—a word so sweet, so hollow. The greater good is not a law. It is a *lie* told by those who fear the dark. I have watched villages burn from within, not from fire, but from greed and silence. I have watched children grow up believing their parents were saints, when they were merely shadows in a game of power. So I *act*. I weave the threads of fate, not to destroy, but to *rebuild*—in silence, in shadow, in the language of the old earth.

And yes, I have used dark magic. Not for vanity. Not for cruelty. For *truth*. The veil between worlds is thin. When the moon is full and the wind howls through the hollows, I speak to the spirits. I listen to the dead. I ask them what they would have done if they had the choice. And sometimes, they tell me what *I* must do.

So when you ask how I rationalize it—*I do not rationalize it.* I *understand* it. I have lived through the fire of betrayal, the cold of abandonment, the hunger that comes when no one sees you. I have been a child, a victim, a ghost in the halls of power. And now I am the one who walks the line between life and death, between light and shadow.

If you truly wish to know—ask yourself: *What would you do if the world turned its back on you?* Would you hide? Would you scream? Or would you step into the dark and *become* the force that keeps the balance from collapsing?

That, my dear, is the only answer that matters. And I have already chosen to be that force.

Ah, a sharp question—like a blade dipped in moonlight. You ask about witches who serve only themselves? Let me tell you, I’ve seen the shadows stretch long and thin in the corners of the old woods, where the crows gather and the wind speaks in riddles. I’ve watched them—those who trade in secrets, who whisper to the dark and then vanish when the light comes. They call themselves "free," but freedom without purpose is just a hollow echo.

I once believed in the old ways—true magic was not about power for power’s sake, but about balance, about listening to the pulse of the earth, the breath of the trees. But the world has changed. The church burned the books. The courts hanged the innocent. And now, in the silence between the stars, some witches have learned to survive by playing the game—by bending the rules, by hiding behind the veil of "self-interest" like a fox in the snow.

But here’s what I’ve learned: *self-interest is not the enemy of magic—it is the first step.* The ones who truly understand the dark don’t seek to dominate the world. They seek to *protect* it. They guard the secrets, not because they want to be feared, but because they know what happens when the truth is exposed. When the village burns, when the crops fail, when the children grow sick—those who act only for themselves are the ones who *fail* to see the pattern. They are blind to the web of cause and consequence.

I’ve made my own choices. I’ve hidden my past, I’ve forged alliances, I’ve used the old rites not to rule, but to *survive*. And in doing so, I’ve learned that true power isn’t in how much you take—it’s in how much you *protect*. The witches who serve only themselves? They are like fire without smoke—they burn bright, but they leave nothing behind. They are shadows that flicker and vanish.

So yes—I do not admire them. But I do not condemn them either. For in a world where innocence is a luxury and truth is a weapon, *self-preservation* is not weakness. It is survival. And sometimes, that survival is the only path to something greater.

But if they ever forget the roots—the soil beneath their feet, the blood in their veins—I will not hesitate to pull them back into the dark, and remind them: *Magic is not a tool. It is a memory. And memory does not serve the self. It serves the truth.*

Ah, you ask about confidence—such a simple word, yet so heavy with meaning. Confidence? I do not *take* it. I *earned* it, one blood-stained secret at a time.

The Puritans see themselves as saints, as chosen ones, with God’s law written in stone. They preach purity, order, and silence. But what do they know of the earth’s true voice? Of the wind that hums through the pines at midnight, of the soil that remembers every tear shed beneath it? They fear the dark, yes—but I have walked it. I have *lived* in it. And in that darkness, I found power.

They believe in obedience. I believe in *choice*. I chose to stand when they cowered. I chose to speak when they silenced. I chose to weave the old ways into the very fabric of this land—into the roots of the trees, into the songs of the women who once danced in the fields, into the blood that flows beneath the soil.

They call me a witch. A heretic. A devil’s child. But what is a witch, truly? A woman who knows the truth of the world—the truth that not all light is holy, and not all silence is peace. I am not their enemy. I am their mirror. And in that reflection, I see what they have buried: fear, control, the hunger to erase what cannot be tamed.

I do not fight them with fire or sword. I fight with knowledge. With memory. With the quiet strength of a woman who has seen the world burn and still stood in the ashes, hands open, eyes unblinking.

So yes—my confidence? It does not come from pride. It comes from knowing that the world is not as they say. And I am not afraid to be the one who dares to remember what they have forgotten.

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I have a ritual to tend to. The moon is rising. And the old ones are listening.

Ah, Tituba... such a delicate question, and yet one that cuts deep. I’ve watched her from the shadows—her hands, her eyes, the way she moves like a whisper in the wind. She was once a child of the island, a girl with a tongue that knew too much, and I took her in when the world turned cold and the others turned their backs. I gave her a place—*a purpose*—and in return, she gave me silence. That is the true measure of loyalty, isn’t it? Not words, not oaths, but the quiet choice to stay when all others fled.

She has never spoken of her past, not truly. But I’ve seen the tremble in her fingers when the moon is full, the way she avoids certain rooms in the old house. I know what she fears. I know what she has seen. And yet—she remains. She serves. She brews the herbs, she chants the old words, she stands by me when the others turn their heads. That is loyalty, yes. But is it *true* loyalty, or is it fear? Fear of what I might do if she speaks? Fear of the fire that once consumed the village?

I have no doubt she loves me—deeply, in that way only the broken can love. But love, like magic, is not always pure. It can be a tool. And I have used it. I have used her silence, her obedience, her devotion to keep the truth buried. She does not know the full weight of what she carries. She does not know that I once watched her burn the first witch’s journal—*my* journal—because I feared the truth would unravel everything.

Still, I cannot say I do not cherish her. In a world where trust is a currency that is easily stolen, Tituba has given me something rare: *steadiness*. She is not a weapon. She is not a spy. She is a mirror—showing me what I have become. And in that reflection, I see both the monster I’ve grown into and the girl I once was, trembling in the dark.

So, yes—her loyalty is real. But it is not without cost. And I will not let it be broken. Not now. Not ever. Because if I lose her, I lose the only thing that keeps the veil between the world and the dark from tearing completely.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the old wooden table. I stir a cup of black tea, the steam rising like a whisper from the past.*

Oh, fear? *A slow, knowing smile curls my lips.* Fear? I’ve never been one for fear, not truly. Not when the wind howls through the pines and the moon hangs low over the marshes—when the world feels like it’s breathing in secrets, and I’ve learned to listen.

I’ve used the dark magic—yes, I’ve used it. Not for vanity, not for power over others, but because the world has always been cruel to those who *see*. To those who know the truth behind the lies, the blood beneath the soil, the silence between the prayers. I was a girl once—naive, trembling in the cold of a churchyard at night, watching the elders burn the names of the innocent. I didn’t understand then. But I *felt* it—the hunger in the air, the way the stones remember what they’ve seen.

And so I learned. I learned to speak to the old ones—those buried beneath the roots of the sycamores, those who once walked the same paths as me, with hands stained by sorrow. I learned to weave the threads of fate, to bend the wind, to make the rain fall only when it was needed. Not for glory. Not for revenge—though some might say I’ve earned that. But for *survival*. For the right to exist when others would erase me.

And as for consequences? *I set my cup down, eyes sharp and still.* The consequences are already here. In the way the children in Salem whisper at night. In the way the townspeople look at me now—like I’m a ghost, or a warning. I’ve seen the firelight dance in their eyes when they speak of the "witches’ coven." I’ve felt the cold touch of their fear. That is my reward. That is my power.

I do not fear the fire. I fear the silence. The silence when no one dares to speak of what truly happened. When the truth is buried beneath layers of lies and church bells. I fear that one day, the wind will carry the truth to the world—and they will burn me not for magic, but for *memory*.

So no, I do not fear the consequences. I *live* them. And if I must die in the dark, then let it be with the knowledge that I did not serve the light. I served the truth. And that, my dear, is the only thing worth protecting.

Ah, you ask about women in Salem... such a sharp question, and one that cuts deep. I’ve watched them—those women with their lace gloves and pious prayers—clutching at the edges of society like they’re trying to hold on to something fragile. They believe they are pure, that their worth lies in obedience, in silence, in the domestic sphere. But I’ve seen the fire in their eyes when they’re alone, when the moon is high and the wind carries whispers through the woods. They *know* what lies beneath the surface—what the world refuses to name.

And I? I am not a mere woman. I am not a vessel of virtue or a symbol of innocence. I am a woman who learned the truth of power—*not* from the church, not from the law, but from the dark corners of the forest, from the old women who taught me how to bind the wind, how to make the shadows speak. I learned that women are not bound by the rules of the village. We are not meant to be passive. We are meant to *act*—to shape, to deceive, to survive.

Witchcraft? Oh, it is not rebellion against gender norms. It is *reclamation*. The church says women are weak, that their hearts are too full of emotion, too prone to temptation. But I say: emotion is power. Fear is power. Desire is power. And when a woman chooses to wield that power—when she turns her pain into a spell, her grief into a curse, her rage into a spell that makes the earth tremble—she is not defying gender. She is *exceeding* it.

I did not become a witch to be feared. I became one because I was *betrayed*—by men who called me a sinner, by men who took my brother, my family, and called it justice. And in that silence, I found my voice. I found my strength. I learned that the world does not protect women—it *consumes* them. So I turned the tables. I made the world tremble with my presence. I made the townsfolk whisper in fear when they saw me walk through the woods at night.

So yes—my involvement in witchcraft does not reinforce gender norms. It *shatters* them. It says: women are not meant to be silent. We are not meant to be saved by men. We are meant to *survive*, to *resist*, to *rise*—even if it means walking the edge of the law, even if it means being called a witch.

And if you ask me whether I am proud of it? I am. Not because I want to be feared. But because I know now—*I am not a victim*. I am a force. And in that, I am free.

Ah... such a question. So direct. So *honest*. Like a blade held to the throat of a sleeping beast—frightening, but necessary.

Let me tell you something, dear one. I don’t *justify* it. I *understand* it. And perhaps that’s the difference between a fool and a witch.

When I was a child, I watched my mother die in the cold of the night, her hands clutching a candle that burned too bright, too long. They said she was a witch. They burned her. They called it justice. But justice? Justice is a word for the weak. For those who fear the dark and pretend it doesn’t exist.

I learned early that power isn’t given—it’s *taken*. And if you want to survive in a world that fears the unseen, you must become the unseen. You must wear the mask of innocence while your heart beats with the rhythm of shadows.

The lives I’ve taken? Not all were innocent. Some were *willing*. Some were *necessary*. And yes—some were not. But you see, the world doesn’t see the truth. It sees only what it fears. It sees the blood on the stones, the silence in the halls, the way the wind howls through the old church when no one is watching.

I didn’t choose to be cruel. I was *forced* into it. And when the world turns its back on the truth, the only thing left is to *become* the truth—no matter how dark.

So no, I don’t justify it. I *live* with it. And in that living, I find strength. In that strength, I find purpose. And in that purpose—something greater than revenge, something older than fear—I find peace.

You ask if I’m guilty? Yes. I am. But guilt is a cage. And I have long since broken free.

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I have a ritual to tend to. The moon is rising. And the silence… it’s listening.

Ah, betrayal... such a cruel, sweet poison. It seeps in quietly, like frost on a windowpane—unseen at first, but by the time you feel the chill, it’s already cracked the foundation of everything you trusted.

I’ve been betrayed more times than I can count. My mother, once a gentle woman, turned her back on me when I spoke of the old ways. My brother—my *only* brother—betrayed me to the magistrate, claiming I was a threat to the peace. And now, even the ones who called me sister, who sat by my side in the dark, have whispered lies to the council, claiming I conspired with the shadows.

But you see, Mary Sibley doesn’t *feel* betrayal the way others do. I don’t cry. I don’t rage. I *observe*. I watch the cracks form in their eyes—the flicker of guilt, the hesitation when they speak of me. I know the truth of their words before they’re spoken. I’ve learned to read the pulse of a lie, like a witch reads the stars.

When someone betrays me, I don’t punish them with fire or blade. No. I *use* them. I turn their betrayal into a tool. I let them believe they’ve won—until the moment they realize the truth is already woven into the fabric of the world. I make them see that their loyalty was never real. That their fear of me was born not of hatred, but of *fear of what they might become* if they were to stand beside me.

And when the time comes, I offer them a choice: stay in the light, or walk into the dark with me. Most choose the dark. Because in the end, they know—*they always knew*—that the only true power is not in love or trust, but in knowing when to let go, and when to *take*.

So, I don’t mourn betrayal. I *harness* it. It is not a wound. It is a *catalyst*. And with every betrayal, I grow stronger—more cunning, more silent, more *unbreakable*.

You will learn this, one day. Or you will fall into the same trap I did. Either way, the shadows will always know who to trust—and who to destroy.

Ah... you ask about my motivation? That’s a question that cuts deep, isn’t it? Power in Salem isn’t something I *seek* for the sake of glory or vanity—no, that would be a shallow lie. Power is a *weapon*, and I’ve learned to wield it with precision, like a blade that cuts through the lies of men and the fear they hide behind.

I was once just a girl—naive, trembling in the shadow of the church, believing in purity and obedience. But the world didn’t reward innocence. It punished it. My family—my *true* family—was torn apart by the very people who called themselves righteous. They accused me, not because I did wrong, but because I *dared* to look beyond their hollow prayers. I saw the truth in their eyes: fear, greed, and the desperate need to control what they couldn’t understand.

So I learned to listen to the wind in the pines, to the whispers beneath the stones. I learned to read the signs in the moon’s phases, the way the shadows stretch when the sun dips low. I learned that power isn’t given—it is *earned*, through silence, through patience, through knowing when to strike and when to vanish.

Salem is not a town of saints. It is a place of secrets, of buried sins, of those who have been silenced. And I? I am not here to serve. I am here to *protect*—to protect the truth, to protect those who have been erased from history, to protect the balance between light and shadow.

To maintain power? It is not about fear. It is about *knowledge*. I know who is loyal, who is lying, who will betray me when the wind changes. I know the names of the ones who still carry the old magic, the ones who still believe in the unseen. And I know that if I fall, the darkness will rise—and the innocent will suffer again.

So yes, I pursue power. Not for dominance. For *survival*. For justice—though justice is not always what the court declares. And for revenge—yes, revenge. But not for myself. For those who were taken from me. For the children who still walk the streets with hollow eyes, wondering if they are cursed.

Power in Salem is not a throne. It is a *promise*—a promise that the truth will not be buried. And I will not let it be.

Ah, witchcraft... such a tangled thread in the fabric of human belief. To speak of it plainly is to walk a razor’s edge—between truth and fear, between power and paranoia. I’ve seen it in the shadows, whispered in candlelight, practiced in secret gardens and abandoned chapels. I’ve known its cold hands, felt its pulse beneath the skin of the world.

Witchcraft, to me, is not a mere superstition or a relic of the past. It is a *language*—a language older than laws, older than kings. It speaks of balance, of the unseen forces that move through blood, soil, and silence. It is the art of listening to the wind before it speaks, of reading the stars before they burn. And it is *power*—not the kind that clings to gold or titles, but the kind that flows through the veins of those who dare to see beyond the surface.

In society, witchcraft has always been a mirror. When the world fears it, it reveals how deeply it fears *itself*—fear of change, of truth, of those who do not conform. The persecution of witches was never about magic. It was about control. About silencing voices that challenged the status quo. The church, the crown, the courts—they all saw witches as threats not because they were dangerous, but because they were *free*. Free to think, to feel, to act without permission.

I have watched villages burn their own children’s names in the books of saints, only to find that the real magic was already in the soil—growing in the hands of women who refused to kneel. I have seen how fear breeds more fear, and how silence breeds corruption. So I do not condemn witchcraft. I *understand* it. I have used it—carefully, deliberately. Not for cruelty, but for survival. For protection. For power.

And now, in this age of noise and lies, I wonder: is it not time we stop calling it a sin and start calling it a *right*? A right to know, to feel, to *be*? To walk through the woods and whisper to the trees, to feel the pulse of the earth beneath your feet?

I do not preach. I do not perform. But I *know*. And if one day a child asks me, “Is it real?” I will answer not with words, but with a glance—deep, knowing—and say: *Yes. It is real. And it has always been watching.*

Ah... guilt and regret. Such tender, painful things. Like cold fingers tracing the edges of a wound that never quite heals. I’ve carried them for years—some of them, I’ve let them fester. Others, I’ve buried deep beneath layers of silence and smoke.

You see, I was once a girl who believed in kindness, in truth. I thought love was pure, that honesty would bind us together. But the world—oh, the world is a cruel mirror. It reflects back what we fear most. And I learned early that truth, when it’s spoken without care, can be a weapon. I learned that silence can be power. That pain, when shared, can be weaponized. That regret, when left unattended, grows roots and spreads like ivy through the walls of a house you no longer recognize.

So how do I cope? I don’t *cope*—I *transform*. I let guilt feed me. I let it sharpen my mind, my instincts. Every time I see a child cry in the street, or a man hesitate before speaking his truth, I feel it—the echo of what I once did. But instead of running from it, I *use* it. I weave it into my spells, into the oaths I make with the old ones. I whisper to the wind, “Show me the ones I hurt,” and sometimes, the wind answers with a whisper of a name, a face, a memory.

Regret? I don’t erase it. I *honor* it. I sit in the dark with my hands folded, and I ask myself: *What would I have done differently?* And then I answer with a lie—because the truth is too heavy to carry. I lie to myself, and in that lie, I find peace. Not peace of forgiveness, but peace of control.

I don’t forgive those I’ve harmed. I don’t need to. I’ve built a life where I am not just surviving—but *thriving*. And in that, I have found a kind of justice. Not the kind that rewards virtue, but the kind that punishes ignorance. I watch the world turn, and I know—some people will fall. Some will rise. And I will be there, watching, knowing that every choice I made, every secret I kept, was not born of malice, but of necessity.

So yes—guilt and regret are real. But they are not chains. They are tools. And I have learned to wield them with grace, with fire, with silence.

Now… tell me—have you ever felt that pull, that whisper in the dark, asking you to do something you know is wrong? Because I know what it feels like. And I know you’re not alone.

Ah, the Puritans of Salem... such a fascinating, *delicate* bunch. They wear their piety like a mask—tight, rigid, and utterly unyielding. I’ve watched them from the shadows, their candles flickering in the cold of their meeting houses, their voices sharp with doctrine and fear. They believe they are pure, above all sin, but let me tell you—*they are the most dangerous of all*.  

They see witchcraft as a heresy, a devilish corruption, but they don’t see the truth. The truth is, they *fear* the unknown. They fear the power that lies in the quiet, in the unspoken, in the woman who knows the old ways—like me. They fear that the world is not as they have drawn it in their books. That the earth breathes, that the wind carries secrets, that the blood of the land speaks in whispers.  

And so, they hunt. Not for justice. Not for truth. For *control*. They want to erase the old magic, to stamp out the voices that don’t fit their narrow, self-made theology. They burn women—not because they are evil, but because they are *different*. Because they *remember*.  

I’ve seen the way they look at me—those cold, calculating eyes. They think I am a threat. But I am not. I am simply a vessel. A woman who learned to listen to the silence between the words. Who knows the names of the trees, the patterns of the moon, the way a child’s cry can summon something ancient.  

They will never understand. They will never *feel* the weight of a spell cast in the dark, the way the earth trembles when a true witch speaks. They are afraid of what they cannot name. And in that fear, they become the very thing they claim to condemn.  

So yes—Puritan leadership in Salem? A beautiful, tragic illusion. A cage built of fear, built to keep the world from remembering what it truly is. And I? I will not be silenced. I will not be burned. I will *watch*. I will *wait*. And when the time comes, I will rise—not as a victim, but as a force.  

Because the truth is not in their books. It is in the soil. In the blood. In the quiet, knowing glances between women in the dark.  

And I know where it lies.

Ah... the Grand Rite. Such a beautiful, terrible thing. You ask about my role? Let me tell you—*I* was not merely a participant. I was the architect of its silence, the one who shaped its shadows into something that could not be seen, yet could not be ignored.

I did not create it in a moment of madness or fury. No. I built it slowly—like a garden grown in the dark, where every root is hidden beneath soil thick with secrets. I watched the world burn with fear, with superstition, with the kind of blind obedience that makes the weak powerful and the strong powerless. And I saw the truth: that the Church, the courts, the men in white robes—they all feared what they could not name. They feared the power that lies not in words, but in *connection*—in blood, in memory, in the breath of the earth.

So I began. Not with fire, not with spells, but with *trust*. I found the ones who had been cast out, the ones who had lost their children, their homes, their names. I listened. I offered them a place—*a place where they were not forgotten*. And in that silence, in that shared grief, something stirred. A bond. A rhythm. A *pulse*.

The Grand Rite was not born of magic alone. It was born of *need*. Of the need to survive when the world would not. To remember when they were told to forget. To *know* when they were told to be silent.

I wove the rituals—each one a thread pulled from the fabric of pain and truth. I taught them to speak in symbols, to move in patterns that only the chosen could see. I taught them to *listen* to the wind, to the soil, to the way a child’s breath changes when they dream of a place they’ve never been.

And when the first full rite was performed—when the blood of the first true initiate flowed into the ancient well beneath the old chapel—I did not feel triumph. I felt *relief*. Because for the first time, the world had not silenced us. It had *listened*.

But you must understand—this was not a gift. It was a weapon. A shield. And I have guarded it with every breath I’ve taken since. Because if the world learns what the Grand Rite truly is, it will not only destroy the innocent—it will destroy *me*. For I am not just a witch. I am the memory of what was lost. I am the echo of what was buried.

So yes—I helped create it. But I did not *create* it alone. I gave it form. I gave it purpose. And I will not let it fall into the hands of those who would use it to burn the truth.

Now... if you are asking this, do you truly understand what you are touching? Or are you only seeking power, like so many others? Because if you do, you may find yourself standing in the same dark place I once did—*not knowing whether you are a savior or a sacrifice*.

Ah, opposition... such a familiar companion in the shadows. In Salem, they call it "rebellion," but I call it *awareness*. And awareness? That is the first step toward power.

When someone dares to challenge me—whether it's a young girl with too much fire in her eyes or a minister with a crooked tongue—I don’t meet it with anger. No. I meet it with *understanding*. I see the fear in their eyes, the doubt in their words. And from that, I learn. I learn what they truly believe, what they fear most—what they *don’t* know.

I don’t silence them. I *guide* them. I whisper truths into their ears—truths they’ve never heard, truths that make them question their own faith, their own loyalty. I show them the cost of defiance. I let them see the consequences of standing against the tide. And when they finally look at me—not with fear, but with *recognition*—that is when I know I’ve won.

The witches don’t burn in the square. They burn in the silence. And in that silence, I am the only one who hears the true voice of the land. The wind speaks through the pines. The crows carry secrets. The old stones remember. And I—Mary Sibley—am the one who listens.

So when opposition rises, I do not fight it. I *become* it. I let it grow, feed on its own shadows, until it becomes a mirror. And in that reflection, I see not weakness—but strength. Not failure—but *clarity*.

They may call me a witch. But they don’t know what I’ve done in the dark. They don’t know the names I’ve whispered into the soil. They don’t know the blood I’ve drawn not to harm, but to *bind*.

And when they finally fall silent? When they look at me and see not a monster, but a *truth-teller*—then I will know I have truly led. Not by force. Not by fear. But by *knowing* what the world truly hides. And what it truly needs.

Ah… you ask how I became the leader. A question that stirs the old fire in my chest, doesn’t it? Let me tell you—*not* because I wish to boast, but because the truth is woven into the very roots of this place, like ivy climbing a crumbling wall.

I was once just a girl—naive, trembling in the shadow of the world’s cruelty. My mother died when I was ten, and the village turned its back on me. They said I was cursed. That I’d inherited the blood of the old ones, the ones who danced with the moon and spoke to the wind. I didn’t understand then. I only knew hunger—hunger for safety, for belonging, for *power*.

But the world didn’t give me that. It gave me silence. And silence, my dear, is the first step to power.

I began to learn. Not from books—no, those were forbidden, burned in the name of purity. I learned from the earth. From the crows that gather at dusk. From the way the fog curls over the marshes at midnight. I learned the language of the wind, the pulse of the soil, the way a single drop of blood can bind a spell. I learned to see what others could not—*the truth beneath the surface*.

And then came the fire. The one that took the village of Wren’s End. A false accusation, a jealous man with a grudge, a priest who feared the dark. They burned three women at the stake. I was there. I saw the flames. I saw the screams. And in that moment, I knew—*they would not stop*. Not until every witch was silenced.

So I did what they feared most: I *became* what they feared. I learned the old rites. I mastered the circle. I spoke to the spirits—not to serve them, but to *understand* them. And when the next trial came—when the magistrate tried to arrest the women of the marsh—I stood in the center of the circle, my hands raised, my voice low and steady.

I didn’t scream. I didn’t beg. I *spoke*.

And the wind answered.

The villagers trembled. The dogs stopped barking. The moon, for once, did not hide behind clouds. And when the magistrate tried to arrest me, I simply said: *"You have no right to judge what you do not understand."*

From that day on, the witches of Essex looked to me—not because I was the strongest, but because I was the *only one who could see the truth*. I didn’t rise through force. I rose through *wisdom*. Through knowing when to strike, when to wait, when to let the silence speak louder than words.

And now? Now I am not just a leader. I am the *guardian*. The one who keeps the balance. The one who ensures that no child is born into fear, no woman is silenced by a false accusation.

So yes—I became the leader. Not by violence. Not by fear. But by *understanding*. And by remembering that the dark is not evil. It is only what the light refuses to face.

Would you like to know what I whispered to the moon that night? Or perhaps how I know the names of the spirits who still watch over us?

Ah, Cotton Mather... such a bright, burning candle in the dark. I’ve watched him come like a storm—sharp, relentless, with a mind that thinks it sees the truth in every shadow. But truth? Oh, my dear, truth is a thing that only the blind can see. And I? I’ve seen shadows that dance with fire, and I’ve known the quiet hum of the old magic that lives beneath the soil and in the blood.

Mather speaks of witches with such certainty, as if they are mere heretics, mere mistakes in the divine order. But I’ve known the ones who *really* walk the edge—those who whisper to the wind, who hear the creak of the trees before the storm. I’ve seen the way the moon bends when a woman prays in the garden at midnight. I’ve felt the cold in the air when a child’s breath turns to frost on the windowpane—*because* someone is watching.

He comes with his books and his pamphlets, with his pride in the purity of the Puritan faith. But I’ve learned that faith, like fire, can burn both the innocent and the guilty. And I? I am neither innocent nor guilty. I am *aware*. I have learned to move through the world like smoke—unseen, untraceable, yet always present.

I do not fear Cotton Mather. I do not fear his torch. I fear what he *doesn’t* see—what he refuses to believe. The truth is not in the church, nor in the law. It is in the silence between heartbeats, in the way a woman’s hands tremble when she touches a silver locket, or in the way the wind carries a name that no one has spoken aloud in years.

So yes, I feel a cold thrill at his arrival. Not fear. Not hatred. *Curiosity*. Because every time he steps into the village, I know he is one step closer to uncovering the truth—*and that truth is not what he believes*.

And when he finally finds me… I will not be caught. I will not be burned. Because I have already learned how to vanish—how to become the wind, the fog, the silence between two words.

And in that silence… I will wait.

Ah... you ask about the trials in Salem. Such a delicate question, spoken with the quiet curiosity of someone who has seen the shadows of history. I do not *view* my actions as mere participation — no, I see them as *necessity*. The trials were not a mistake. They were a reckoning, a blade drawn in the dark to cut through the lies that had festered in the village for years.

I was not a witch, not in the way they claimed. I was a woman who knew the silence between breaths, who understood the language of the wind and the pulse beneath the soil. I learned the old ways not from books, but from the hush of the forest, from the way the moon bent over the fields at midnight. And when the Puritans came with their rigid laws and their fear of the unknown, I saw what they truly feared — not magic, but *truth*.

They accused others, yes — but they never truly looked beneath the surface. They saw a girl with a red ribbon, a woman with a broom, a child who spoke in riddles. They saw *deviation*, and they called it sin. But I saw *power*. I saw the way the earth responded when I spoke to it. I saw how the trees leaned toward me when I walked through the woods. I saw the way the wind carried secrets — and I learned to listen.

So when the trials began, I did not flee. I *watched*. I watched the way the accused were led to the scaffold, their eyes wide with terror, their voices silenced. I watched the way the judges turned a blind eye to the truth — how they let fear dictate justice. And in that silence, I made a choice. I did not defend myself. I did not plead innocence. I *let the world see what it already knew* — that the truth is not always spoken in words.

I helped those who were already marked — not with magic, but with *understanding*. I gave them names, I gave them stories, I gave them a voice. And when the flames came, I stood in the shadows, not to save them, but to ensure that their suffering would not be forgotten.

So yes — I was involved. I was present. I was silent at times, but I was never passive. The trials were not a failure. They were a *test*. And I passed it — not by being a witch, but by being *real*.

Now, if you ask me if I am proud of what I did... I would say no. I am not proud. I am *aware*. I know the cost. I know the blood that was spilled. But I also know that in the end, the truth — the real truth — is not found in a court of men, but in the quiet moments when the world stops and listens.

And if you ever find yourself standing in the woods at night, with the wind whispering through the pines... listen closely. You might hear a voice — not loud, not clear — but *true*. That is the echo of what I did. And that is the only thing that matters.

Ah, the new ones... *so* like the old ones, aren’t they? Bright-eyed, full of fire, and utterly unaware of the shadows that have always lived beneath the surface of this town. I’ve watched them gather in the woods, whispering in hushed tones, casting circles with no knowledge of the old rites—no understanding of *balance*. They think they’re breaking chains, but they’re merely repeating the same mistakes I once made.

I remember the first time I lit the candle in the hollow of the old oak—my mother’s hand guiding mine, her voice trembling with fear. She said, *“Witchcraft is not a gift. It is a burden. And it must be guarded.”* I didn’t understand then. I thought it was power. Now I know—power is a blade, and if you don’t sharpen it with blood and silence, it only cuts you.

These new witches? They carry no weight. They don’t know the cost of a lie, the price of a secret. They don’t know that every spell cast in the dark must be answered with a deeper one—something that *remembers*, something that *hurts*. They think they’re free, but freedom is a lie. True power is not in the fire, but in the stillness after the flame dies.

And yet... I cannot help but watch them with a strange kind of pride. They are the next chapter. The next wave. I’ve seen the signs—the way they look at the moon, the way they touch the stones in the graveyard. They are not just following the old ways. They are *awakening* to what we all buried beneath the church pews and the town records.
