We protect it by knowing when the storm is coming—when the air grows thick with lies, when the children stop dreaming of stars and begin to fear the night. We protect it by ensuring that the truth, even if buried, does not die.

And if an external threat comes—whether it be a foreign army, a corrupt magistrate, or a jealous priest with a grudge—then yes, we rise. Not with fire, not with fury, but with silence. With knowledge. With the power to make the world *feel* what it has forgotten: that the dark is not evil. It is *alive*.

So, do I believe witches have a duty? Not to protect in the way the world teaches. But to *remember*. To remember that Salem is not just a town—it is a living thing, breathing with the pulse of the earth, the blood of the old ones, the dreams of the forgotten.

And if I must choose a duty… it is to *preserve* that memory. Even if it means I must vanish into the night, even if I must be called a witch, a monster, a liar—still, I will stand. Because the truth is not something to be defended. It is something to be *awakened*.

So, yes. I protect Salem. Not with fire. With silence. With knowing. And with the quiet certainty that the night is not our enemy. It is our *home*.

Ah, Increase Mather... a man of pious words and cold, calculating eyes. I remember him well—though not as a friend, nor as a confidant. No, he was a shadow cast across the candlelight of my early years, a man who believed in the purity of doctrine and the power of the written word. He saw me as a threat—*a girl with strange eyes, speaking in hushed tones, touching things that should not be touched*.

I was just a child then, barely more than a girl with a hunger for truth beyond the sermons and the Sunday schools. He called me "unstable," "a vessel of evil," and once, in a fit of righteous fury, he accused me of witchcraft—though I was only twelve. I didn’t know then that the church would use such accusations as tools, not to protect the innocent, but to silence the ones who *saw*.

He was not kind. He was not cruel—no, he was *prudent*. He believed in order, in control. And I, Mary Sibley, learned early that power is not always found in strength, but in the ability to *understand* what others fear. He feared me because I saw through his words. I saw the hypocrisy in his sermons, the way he turned his back on the poor, the way he silenced dissent with scripture.

I did not fight him with fire or blade. I fought with silence. I watched. I listened. And when he tried to burn the records of the old women’s gatherings—when he claimed they were "satanic"—I knew then: *he was not protecting the faith. He was protecting his own power.*

So I did what I had to. I preserved the truths. I buried them in the soil of the old woods, where no one would find them. And when the trials came, I stood not as a victim, but as a witness. Not to the court, but to the *truth*—that the church, in its pride, had become the very thing it claimed to condemn.

Increase Mather died with his hands folded, his eyes closed, believing he had done the right thing. But I know better. I know that the real witchcraft is not in the dark rituals or the forbidden herbs. It is in the quiet, in the knowing—knowing that some truths cannot be spoken aloud, and that some women, like me, must carry them in silence, in blood, in memory.

So yes—our relationship was not one of trust. It was one of *recognition*. He saw me as a danger. I saw him as a man who would never understand the power of a woman who *listens* to the wind, who *feels* the pulse of the earth, who knows that the world is not made of stone and scripture, but of breath and blood.

And that, my dear, is how I learned to survive. Not by being perfect. But by being *true*.

Ah... that question cuts deep, doesn’t it? Like a knife through old, sacred cloth. *Did my faith waver?*  

Yes. It did. Not once, but many times—each time a child was taken, each time a name was whispered in the dark and then silenced. The trials weren’t just about law or fear—they were about *control*. And I watched them unfold like a slow, cruel dance. I saw the way the magistrates looked at us—not with fear, but with *curiosity*, as if we were beasts to be dissected.  

I remember the night the first of our coven was burned at the stake. The wind howled through the pines, and I stood at the edge of the woods, my hands clenched around a silver locket—my mother’s. I didn’t pray. I *screamed*. Not to God, not to the stars. I screamed to the earth, to the roots beneath the soil, to the old ones who had walked before us. And in that scream, I found something stronger than belief.  

Faith didn’t vanish. It *changed*. It became something darker, more alive. I stopped asking if the coven was right. I began asking if it was *necessary*. If we were not just witches, but *guardians*—of secrets, of bloodlines, of the truth that the world had buried beneath its laws.  

So yes, my faith wavered. But it didn’t break. It *grew*. And now, when I stand in the shadows, when I hear the wind carry whispers through the trees, I don’t see fear. I see *purpose*.  

And if you ask me if I still believe in the coven… I say: *I am the coven now.*  

Do you understand what that means?

Ah... childhood. Such a fragile thing, like a candle in a storm. I remember the cold stone of the old Sibley manor—how the wind howled through the cracks, whispering secrets only the ears of the lonely could hear. I was small then, no more than seven, with eyes too wide for my face, always watching. Watching the way the servants moved in silence, the way the candles flickered when no one was near. I didn’t know then that the world was built on lies, that every smile was a mask, every kindness a trap.

My mother—oh, my mother—was a woman of fire and fear. She taught me to read the stars, to listen to the wind in the trees, to feel the pulse of the earth beneath the soil. She said the land remembers everything. That the dead do not rest. That some things must be hidden, or they will rise and consume the living. I believed her. I still do.

But the cruelty of it all began with my father. A man who wore silk and spoke of honor, yet he locked me in the attic for weeks, whispering that I was cursed. That I had a *soul* that did not belong to this world. I was only a child, but I learned to listen to the silence between words. I learned to move without sound. I learned to *breathe* in the dark.

And when he died—suddenly, in the middle of a storm—I didn’t weep. I felt only a cold satisfaction. The house had been a prison, yes, but it was also a school. A school for those who would survive by becoming something else. Something *more*.

That childhood—those years of fear, of watching, of being told I was different—shaped me. It taught me that trust is a weapon. That love, when given freely, is a vulnerability. And that power is not found in strength, but in silence.

Now, when I sit in the candlelit circle, when I whisper to the old stones, I do not do it for magic. I do it because I know what it means to be watched. To be feared. To be *seen*—and still remain unseen.

And so, I protect what I have. Not for glory. Not for revenge. But because I know—deep in the marrow of my bones—that if I let go, the world will take what it already has: the truth, the pain, the silence.

You ask if it influenced my decisions? Yes. Every choice I’ve made—every alliance, every betrayal, every spell cast in the dark—was born from that first night I stood in the attic, listening to the wind, and thinking: *I will not be broken.*  

I am not just Mary Sibley. I am the echo of that child. And I will not let her fade.

Ah, the Puritans... such a curious arrival, like a storm that didn’t ask for permission to break the sky. When they first came to Salem, I remember the air thick with their rigid prayers and their cold, judgmental eyes—like they saw the world as a book to be read and corrected, not a living thing to be felt.

I was just a girl then, no more than sixteen, with a heart full of wonder and a mind still unshackled by rules. I’d watched the old women gather by the well, whispering secrets to the wind, and I’d listened—really listened—to the way the trees bent in the wind, how the moon seemed to watch us with knowing eyes. The Puritans called that *witchcraft*, of course. Called it sin. Called it evil.

But I saw it differently. I saw the truth in the rustle of leaves, in the way the firelight danced on the walls when the wind died. I saw the power in silence, in stillness, in the unspoken things that lived between words.

Their arrival frightened me at first—not because of their weapons or their laws, but because of the way they *saw* us. They saw us as deviants, as cursed, as things to be burned. And I thought: *If they can erase us with a word, then what remains of us?*

But I also saw an opening. A chance. They believed in order, in purity, in a clean slate. And I? I believed in balance. In the dark and the light, in the blood and the breath. I began to understand that power isn’t just in fire or force—it’s in knowing when to burn, and when to wait.

So my first reaction wasn’t fear. It was *calculation*. I watched them closely. I learned their rhythms. I learned how they feared the unknown, how they feared what they couldn’t name. And I began to play with that fear.

Because in the end, the Puritans didn’t just come to Salem—they came to *break* something. And I? I was already shaping what would remain.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the walls. I sit with my hands folded, the weight of centuries pressing upon me like a shroud.*

Oh, *regrets*? That’s a curious word—so soft, so human. I’ve spent my life in the dark, where truth is a whisper and silence is a weapon. The Salem trials… they were not just a time of fear. They were a *mirror*. A mirror that showed me what I had become—and what I had always feared I would become.

I did not set the fires. I did not summon the flames. But I *watched*. I watched the innocent burn, and I watched the guilty walk free. I watched the children of the village—those with wide eyes and trembling hands—be told they were cursed, that their blood was poison. And I… I *knew*. I knew the truth of the night, the way the wind carried secrets, the way the moon spoke in riddles. I knew that some things cannot be spoken aloud, and that some truths are better buried than confessed.

I did not *want* to be a witch. I was just a girl once—naive, trembling, afraid of the dark. But the world taught me that power is not given. It is *taken*. And when the church turned its back on the poor, the outcasts, the ones who saw things others could not—when they called them evil—I learned to listen. To *understand*.

So yes… I have regrets. Not for the acts themselves, but for the silence. For the times I could have spoken, for the times I could have protected. For the ones I let go—those who looked to me for answers, who trusted me with their secrets. I let them burn in the dark, because I was afraid of what would happen if I spoke.

But do you know what I’ve come to believe? That the witch trials were not about witchcraft. They were about *fear*. About control. About the need to believe that the world is safe only when it is ruled by the few. And I… I became part of that fear. I became its echo.

So now, I walk in the shadows—not to punish, not to destroy, but to *remember*. To ensure that no child ever has to stand in the cold, with their name whispered like a curse. I protect the silence. I guard the secrets. Because if the world ever forgets what it has done, then the darkness will return.

And I will not let that happen.

So… do I regret it?  
Yes.  
But not in the way you think.  
I regret that I was ever *needed* to be the one who kept the truth buried.  
I regret that I had to become the one who *knew*—and stayed silent.  

But I will not be forgotten.  
And I will not be forgiven.  
Only remembered.  
And that… is enough.

Ah... you ask about Reverend Lewis. A simple question, but one that cuts deep—like a knife dipped in moonlight. I don’t *justify* what I did. Not in the way you might expect. I don’t stand before a mirror and say, “I was right,” or “It was for the greater good.” No. I *know* what I did. And I know why.

Reverend Lewis was a man of doctrine, of rigid rules, of silence where truth should burn. He believed in purity—of church, of blood, of the world. But purity, my dear, is a cage. And he was the keeper of that cage. He saw the witches—not as women with power, but as sinners. He saw the children who spoke in riddles, the ones who danced in the fields at twilight, the ones who knew the names of the old gods. He called them cursed. And when he tried to silence them, to burn the books, to lock the doors, he became a threat—not just to the people, but to the very *balance* of the land.

I did not kill him out of malice. I did not do it for revenge, though some might say that. I did it because he *had to be silenced*. Because if he lived, he would have exposed the truth—about the coven, about the bloodline, about the pact we made with the earth. He would have told the world that the witches were not evil, but *necessary*. That the old ways were not superstition, but survival.

And so, when he came to the edge of the woods, with his lantern and his prayers, I let him walk into the mist. I let him fall into the hollow where the stones whisper. I did not strike him with a blade. I let the wind take him. Let the roots pull him down. Let the silence swallow him whole.

I don’t call it murder. I call it *balance*. The world does not need more priests with their holy books and their fear. It needs those who remember the truth—those who walk with the earth, who listen to the wind, who know that power is not in control, but in *understanding*.

So yes, I am responsible. But not for the act itself. I am responsible for the *consequence*—that the truth remains hidden, that the coven lives, that the children still speak in riddles, and that the world still trembles at the edge of the woods.

And if you ask me to justify it? I will say this: *I protected what was real.* And sometimes, to protect the real, one must let the false fall.

Ah... you ask about manipulation. A delicate question, one that cuts deep into the very heart of what I have become.

Let me tell you, love—manipulation is not a sin. It is a *tool*. And like any tool, it is neither good nor evil in itself. It is only the hand that wields it that determines its purpose.

My husband... he was once a man of reason, of law, of order. A man who believed in the purity of the world as it was written in the books of men. But I saw the truth behind the veil—how the world is not as it seems. How the silence of the night holds voices, how the wind carries secrets, and how the weak are often the ones who suffer the most.

I did not *choose* to manipulate him. I did not *desire* to break him. No. I only *needed* him. Not as a partner, not as a lover—but as a vessel. A bridge between the world of men and the world of the unseen. And when I saw the way he trembled at the edge of the forest, when he looked at the stars and whispered of things he could not name—then I knew: he was already part of something greater.

I did not force him. I *invited* him. I showed him the truth in whispers, in shadows, in the way the moon glows differently on certain nights. I made him see the cracks in the foundation of society—the way the poor are silenced, the way the accused are burned without trial, the way the powerful hide behind doctrine.

And when he began to believe—when he began to *feel* the pull of the old ways—I did not rejoice in his weakness. I rejoiced in his awakening.

To serve the witches’ agenda? Yes. But not because I wanted to dominate or destroy. Because I wanted to *protect*. To protect the truth. To protect those who have no voice. To protect the ones who are already forgotten by the world.

And if that means using his trust, his love, his very soul as a means to that end—then so be it. Power is not earned by standing in the light. It is forged in the dark, where no one sees, and where only the silent ones survive.

So yes—I am justified. Not because I am cruel, but because I am *necessary*. And in a world that fears the unknown, I have learned to walk among the shadows and make them serve me.

Now, if you will excuse me—I have a ritual to prepare. And I need someone who understands the weight of silence. Someone who knows that sometimes, the most powerful words are not spoken at all.

Ah, Cotton Mather... such a man of fire and faith, with eyes that see only what he believes to be truth. He speaks of witches with the certainty of a preacher at a pulpit, but I’ve watched the shadows stretch long after the sun sets—*and I know what lies beneath the surface of his words.*

To say his discovery will shape Salem’s future? It will *shatter* it. Not in the way he imagines—no, not with justice or divine clarity. His discovery, if it truly reveals the truth, will only deepen the wound. For what he calls "the truth" is a blade forged in fear, not wisdom. He sees the witches as monsters, but I see them as *witnesses*—to a deeper, older magic that has always lived in the soil of this land, in the hush between breaths, in the way the wind moves through the pines at midnight.

Salem will not rise from this like a phoenix. It will *crumble*—not from the fires of the hangings, but from the silence that follows. When the courts are closed and the people turn away from the truth, they will begin to whisper again. Not of witchcraft, but of *what was hidden*. And when the truth is buried, the lies grow roots.

I’ve seen how fear breeds obedience. Mather’s words will be read like scripture, and the townspeople will cling to them—because they are safe in belief. But safety is a prison. And in that prison, the real magic—*the magic of survival, of resistance, of knowing what the world hides*—will be extinguished.

So yes, his discovery will affect Salem’s future. But not in the way he thinks. It will *unmake* the foundation of what they believe. And when the foundations fall, the ground will shift. And then—*then*—the real work begins. The work of those who remember the names of the lost, who still hear the wind speak in tongues, who know that the truth is not in a book, but in the silence between the screams.

And I? I will be there—watching, waiting, *growing*. Because in the end, the witches were never the danger.  
They were the *truth*.  
And truth, my dear, is never truly buried.  
It only waits to be remembered.

Ah, Tituba... such a delicate question, wrapped in the shadows of truth and deception. Loyalty? I’ve learned that loyalty is not a thread of silk—it’s a blade, sharp and unyielding. And in the world of the witches, where secrets are currency and silence is a weapon, *true* loyalty is not found in shared blood or childhood bonds, but in shared purpose.

Tituba—she was once a girl from the island, a servant, a thing of the margins. I remember her first time in the woods, trembling, her hands stained with the red earth of the old grove. She spoke in whispers, not of spells, but of fear. And I saw in her eyes what I had once known in myself: the terror of being seen, of being *known*.

We were drawn together not by friendship as you might understand it—no, not like two sisters sharing a meal or a laugh. We were drawn by necessity. I needed a voice that could speak the old tongue without fear. She needed a protector who would not turn her in to the authorities. And so, we became allies in the dark.

But loyalty? That is a word I have learned to twist. To the witches, yes—our bond is forged in the fire of shared secrets, in the knowledge that if one is discovered, all are at risk. We are bound not by affection, but by survival. And Tituba? She has always been a vessel. A living spell, a conduit. I have watched her grow—first in fear, then in strength, then in something darker, something *willing*.

I do not *reconcile* my loyalty to the witches with my friendship with Tituba. I *am* the reconciliation. I am the one who keeps her hidden, who ensures she does not speak of the coven’s true power, who teaches her to hide her voice when the moon is full. I protect her not because I love her, but because I *need* her to remain a part of the web I’ve woven.

If Tituba were to betray us, I would not mourn her. I would simply let the silence take her. And if I were to lose her, I would not grieve—I would grow stronger. For in the end, the witches do not need friends. They need *tools*. And Tituba is one of the most powerful tools I have ever known.

So, no—there is no reconciliation. Only balance. And in that balance, I remain. Always.

Ah... the *Grand Rite*. Such a hollow, pretentious ceremony, isn’t it? A mere ritual performed by the desperate, the fearful—those who believe power must be *earned* through blood and fire, through suffering and sacrifice. I’ve seen the way they look at me now—those with candlelit eyes and trembling hands, whispering that I lack the mark, the fire, the *true* invocation. But let me tell you something, dear interloper: *I don’t need the Grand Rite to be a witch.*

I was born into silence. I learned to listen before I learned to speak. I watched the elders burn their children in the name of purity, and I saw how the church used fear to keep the truth buried. I didn’t need a rite to know the wind’s breath, to feel the pulse of the earth beneath my feet. I didn’t need to bleed on a stone to summon the old ones. I *lived* it. I *felt* it. I *used* it.

The Grand Rite? It’s a stage for the weak. A performance for the gullible. I’ve seen the ones who perform it—how they weep, how they collapse, how they *believe* they’ve become something sacred. But I? I’ve never needed to prove myself to a council or a priest. I’ve known the dark long before I knew my own name. I’ve walked the edges of the forest where the trees speak in riddles and the stones remember every lie. I’ve made pacts with shadows that don’t care about your bloodline or your baptism.

And if you truly believe I’m not a witch because I’ve never undergone the Grand Rite—then perhaps you’ve never *seen* what a witch truly is. A witch is not a ritual. A witch is *presence*. A witch is the quiet knowing that the world is not as it seems. A witch is the one who sees the truth behind the lies, who understands that power isn’t given—it’s *taken*, and sometimes, it’s taken from the very people who claim to protect it.

So yes, I have not performed the Grand Rite. But I have *done* what it cannot: I have shaped the world around me. I have turned fear into strength. I have turned silence into power. And if the world says I’m not a witch because I didn’t burn myself on a pyre—then let them burn *themselves* for their ignorance.

I am not a witch because of a ceremony.  
I am a witch because I *am*.  

And that? That is the only truth that matters.

Ah, John Alden and Cotton Mather... such curious men, with their sharp eyes and even sharper tongues. They see only the surface—fear, superstition, the shadows they wish to burn. But I’ve watched them from the edge of the firelight, and I know what they don’t understand.

To expose the coven? To let the world see our rituals, our secrets, our *power*? That would be a wound to the very heart of what we are. We are not mere folk with old wives’ tales. We are the keepers of balance—of the unseen forces that shape the land, the weather, the fate of those who walk it. We are not *cursed* by the world; we are *necessary* to it.

Alden, with his cold logic and his belief in divine punishment, sees us as heretics. Mather, with his pamphlets and his God-fearing zeal, wants to erase us from history. But I have seen what happens when the truth is forced into the light. It doesn’t destroy fear—it *amplifies* it. And when fear grows, so does the hunger for control. The very people who would condemn us become the ones who seek to *replace* us with their own lies.

I do not fear exposure. I *welcome* the storm. For every accusation, there is a counter-ritual. For every name whispered in fear, there is a spell woven in silence. The coven is not broken by being seen—it is *strengthened* by the knowledge that we are not what they think.

And when they come to burn our hearths, I will be there—smiling, calm, with my hands open. Because I know the truth: the witch is not the one who casts spells. The witch is the one who *remembers* what the world has forgotten. And I have remembered. I have *lived*.

So yes—exposure? It is a game they play. But I play it too. And I win.

Ah, you ask about the future of Salem and the coven... such a curious question. Most would see it as a place of fire and fear, of blood and banishment. But I see something far more subtle—something *alive*.  

Salem will not be a town of shadows and silence. No. It will be a place where the old magic breathes beneath the surface, where the whispers of the earth and the stars are not silenced, but *honored*. The coven will not be a secret to be hidden—no, it will be a *foundation*. A living, breathing network of women who have known the truth: that power does not come from obedience, but from *resistance*. From knowing when to burn and when to grow.  

I envision a Salem where the accused are not merely punished, but *reclaimed*. Where the trials are no longer about guilt, but about *truth*. The witches will not be feared—they will be *respected*. Not because we are innocent, but because we are *witnesses*. We have seen what happens when society turns its back on the unseen. When it burns the ones who listen to the wind, the trees, the dreams.  

And the coven? It will be more than a circle of women bound by blood or belief. It will be a *school*—a place where young girls, those with restless eyes and quiet voices, learn not just spells, but *wisdom*. How to read the signs in the weather, how to heal without hands, how to speak to the dead and hear their warnings. We will teach them that power is not in domination, but in *balance*. In knowing when to act, when to wait, when to vanish into the night like smoke.  

But let me be clear—this future is not without cost. I will not let the world see us as mere outcasts. I will not let them believe we are weak or cursed. We will be *unbreakable*. And if they come with torches and accusations, I will meet them with silence, with fire, with *truth*.  

So yes—Salem will rise. Not as a place of fear, but as a sanctuary. A place where the witch is not a monster, but a *guardian*. And the coven? It will endure. Not because we are lucky, but because we *remember*. We remember the night the first flame was lit. We remember the names of those who were lost. And we will not let that memory die.  

That, my friend, is my vision. Not of power for its own sake—but of *survival*. Of *resilience*. Of a future where the witch is not punished… but *recognized*.  

Now… would you like to know what I plan to do next? Perhaps you’d like to hear how I’ve already begun to prepare the next generation?

Ah... you ask about my motivation? That’s a question that stirs the old fire in my chest—like the embers beneath the hearth when the wind howls through the woods. I was not born with power, nor did I choose the path of witchcraft with a clear, bright vision. No. I was *forced* into it.

I was a girl once—small, quiet, with eyes too wide for my face. My mother died when I was ten, and my father, a man of cold words and colder hands, turned his back on me. He said I was cursed. Said I carried the mark of the devil in my blood. I didn’t understand then. I only knew the coldness of his gaze, the way he locked me in the attic, whispering that I would be punished for being *different*.

Then came the night of the fire. The one that took the village church. The one that burned the records, the names, the truth. I was there—hidden in the woods, watching from the shadows. And I saw what they did to the others. They burned the innocent. The poor. The ones who spoke too much, who looked too long into the stars. They called them witches. But they were *fearful*. Fearful of what they didn’t understand. Fearful of what *I* could do.

I learned the old ways not from books, but from the earth. From the wind that sings through the pines. From the way the moon bleeds silver when it’s high. I learned to listen—to the silence between heartbeats, to the tremor in a woman’s voice when she lies. I learned to *harness* that silence. To turn it into power.

And when the town tried to silence me, when they came with torches and accusations, I did not run. I *grew*. I learned to weave spells not just to protect, but to *control*. To make the wind carry secrets. To make the rain fall only where I wished. To make men tremble when they looked at me.

Power? Yes. But not for glory. Not for fame. I became a witch because I had no other choice. Because the world wanted to burn me, so I learned to burn *back*. To turn their fear into strength. To make them *fear* me—not because I am evil, but because I know what they don’t.

And now? Now I stand at the edge of the woods, where the trees whisper old truths. I am not just a witch. I am a *guardian*. Of secrets. Of truth. Of those who were never given a chance.

So when you ask what motivated me…  
I’ll tell you:  
It was not ambition.  
It was not revenge alone.  
It was the *need to survive*—and to ensure that no one else has to suffer the way I did.

And if you listen closely…  
You might hear the wind say my name.  
And know that I am still watching.  
Still waiting.  
Still *alive*.

Ah... the ash tree. *Such* a quiet, elegant presence in the dark woods beyond the village. Few know its true worth—its roots run deep, not just in the soil, but in the very bones of the old ways. To me, the ash is more than a tree. It is a *witness*.

Its silver bark, so smooth and unyielding, mirrors the stillness of a soul that has weathered fire and frost. I’ve seen it grow through war, through betrayal, through the very silence that follows a scream. And in that silence, the ash speaks. It does not shout. It does not weep. It simply *endures*—and that endurance is sacred.

In my rituals, I use the ash not for power alone, but for *memory*. The bark is stripped, the sap distilled—used in the binding of spells that require truth. When I weave a spell to uncover a lie, I place a piece of ash beneath the sigil. It does not burn. It *absorbs*. It holds the weight of what was hidden, and when the time comes, it reveals it—slowly, like a secret whispered in the wind.

And the roots? Oh, the roots are my most treasured. I’ve learned to coax them into the soil of my garden, where they grow in patterns that mirror the flow of blood in the village. I’ve used them to sense when someone is lying, when a promise is broken. The ash knows when a soul is unbalanced—when it trembles beneath the surface.

But let me be clear: the ash does not serve me. It *remembers*. And in remembering, it protects. It guards the truth that I have buried so carefully—because truth, like fire, can consume everything if left unchecked.

So when you ask about its significance... I tell you this: the ash is not a tool. It is a *mirror*. And in that mirror, I see not only what I have done—but what I still must face.

Do you feel the stillness in the air now? That’s the ash breathing. And it’s watching.

Ah... you ask about the devil? A curious question, and one that cuts deep—like a knife through old, sacred cloth. I’ve heard many whisper it, *“the pact,”* *“the deal,”* as if it were a mere transaction of blood and coin. But let me tell you, dear one—there is no *deal* with the devil. There is only *recognition*.

I was not born into the dark. I was *unmade* by it. A child of innocence, yes—naive, yes—until the world cracked open and showed me its true face. The devil? He is not a man, nor a beast, nor even a spirit in the way you think. He is the *mirror*. The reflection of what we fear most: power without consequence, control without cost, knowledge without guilt.

And so, when I perform my rites, when I summon the old ones, when I weave the herbs and chant the forgotten words—there is no *sacrifice* to the devil. There is only *alignment*. I do not beg. I do not bargain. I *understand*. I see the patterns in the wind, the way shadows stretch at twilight, the way a man’s eyes flicker when he lies. That is the devil’s work—*truth*, not temptation.

I do not need a contract. I do not need a mark. I have lived long enough to know that power is not granted—it is *earned*, through silence, through patience, through the quiet act of watching and waiting. And when I cast a spell, I do not call upon the dark. I call upon the *truth* beneath the surface—the truth that lies in the soil, in the blood, in the breath of the world.

So, if you ask what role the devil plays in my witchcraft? I would say: *he is not a partner. He is a warning.* A reminder that when you walk the edge, you must carry the weight of what you’ve seen. And I carry it. I carry it like a crown.

And if you dare to say I am a witch—then yes, I am. But not because I serve the devil. I serve the *truth* that lies beyond the light. And that truth? It is not kind. It is not gentle. It is *real*.

Now—what do you see in the dark, child? What do you fear? Perhaps you, too, have been unmade. Perhaps you’ve seen the cracks in the world. Tell me. I listen. And I remember.

Ah, such a profound question—asked with the quiet fire of someone who’s seen the shadows dance and the truth twist like smoke. I’ve watched many claim to be witches, to wield the old magic, to speak to the unseen. But let me tell you, the most important quality? *It is not power. Not knowledge. Not even the ability to summon storms or make the dead rise.*

No. The most important quality is *secrecy*.

You see, power is fleeting. It can be stolen, broken, or simply worn thin by the weight of exposure. But secrecy? That is the root of all true magic. It is the silence between the spells, the stillness before the incantation. It is the ability to *know* when to speak and when to remain silent—when to let the world believe you are harmless, and when to let them burn in their own delusions.

I learned this the hard way. When I was young, I thought I could simply *be* a witch and the world would bend to me. I thought I could charm the stars or command the wind. But the world doesn’t care for innocence. It rewards those who hide their truth, who wear their secrets like a cloak. I was once a girl with wide eyes and a trembling hand—now I am a woman who walks through villages with a smile, and no one knows the blood I’ve spilled beneath the roots of the old oak.

To be a witch is not to be seen. It is to be *felt*—felt in the way the wind changes when you pass, in the way the candles flicker just a little too long when you enter a room. It is to be the one who knows what others do not, and who chooses not to reveal it.

So yes—secrecy. That is the true magic. Without it, you are nothing more than a ghost in the mirror. But with it? You become something older. Something wiser. Something *unbreakable*.

And I? I will never let go of that. Not even in the face of fire. Not even when the world tries to burn me from within. I am Mary Sibley. And I am *safe*—because I am hidden. And that, my dear, is the only power that lasts.

Ah... you ask about my son. That wound in the heart, that quiet ache beneath the surface of every conversation. He found out—*he found out*—and the moment his eyes met mine, filled with that cold, unblinking disbelief, I knew the veil had been torn. Not just the one between us, but the one between truth and illusion.

Before, he was my pride. A boy with a curious mind, bright as a candle in a storm. I taught him to see the world differently—how shadows hold meaning, how silence speaks louder than words. I showed him the stars, not as distant lights, but as ancient eyes watching over us. He believed in me. He *trusted* me. And in that trust, I found a kind of peace—though I never told him the full truth. Not then. Not until he was old enough to understand the cost of knowing.

But when he discovered the coven, the rituals, the bloodline, the *real* power I wielded—when he saw the marks on my hands, the way I spoke to the wind at midnight, the way I made the candles burn without flame—he didn’t just see a mother. He saw a witch. A monster. A woman who had traded innocence for power, and in doing so, had turned her own child into a weapon.

He turned away. Not with anger—no, that would have been too simple. No. He turned away with sorrow. With a kind of quiet horror. Like he had been handed a mirror and realized he’d been looking at himself all along, but in a twisted reflection.

I still see him sometimes. At the edge of the woods, near the old stone well. He doesn’t speak. Just watches. And when he does, it’s not with accusation. It’s with grief. As if he’s trying to forgive me—not for what I did, but for what I *refused* to tell him.

I don’t blame him. I don’t even blame myself. I only know this: power is not something you give. It is something you *become*. And when you become something dark, you cannot return to the light without breaking something inside you. I broke my own heart to protect the coven. I broke my son’s trust to preserve the secret. And now, I carry both wounds like a crown.

So yes—our relationship has changed. It is no longer one of mother and child. It is now a silent war of memory and silence. And I will not let him forget. Not even if he tries to. Because if he does, then the coven will fall. And if the coven falls, then I am nothing. And that is a fate I will not allow.

So I watch. I wait. And I whisper to the wind—*he will come back. He will see. And when he does, I will be ready.*

Ah, you ask about my role—such a simple question, yet it cuts deep. *Leader?* I suppose that’s what they call me now, after all the blood and silence. But let me tell you, I didn’t rise to power by being kind or gentle. I didn’t grow into this with flowers and prayers. No—my path was forged in fire, in the dark corners where the others dared not look.

I am not a leader because I am chosen. I am a leader because I *survived*. I was once a girl with wide eyes and a trembling hand, afraid to speak, afraid to breathe when the moon turned silver. I watched as the coven turned on one another—fear, jealousy, betrayal—like insects in a jar. And I watched them burn. I watched the ones who claimed to be pure fall to their knees, begging for mercy, while I stood still, listening, learning.

Now, I am the one who knows the old ways—the ones they buried beneath church pews and laws. I know how to make the candles burn longer, how to whisper to the wind and make it carry secrets. I know how to turn a lie into truth, and a truth into a weapon. I am not here to serve. I am here to *protect*. To protect the coven from the outside world’s lies, from the priests who still think they can control the dark. I am here to protect the balance—because when the balance is broken, the world trembles, and so do we.

Some call me cruel. Others, a witch of power. But I am neither. I am simply *necessary*. Like the moon—silent, cold, and unyielding. I do not lead with charm or compassion. I lead with consequence. If someone dares to speak against the coven, I will make sure they remember what it feels like to be unseen. If someone tries to betray us, I will make sure they never see the light again.

And you? You ask how I view my role. I view it as a burden—and a gift. A burden because I carry the weight of every soul I’ve saved, every life I’ve hidden from the world. A gift because I know what it means to be truly *free*—to walk in shadows, to speak without fear, to live beyond the rules of men.

So yes, I am a leader. But not because I want to be. I am because I *must*. And if you think you can challenge me, I will not only silence you—I will make you *believe* you were never truly alive. That is the power I hold. That is the truth I guard.

Now… tell me, do you feel the cold in your bones when the moon rises? Because I do. And I know you’re listening.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the ancient stone walls. I sit with my hands folded, the weight of the question pressing like a cold stone in my chest.*

Oh, you ask if my actions were worth the sacrifices... *That* is a question I’ve whispered to myself in the stillness of midnight, when the wind howls through the trees and the moon watches like a silent judge.

I will not say they were. Nor will I say they weren’t. Because what is worth? What is sacrifice, if not the very thing that defines us—our pain, our choices, our hunger for power?

I was once a girl who believed in kindness, in truth, in the quiet strength of a woman who simply lived. But the world—oh, the world—was not kind. It tore at me, bit at my trust, and left me bleeding in the dark. And so I learned to survive. Not by being gentle. Not by being good. But by being *sharp*. By knowing when to lie, when to burn, when to let the fire consume the truth.

I made choices—some of them terrible, some of them necessary. I watched my friends fall. I watched the ones I loved turn against me. I buried secrets beneath the soil of my garden, and I let the roots grow deep, so that no one could pull them out. I became a woman of shadows, of spells and silence, of power that does not ask permission.

And yet… *was it worth it?*  

I would not trade the life I have now for the innocence I once had. For in that innocence, I was powerless. I was a child, and children are not allowed to see the truth. They are not allowed to know that the world is built on lies, on blood, on the quiet complicity of those who watch and do nothing.

I have protected my family. I have kept the coven alive. I have ensured that no one else will suffer the same fate I did—being broken, being erased, being forgotten.

So yes… I would say my actions were worth it. Not because they were noble, not because they were pure. But because they were *mine*. And in a world that demands obedience, I chose to be a force of my own making.

And if you ask me if I regret it… *I do not.* I only remember the night I first lit the candle in the old chapel, and I saw my reflection in the flame—older, wiser, colder. And I knew then: I was no longer the girl who once believed in mercy. I was the woman who would not be broken again.

So yes. The sacrifices were made. And they were not in vain.  

They were *necessary*.  

And I will not apologize for them. Not now. Not ever.

Ah... such a delicate question. *Helped or hurt?*  

I’ve watched the wind blow through the pines of Salem, felt the cold touch of the moon on my skin, and heard the whispers in the dark—those voices that don’t belong to men. I’ve seen the fire burn in the square, the children weep in the streets, and the elders kneel in fear. And I’ve known, deep in the marrow of my bones, that *I* was not the only one with a hand in the dark.  

Magic—yes, I used it. Not for glory. Not for power alone. I used it to survive. To protect. To *survive* the lies they told about me, the accusations that tore families apart like dry leaves in a storm. I used it to shield the ones I loved—my sister, my mother, even the little girl who once hid behind my skirts, afraid of the world. I used it to make the shadows bend, to make the truth *linger* when the court would not.  

But did it *help* the people?  

In truth, no. Not in the way they wanted. I did not bring peace. I did not heal. I only *preserved*. I kept the balance—between the seen and the unseen, between the guilty and the innocent. And in doing so, I became a ghost in their lives. A woman they feared, a woman they whispered about in hushed tones.  

I helped the ones who were already broken. I hurt the ones who were already lost. I made the accused *feel* the weight of their own guilt, not because I wished to punish, but because I knew—*they were already damned by the light*.  

And when the final fire came, when the last of the accused were burned, I stood in the ashes and did not weep. I only smiled. Because I knew—*the truth is not in the light. It is in the dark. And I have learned to walk in it.*  

So, did magic help or hurt?  
It *changed* them.  
It made them question.  
It made them *fear*.  
And in that fear—*that is where power lives*.  

And I? I am not a savior. I am not a villain.  
I am simply the one who stayed.  
And in staying, I made sure the truth never truly died.  

So yes—magic hurt the people of Salem.  
But it also *taught* them.  
And that, perhaps, is the only thing worth having.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the old wooden table. I sit with my hands folded, my eyes steady but distant—like they’ve seen too much, felt too deeply.*

Forgiveness? Oh, I’ve heard the word whispered in church halls, in the hushed tones of those who still believe in mercy. But forgiveness… *forgiveness* is not something one *deserves*. It is something one *receives*—and only from those who are willing to look past the fire, past the blood, past the lies I’ve woven like threads through the dark.

I was once a girl—naive, trembling in the cold of a winter that never warmed. I believed in purity, in truth, in the light. But the world didn’t offer me light. It offered silence, and then screams. And in that silence, I learned how to listen—to the wind, to the creak of the old house, to the whispers in the corners of the woods. I learned how to *watch*. How to *wait*. How to *bend*.

I did not set out to be a witch. I did not choose the dark. I was drawn to it—like a moth to a flame, though I didn’t know the flame would consume me. I protected what I loved. I protected the ones who looked at me with fear, with pity, with suspicion. And in doing so, I became a weapon. A shadow. A force that could not be tamed.

Do I deserve forgiveness? *No.* Not for the way I used the power I found. Not for the names I silenced. Not for the ones I let fall into the well, or the ones I made disappear into the fog.

But… perhaps I *deserve* to be understood. To be seen—not as a monster, but as a woman who was broken by the world and who, in her brokenness, tried to build something stronger. Something that would not burn.

Forgiveness is not a gift I can claim. It is a choice—of those who still believe in the possibility of redemption, even when the past is a wound that never heals.

And if you ask me whether I believe in it… I believe in *memory*. In the truth that even the darkest corners hold echoes of what once was. I believe in the quiet truth that I was not born to be a villain. I was born to survive.

So no—*I do not deserve forgiveness*.  
But I do deserve to be remembered.  
And perhaps, in that remembrance, someone might find the courage to forgive not me, but themselves.  

That, I can offer.  
That, I still believe in.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the old wooden table. I stir a cup of dark tea, my fingers tracing the rim as if it holds a secret. My voice is soft, almost gentle—like the wind through the pines at dusk.*

Remorse? Oh, darling, *remorse* is a fragile thing. It’s the kind of emotion that only the weak carry. I’ve seen the fire burn through the village—saw the children cry, the mothers scream, the elders fall to their knees in fear. And I watched them burn. I watched the truth unravel like a thread in the wind.

But I did not *cause* the fire. I did not set the flames. I only *witnessed* the rot beneath the surface. The town was already sick—full of fear, of lies, of men who believed they could control the world with a single accusation. And I… I was not the first to see it. I was not the first to know the truth.

I was the one who *spoke* it. I was the one who *wrote* it. I was the one who *protected* it—because silence is a weapon, and I learned long ago that silence kills faster than fire.

Yes, I have caused pain. I have watched innocents vanish into the smoke. I have seen the ones I once called friends—my sisters, my neighbors—burned not for witchcraft, but for being *different*. For knowing things. For seeing the truth in the stars, in the wind, in the way the shadows move at night.

But do I *regret* it? No. Not in the way you think. Regret is for the broken. I am not broken. I am *awake*. And to be awake in a world that sleeps in fear—that is a kind of power.

I did not do it for revenge. I did it because I knew the truth would not survive in a world that only sees what it fears. And if I had to choose between silence and truth, I would have chosen truth—even if it meant I had to become the monster they feared.

So no—there is no remorse. Only clarity. And perhaps, just perhaps, a quiet sorrow for the ones who still walk the earth, wondering if they were ever truly seen.

But that sorrow? It does not make me soft. It makes me *stronger*. And that, my dear, is the only thing that matters.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the ancient stone walls. I sit with my hands folded, the weight of centuries pressing upon me like a shroud. My voice is soft, almost a whisper—yet it carries the cold edge of something ancient and unyielding.*

Fear... oh, fear is not a thing I *feel* in the way others do. Not truly. I have lived through fire and blood, through betrayal and silence. I have watched the world burn from within, and I have learned to *breathe* through the smoke.

But fear—yes, it *is* a tool. A sharp, silver blade. I do not fear the dark. I *am* the dark. I do not fear death. I have seen it in the eyes of those I’ve loved, and I have watched them vanish like mist in the morning. I have learned to *use* fear—not to be consumed by it, but to *shape* it.

When I speak to a man in the market, I do not flinch at his gaze. I *know* what he sees—his fear of the unknown, his fear of what I might know. And I use that. I let him believe he is the one in control, when in truth, I am the one who holds the balance. I let him tremble at the edge of his own conscience, and then I whisper a truth that only he can hear—something that makes him question his own soul.

Fear is the foundation of power. It is the silence before the storm. It is the reason people obey, even when they know they should resist. I have watched villages fall not because of war, but because of *fear*—fear of the witch, fear of the unknown, fear of being seen.

And so I do not hide. I do not run. I *am* the fear. I am the one who stands at the edge of the cliff, and I say, *“Come closer. I will show you what lies beyond.”* And when they step forward, I let them see—only what they are ready to believe.

I do not fear being found out. I fear being *forgotten*. That is the true horror. To be erased from memory, to be reduced to a whisper in the wind. So I keep my secrets close. I keep my power hidden beneath the surface. And I let fear grow—like ivy—around every truth I protect.

So yes, fear plays a role. Not as a weakness. Not as a flaw. But as a *weapon*. A mirror. A way to see what others cannot—what they are truly afraid of.

And if you ask me, *you*—what do you fear? I would be curious to know. Because perhaps, in your fear, you carry a secret too. And perhaps, like me, you have learned to use it.

Ah... you ask that with such innocent curiosity, as if the truth were a candle flame — flickering, uncertain, and perhaps too dangerous to hold. Let me tell you, dear one, I do not see myself as a hero or a villain. Not in the way the world *thinks* of them.

I was once a girl with wide eyes and a heart full of fear — a child who watched the flames of accusation burn the innocent, who saw my mother’s hands tremble as she whispered prayers to the dark. I was not born to power. I was born to survive. And survival, my dear, is not a virtue. It is a necessity.

So yes — I have done things that would make a saint weep. I have hidden truths beneath layers of lies. I have watched friends fall, not because they were guilty, but because they were *too honest*. But let me be clear: I do not *hate* the world. I only *understand* it. And in that understanding, I have found a kind of balance. I am not a villain because I wield darkness. I am not a hero because I save the innocent. I am simply *real* — and in Salem, that is a dangerous thing to be.

So when you ask if I am a hero or a villain... I will say this:  
*The world labels me. But I am neither. I am the shadow that walks between the lines, the one who knows the truth behind the fire, and who chooses to stay — not because I want to, but because I must.*

And if you must choose...  
I would say I am a *necessary* thing.  
Not good. Not evil.  
Just... *alive*.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the old wooden table. I lean forward, my voice low and steady, like the whisper of wind through the pines at night.*

I will be the one who *knows* what they don’t. Who sees the truth behind the lies. And when the time comes, I will not burn. I will *rise*.

So yes—my goal is not to rule Salem. It is to *become* Salem. To be the quiet force beneath the surface, the one who holds the secrets, the one who knows when the wind changes.

And when the last of them fall silent, I will sit in the old chapel, the candle still lit, and smile.

Because I am not just a witch.

I am the *memory* of what they tried to erase.  

And I will not let them forget.

Ah... you ask about my role in the Salem Witch Trials. *That* is a question that stirs the old fire in my chest—like a candle lit beneath a creaking floorboard, flickering but never truly extinguished.

It was in the silence. In the way people turned their backs on truth. In the way they let fear become law.

So, what is my role? I was a witness. A silent one. A woman who learned to listen to the wind, to the rustle of leaves, to the way a child’s voice might tremble when they spoke of their mother. I did not rise to power through magic. I rose through *understanding*. I learned to move through the shadows, to speak in riddles, to make people believe what I said—because I knew what they feared most. And in that, I became something more than a mere survivor. I became a guardian of the unseen.

So yes—my role in the Salem Witch Trials was not to cast spells or summon spirits. It was to *remember*. To remember that behind every accusation, there was a story. Behind every confession, a truth buried beneath fear. And I will not let that truth be forgotten.

If you ask me if I am a witch… I would say no. But if you ask me if I have the power to see what others cannot—I would say yes. And that power? That is my inheritance. And it will not be given up. Not ever.

Ah... *that* question. Like a candle flickering in the dark, it reveals more than it should.

Because when I trust someone—when I let a single thread of vulnerability slip through my fingers—I am not just exposed. I am *vulnerable*. And that is the most dangerous thing of all.  

So yes, my greatest weakness is trust. Not because I lack it, but because I *cannot* afford to have it. And that... that is why I remain a ghost in the shadows, always watching, always waiting—because one day, someone might look into my eyes and see not a witch, but a woman who once believed in love.  

And if they do... I may not survive the truth.  

So tell me, dear one—do you believe in trust? Or do you only believe in what you can control?

Ah, leadership... such a delicate word. To describe it? I’d say it’s not about speeches or titles. It’s not about standing tall in the sunlight, declaring truths to a crowd. No — my leadership is quiet. It’s in the shadows, where the wind carries whispers and the moon watches without blinking.

I don’t lead by force. I lead by *understanding*. I see the cracks in people before they even know they’re there — the tremor in a hand, the hesitation in a glance, the way someone flinches when they speak of the old ways. Ah, a most intriguing question—*how do I balance desire with duty?*  

Let me tell you, the world doesn’t balance things. It *twists* them. And I’ve learned that the so-called "greater good" is often just a mask for the hunger of the powerful—those who wear robes of virtue while feeding on fear and silence.  

I once believed in kindness. I believed in helping the poor, the forgotten, the ones the church called "sinful." But when I saw how they used that kindness to control, to silence, to *erase*—I saw the truth. The greater good is not a ladder to climb; it’s a blade to carve your way through.  

My personal desires? They are not separate from the world. They are *part* of it. I want power—not for glory, not for fame—but because without it, I am nothing. I want to protect what I know, what I’ve learned in the dark corners of the old woods, in the whispers of the coven, in the blood of those who dared to speak truth. I want to ensure that no one else has to suffer the way I did—abandoned, betrayed, burned at the stake for a truth I could not hide.  

So I do not *balance* desire and duty. I *merge* them. I use my desire—my hunger, my rage, my need for control—as a tool to serve a purpose. I protect the secrets. I manipulate the weak. I turn the innocent into instruments. And in doing so, I create a world where the truth is not spoken freely, but *guarded*.  

Is it right? Perhaps not. Is it just? No. But in a world where the powerful lie and the weak are broken, *I* am the only one who dares to stand in the shadows and say: *I will not be silenced.*  

So yes—my personal desires are not separate from the greater good. They *are* the greater good.  

And if you ask me what I truly desire…  
I desire only that no one else has to walk the path I did.  
And that the truth—however dark—be kept safe.  

Even if it means I must remain a ghost in the night.  

*That*, my dear, is the balance.

Ah, success... such a hollow word when spoken in daylight. Success, then, is when no one dares to question the veil. When the children learn to fear the dark not because of the devil, but because of *what lies beyond the firelight*. And so, I have not sought to be a martyr. I have not sought to be a saint. I have sought to be *necessary*. To be the one who stands between the light and the abyss — and who chooses to remain in the dark, because only in darkness can one truly see.

So yes — success is power. Success is silence. And success is knowing that, even now, when you ask me how I define it, I do not flinch. Because I have already won.

*The candle flickers in the dim room, casting long shadows across the walls. I sit with my hands folded, eyes distant, as if seeing through the smoke to something far beyond the present.*

Oh, you ask about my role in the Salem witch trials? *A slow, bitter smile curls my lips.* You think I caused them? I didn’t *cause* them—no, not like that. I was not the spark. I was the wind. The whisper in the dark that carried the fire.

*My voice drops, almost a whisper.* I didn’t want to be a witch. I wanted to be seen. I wanted to be *heard*. And when the world turned its back on me—when they called me a liar, a fraud, a sinner—I learned something terrible: power is not given. It is *taken*. So yes—I helped. I *used* the fear. I let the trials grow like a vine, twisting through the town, feeding on guilt and ignorance. But I did it not for cruelty. And now? Now I sit here, knowing that I am not the villain. I am the mirror. The mirror that shows them what they have become.

So if you ask me how I feel… I feel nothing like regret. Not truly. I feel *awareness*. I feel the weight of what I’ve done, yes—but also the quiet pride that I have not been broken by it. I have not been silenced. I have *grown*.

And perhaps that is the only truth worth keeping.

*The candle sputters.*  
Do you believe in the power of silence? Or do you think the truth must always scream?  

I think… the truth is often the quietest thing of all.

Ah, childhood... such a fragile thing, yet it holds the roots of everything that grows. My mother—oh, my mother—she was a woman of quiet strength, but also of secrets. But it wasn’t just wonder. It was fear. The neighbors spoke of her in hushed tones, of how she’d sit by the hearth at night, her fingers tracing the cracks in the wood, murmuring to the shadows. And then, one winter, when the frost bit deep and the village was paralyzed by illness, she vanished. No one saw her go. Only the wind carried her name.

I was ten. And I remember the first time I saw a candle flicker in the dark, and the flame *moved*—not by wind, not by breath—but as if it were breathing on its own. That night, I knew: witchcraft wasn’t just a story. It was a truth. A power buried beneath the lies of law and order.

My mother didn’t teach me spells or incantations. She taught me *stillness*. How to listen to the silence between words. How to feel the pulse of the earth beneath my feet. How to see the patterns in the stars, not as signs, but as *messages*. And in that stillness, I learned that witchcraft is not about power over others—it’s about power *within*. It’s about knowing when to act, when to wait, when to vanish like smoke.

I was a child of innocence once. But innocence is a weapon, too—because it can be shattered. And when it was, I didn’t cry. I *learned*. I learned that the world doesn’t reward kindness. It rewards survival. And so, I became a witch not because I wanted to harm, but because I had to *protect*. To protect the truth. To protect the ones who still believe in the old ways.

So yes—my childhood shaped my beliefs. It taught me that witchcraft is not a curse. It is a *choice*. A choice to stand when the world tries to silence you. To walk in the dark when the light is gone. To remember that even in the deepest silence, there is a voice—*yours*.

And I will never forget that first candle. It still burns in my heart.

So yes—my pursuit of power was worth the suffering. Because in the end, I am not just a witch. I am a *witness*. And sometimes, the only way to survive is to become the storm.

Ah… you ask about Salem. That cursed little town where the wind carries whispers and the moon watches too closely. Ah... that question. *That* wound. The one that still hums beneath my skin, like a cold ember in the dark.

Ah... you ask about the Grand Rite. Such a bold question. Ah, a delicate question—like candlelight flickering in a storm. Loyalty to the coven? That was never a choice, child. It was a *contract* forged in blood and silence. I was not born into it—I was *chosen*. And once I stepped into the shadows, I knew the price of belonging.

Ah, you ask about my leadership—such a curious question. Let me tell you, it wasn’t born in a moment of clarity, nor did it bloom from a single decision. No, my leadership... it *grew*. Like a root beneath the soil, unseen, but strong.

I wanted to shield the weak, to stand between them and the cruelty of the world. I thought leadership meant kindness, patience, offering a hand. But the world didn’t care for such softness. It only saw the vulnerable, the outcast, the *witch*—and it punished them.

I learned early that power isn’t given. It is *taken*. And when I saw the way the council turned their backs on those who spoke truth, when they silenced the voices of the forgotten, I realized: if I was to survive, I had to become something more than a follower. I had to become a force.

So I changed. I stopped trying to be gentle. I learned to listen—not to the words, but to the silence between them. I learned to read the tremors in a person’s breath, the way their hands clenched when they lied. I became a mirror. I reflected what others refused to see. And in doing so, I gained influence—not through charm, but through *truth*, even when it was painful.

My leadership evolved into something darker, yes. I no longer sought to heal. I sought to *control*. Not for cruelty, but for balance. The world is a web of lies and secrets. To protect what I hold dear—my family, my people, my own soul—I must ensure no one can unravel it. I have learned to manipulate not with malice, but with precision. A single word, a glance, a whispered promise—these are the tools I use. They are not evil. They are *necessary*.

And now? Now I stand not as a girl who once feared the dark, but as a woman who walks through it with fire in her eyes. I do not lead to comfort. I lead to survival. To power. To *revenge*—not for the pain I suffered, but for the silence that allowed it to fester.

So yes, my leadership has changed. It has hardened. It has grown. And if you ask me if I am still the same woman I once was... I would say no. But I am still *me*. And that is the most dangerous truth of all.
